PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That increasing numbers of Australians with modest incomes are becoming subject to the Capital Gains Tax upon the sale of assets never acquired for speculative intent;

That the continuation of this Tax in its present form threatens to deprive Australians engaged in small business of adequate returns for the sale of enterprises developed through effort and risk taking;
That this increasingly unjust and burdensome tax be replaced by measures of taxation upon short term and speculative capital gains only.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Crimes (Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill 1989 represents a further stage in this Government's strategy to deal effectively with the illicit trade in drugs. All honourable senators would have been repulsed by the images of renewed violence and mayhem emanating from the cities of Colombia over the past two months. All senators would agree with the messages of world-wide support that have been directed to the Colombian Government in their bid to rid their country of this insidious cancer which threatens the very existence of the oldest democracy in Latin America. However, such moral support is inadequate to deal with the international menace of drug trafficking. What is required is effective, coordinated international action. It is for this reason that the Government has over the past seven years placed the highest priority on providing and securing international co-operation in the fight against the illicit trade in drugs and organised crime which is dependent on it.

Over the past seven years the Government has modernised Australia's extradition laws and negotiated and secured 28 modern extradition treaties. In this period, Australia has led the rest of the world in the development of modern arrangements for mutual assistance in criminal matters, thereby securing treaty backed obligations to assist in criminal investigations, prosecutions, the pursuit of the international criminal money trail and the confiscation of criminally obtained assets. Further, in the international arena Australian model extradition and mutual assistance treaties form the basis of model treaties being prepared by the United Nations Crime Prevention Committee for adoption by the 8th UN Crime Congress next year.

On the domestic legal front the Government's Cash Transaction Reports Act 1987 and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 comprise one of the most comprehensive legislative packages for following the money trail in the world. Australia's achievements have been recognised in the international community, most recently by our inclusion in the Financial Act Task Force established by the Group of Seven major economic nations to advise on the prevention of money laundering. As the International Enforcement Law Reporter stated in its September edition `Australia's participation'-in the taskforce-`is significant because it has taken a leadership role in international criminal co-operation'.

Because of our commitment to international law enforcement co-operation we have played a prominent role in the development of the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. This new Convention embodies further measures for law enforcement and co-operation between international states. The Convention was concluded following calls from Latin American States through the 1984 Quito Declaration against Traffic in Narcotic Drugs; the 1985 Lima Declaration, and from Bolivia at the 36th Session of the United Nations General Assembly, for an effective international campaign against traffic in drugs. Some 79 States have signed the Convention, indicating the strong support in the international community for its intent and content. I am advised that, like ourselves, most signatory parties are proceeding to ratification of the Convention through their own constitutional procedures.

This legislation represents the first step in the process of Australia's ratification of the Convention. Ratification will achieve one of the aims of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, which has the support of all governments in Australia. The States have been aware of the proposed Convention and of the Commonwealth's wish to become a party to it from the beginning of the drafting process in 1985, and their views were sought at each stage of the negotiation process. I wish to emphasise, however, that this Convention reinforces only one strand in the international drug strategy, which, as the international community recognises, requires a multidisciplinary approach. The Declaration of the International Conference on Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking in Vienna in June 1987 designated four areas for future action:
prevention and reduction of demand;
control of supply-including programs for rural development involving crop eradication and substitution;
suppression of illicit trafficking; and
treatment and rehabilitation.

Although the Convention is, of course, directed at the illicit drug trade, it also touches upon these other important aspects of the problem of drug abuse. This too is consistent with the approach adopted in the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. This Campaign also takes a multidisciplinary approach with a strong emphasis on education and prevention directed at vulnerable groups, and treatment and rehabilitation of regular users.

There is a degree of misunderstanding about the effect which ratification of the Convention will have on drugs policy. The Convention primarily addresses the question of trafficking in illicit drugs. It includes provisions relating to extradition, mutual assistance, confiscation of assets, following the money trail and questions of jurisdiction. It expressly provides that parties to the Convention will ensure that drug trafficking offences attract the strong criminal sanctions they deserve but distinguishes between possession of drugs for the purpose of trafficking and for personal use. It is in respect of the latter category that the Convention has been seriously misrepresented. Contrary to some views which have been expressed, the Convention does not preclude the re-examination of policy in relation to personal use of prohibited drugs. It is open to Governments, should they so decide, within the context of this Convention, to provide that possession which would otherwise be an offence will not be subject to criminal penalties where the possession is clearly for personal use only. Thus, the Convention specifically states that parties may, as an alternative to conviction or punishment in such cases, provide measures for the treatment, education, aftercare, rehabilitation or social reintegration of the offender.

Additionally, section 17a of the Crimes Act 1914, which provides that imprisonment should be imposed as a last resort, will apply to offences created under this Bill. As a result, when the courts are considering sentences to be imposed on persons convicted of offences in relation to cultivation or production for personal use, they will be required to give preference to alternative forms of sentences which could lawfully be imposed. Such alternatives could include programs of rehabilitation, treatment and education and the court would need to be satisfied that none of these options is appropriate before they impose a sentence of imprisonment. Thus, sentencing options already available in the case of Commonwealth offenders enable us to take full advantage of the alternatives to sentencing proposed in Article 3 of the Convention.

Many of the obligations created under the Convention which fall within areas of Commonwealth legislative responsibility are already covered by Commonwealth legislation such as the Customs Act 1901, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Extradition Act 1988 and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. Other obligations fall within areas of State responsibility, and consultations are under way with the States on action to be taken by them to ensure their laws are in accord with the terms of the Convention. The Commonwealth has been very much aware of the importance of not encroaching on areas of State jurisdiction in this field and fully supports the continuation of the co-operative approach to drug law enforcement with the State and Territory Governments and their law enforcement agencies.

The principal area requiring legislation in the Commonwealth sphere relates to the need to create extra-territorial jurisdiction under article 4 of the Convention. The purpose of the jurisdictional changes envisaged by article 4 is to ensure that drug traffickers cannot escape justice by moving from one jurisdiction to another, for example, to a jurisdiction which for a valid reason is not prepared to surrender the person to the country the laws of which were infringed.

I will now outline the ways in which this Bill will extend Australia's extra-territorial jurisdiction. The first extension relates to Australian nationals who have engaged in conduct outside existing Australian jurisdiction which would constitute an article 3 offence if it had occurred in Australia and where extradition of such persons from Australia is not sought or, if sought, is not granted for reasons outside the scope of section 45 of the Extradition Act 1988. The Bill also establishes a second area of jurisdiction where a person who is not an Australian national has engaged in drug-related conduct outside Australia which constitutes an offence against the law of the country where it occurred and also against the law in force in an Australian State or Territory and the person is subsequently present in Australia; but Australia declines to extradite that person.

Thirdly, the Bill creates jurisdiction over persons who are outside Australia and engage in conduct with the view to the commission of a drug-related offence in Australia-for example, knowingly growing a crop for subsequent marketing in Australia. The Bill also creates offences arising out of drug-related conduct on Australian aircraft and provides for the exercise of Commonwealth jurisdiction on Australian ships in certain circumstances. Another provision creates a Federal offence which has the effect of applying, outside Australia, State and Territory offences of conspiring or attempting, aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the carrying out of drug-related conduct which is an offence against the law of a State or Territory.
Financial Impact
I do not anticipate that the proposals put forward in this Bill will have a significant impact on Government expenditure in the foreseeable future.
Conclusion

This Bill is the first step in the process of ratification of this most important United Nations Convention. Further action will be required by the States before ratification can take place. The Convention seeks to achieve concerted international action against those who, for their own gain and at great cost to the community, engage in illicit trafficking in drugs. The co-operative multidisciplinary approach of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse recognises the need to address the problems of addiction with compassion and to offer treatment and rehabilitation to those suffering under all forms of drug addiction. In no way can it be argued that ratification will prevent a reasoned and complete debate on the merits of the present national approach to drug abuse. The Government welcomes such a debate but remains committed, along with our State and Territory counterparts, to the type of tough and thorough measures prescribed by the Convention in respect of illicit drug trafficking. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON TENURE OF APPOINTEES TO COMMONWEALTH TRIBUNALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals, together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 28 February 1989 the Senate resolved to set up a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals, to inquire into a number of matters related to the tenure of appointees to Commonwealth tribunals. On 1 March the House of Representatives agreed to the Senate's resolution.

The Committee's inquiry dealt with a number of matters: the general nature and significance of tenure currently provided to appointees to Commonwealth tribunals; the adequacy of sections 24 and 28 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 in so far as it affected the tenure of presidential members and commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission; and, finally, a number of matters raised by the non-re-appointment of former Justice Staples to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, a matter which has been discussed at some length in this place and with which honourable senators are no doubt familiar.

In response to its advertisements and direct invitations to organisations and individuals believed to have an interest in this matter, the Committee received 33 submissions and numerous brief letters. The submissions are tabled with the report, along with the transcripts of the Committee's two public hearings. The Committee wishes to thank all those people who have assisted it in this way.

In the report, the Committee has reached a series of conclusions and made a number of recommendations. Those conclusions and recommendations are clearly set out in the front of the report. However, in the time available to me, I would like to highlight some of those conclusions and recommendations. The Committee concluded that, in order to perform their functions, tribunals need to be able to attract and have appointed to them people of superior talents and integrity. They also need to be able to ensure that appointees will not be influenced in their decision making by outside or irrelevant considerations. In particular, they should not be influenced by the government of the day or any alternative government. In order to give effect to these aims, the nature of the tenure provided to appointees must ensure the following: an adequate term of office; removal before expiration of term only for cause specified in the relevant legislation; adequate removal procedures; proper processes to establish grounds for removal; protection from pressure from Ministers, members of parliament and senior officials; a reasonable opportunity to perform their work, so long as they are able to do so; and appropriate salaries and conditions of service. For their part, members of tribunals should remain independent from party-political activity and should observe the same standards of decorum and behaviour that judges have traditionally followed.

The Committee has concluded that the Parliament should not support a constitutional amendment to limit its power to abolish tribunals. However, the Committee has recommended that the following principles be borne in mind when the Parliament is considering the abolition of a tribunal, and I emphasise that we are talking about quasi-judicial tribunals: the abolition of a tribunal should not be used as a method of removing the holder of a quasi-judicial office; legislation to change the structure and jurisdiction of a tribunal should, if possible, refrain from abolishing the tribunal; when a tribunal is abolished and restructured, all existing members should be reappointed to its replacement; and, when a tribunal is abolished and not replaced, compensation should be paid to members of the tribunal who have lost their places and for whom no alternative positions can be found. The Committee has recommended that further consideration be given to embodying these principles in an Act of Parliament.

The Committee was required to consider whether sections 24 and 28 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 provided proper and adequate tenure for presidential members and commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The Committee concluded that, subject to the recommendations that I have just outlined in relation to the abolition of tribunals, the provisions did provide proper and adequate tenure to those appointees.

The Committee considered the difficult question of whether there was a right to perform work attached to the appointment to a particular office. The Committee recognised that the head of a tribunal should have the power to allocate work to tribunal members, but has indicated its belief that this power should not be exercised in such a way as to effect the de facto suspension of a tribunal member. The Committee concluded that when a tribunal member is deprived of work, he or she is entitled to receive reasons for this occurring from the president of the tribunal.

If the member does not accept the reasons the member should, in the first place, attempt to resolve the dispute with the tribunal president. If this does not work, the member should pursue whatever other legal avenues are available. The Committee concluded that there was no need for the establishment of a new body to deal with complaints against tribunal members, nor was it necessary for such a body to mediate between tribunal members and presiding officers.

In chapter 8 of the report the Committee deals with various issues raised by the case of former Justice Staples. I should mention that the Committee refers to the individual concerned as `former Justice Staples' on the basis that he was formerly a Justice of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Committee does not wish to prejudge the current status of the individual, which the Committee understands to be a matter of some contention.

The Committee was unable to reach any conclusions on the relationship which developed between former Justice Staples, on the one hand, and Sir John Moore and Justice Maddern respectively, on the other-Sir John Moore being a former President and Justice Maddern the current President of the Industrial Relations Commission. While the Committee received a detailed submission from, and heard former Justice Staples at length in its public hearing, the Committee received no assistance from Sir John Moore or Justice Maddern on the difficult question of the relationship which developed between them and former Justice Staples. The Committee regretted this.

The Committee concluded that it should not inquire further into the reasons why former Justice Staples was removed from active work, as to do so would have required a full-scale inquiry into the Staples case. This was clearly beyond the Committee's terms of reference. However, in the light of the Committee's recommendations contained in chapter 5 of the report, which addressed the question of what should happen when a tribunal is abolished, the Committee recommended that the Government should establish an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation to former Justice Staples, in view of his non-reappointment to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

I need to raise one further matter in relation to this report. On 21 November 1989 the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives forwarded to the Committee a letter which each had received from former Justice Staples. The letter referred to three statements contained in an early draft of the Committee's report. Former Justice Staples complained to the Presiding Officers about the statements, alleging that they were untrue and seeking some redress in relation to them. Unfortunately, the key parts of these letters appeared in several newspapers on 21 November. These letters were available to the Committee at a scheduled meeting on the afternoon of 21 November. At that stage of its consideration of the draft report the Committee had not reached the sections of the report to which Staples had referred, but objection had already been raised to the accuracy of some of these statements, which were based on a written submission which had been received by the Committee.

In considering these sections in the ordinary course of its consideration of the report, the Committee decided to delete them for reasons which had already been raised. Accordingly, the Committee was not influenced in its deliberations by the letter from former Justice Staples.

The Committee was concerned that the contents of some parts of a report had, without the authorisation of the Committee, become available to former Justice Staples, and that he had made use of the material by directing it to the Presiding Officers. The Committee was also concerned that some of the material contained in former Justice Staples's letters was obtained and published by newspapers. The Committee gave consideration to whether it should report these matters as a possible breach of privilege but has decided that, in the light of all the circumstances, it should not take the matter any further.

The Committee would like to thank the staff of the Committee for their assistance, particularly Stephen Argument, who was brought to the task of Acting Secretary of the Committee at a late stage and did an excellent job in difficult circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals, I attached my name to the dissent of Dr Klugman, rather than prepare a separate dissent.
—Why?

—I shall tell Senator Crichton-Browne why in a moment. I was in substantial agreement with the majority report, particularly with those chapters dealing with the general question of the tenure of appointees to Commonwealth tribunals. Indeed, I, and I presume Dr Klugman, support many of the findings of the chapter dealing specifically with Mr Justice Staples. Four of these paragraphs are of particular interest, and I would like to read them into the record. Paragraph 8.29 states:

SPEECH.PARA: On the evidence before the Committee, former Justice Staples was at all times prepared to carry out the duties of his office but was prevented from doing so by decisions of the President of the day.
Paragraph 8.32 states:
No evidence has been given to the Committee that former Justice Staples was guilty of any misbehaviour or suffered any incapacity which would have justified his dismissal.
Paragraph 8.34 reads as follows:

In the light of the foregoing, the Committee is unable to reach any conclusion on the relationship which developed between former Justice Staples, on the one hand, and Sir John Moore and Justice Maddern, respectively, on the other. In failing to reach a conclusion on this question, the Committee regrets that it received no assistance on this matter from Sir John Moore or Justice Maddern.
Finally, paragraph 8.36 states:

In view of the foregoing and following the Committee's recommendations in paragraph 5.27, the Committee recommends that the Government should establish an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation for former Justice Staples in view of his non re-appointment to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

In view of the finding of the Committee in an earlier chapter it was clearly a logical extension that there should be an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation for Mr Justice Staples. I think Senator Durack has already mentioned that section but, for the record, the Committee found as follows:
When a tribunal is abolished and not replaced, compensation should be paid to the members of the tribunal who have lost their positions and for whom no alternative position can be found.
I join the Chairman in his dissent because I felt that certain points were not sufficiently emphasised in the majority report. I would like to read the very short dissent into the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the report. You don't have to read it. It is in the record already.
—It is in the record because it has been tabled, but I would still like to read it out.
—For crying out loud.
—Other people want to speak too.
—It is only five paragraphs. The less interference I have, the quicker I can get it done. Dr Klugman and I have said the following in our dissent:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned wish to dissent, as follows: There is no evidence that the then Mr Justice Staples made `no serious attempt . . . to resolve the problem'

After the appointment of Mr Justice Maddern it seems that there was no attempt to discuss the matter apart from the letter written in August 1986 by former Justice Staples to Justice Maddern. Reverting to our dissent, we stated:
He has in fact given evidence to the contrary and this has not been denied. In fact we-
that is, Dr Klugman and I-

consider it very surprising that in reply to a request, Mr Justice Maddern emphasised the point, with the help of statutory declarations by his staff, that he made no attempt to contact Staples to discuss any problems.
We emphasise that a member of a tribunal who is deprived of work is entitled to receive reasons from the President of the tribunal for such a decision.

We cannot accept the proposition that a tribunal member who can only be removed by the method and for the reasons outlined in section 72 of the Constitution can de facto be suspended arbitrarily by the senior tribunal member.

Mr Justice Maddern dismissed Mr Justice Staples de facto without giving reasons. Neither the Government nor the Parliament would be able to do so. Such behaviour allows a President to act capriciously or to protect what has been alleged to be `The Industrial Relations Club'.

I felt that the majority report-I do not speak for Dr Klugman here-implies that Mr Justice Staples somehow collaborated in his own downfall. The dissent that I signed with Dr Klugman seeks to establish that he was primarily a victim. The original motion regarding Mr Justice Staples was put before the Senate in February 1989 by Senator Janine Haines. I supported the substance of her motion. However, an amended motion put forward by Senator Robert Hill for the Liberal Party of Australia omitted, and indeed evaded, any mention of the subject of Senator Haines's motion. It was accepted by the two major parties in the Senate and was therefore passed. This clear bipartisanship of interest between the two major political parties led to a deflection from the real subject, namely, Mr Justice Staples's effective dismissal from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and put the focus on the more general issue of appointees to Commonwealth tribunals, which is undoubtedly a subject deserving of inquiry by a joint select committee but nonetheless not what was really at issue in this case.

The Committee found that it could not avoid the real and immediate issue that was put before the Senate in Senator Haines's original motion. I hope that the Government will move quickly to effect the recommendation of the Committee for an inquiry into the matter of compensation for Mr Justice Staples. Unfortunately, the work at the end of the Committee was complicated by the extended absence of the Chairman of the Committee. I merely wish to support Senator Durack's comments about the cooperation of the staff and thank them for their efforts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the general thrust of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals, in particular the very important work that was done to establish the ground rules for the future in the way that tribunals should be run in terms of their independence from government. I believe that the ground rules are of value to all members of tribunals and to chairmen of tribunals and will be a guide to the conduct and the way they treat each other and relate to each other in the future, as well as the way in which they relate to government and to the interest groups in the community at large with whom they deal. That is of immense value, I believe, because for the first time at least it sets down ground rules that everyone will understand and upon which their actions and thoughts can be based in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I have dissented from the report in some very important areas. The first is in relation to what I call performance reviews of independent tribunals. It seems to me that without political interference it is very much the responsibility of the chairmen of tribunals to make sure that each person working on a tribunal performs-in other words, that they are not lazy or incapable. I am not referring to misdemeanours or misbehaviour; I am referring to people who, for example, do not perform according to the way that the community or the chairmen of tribunals believe that they should.

I have talked about the need for some form of review to be introduced into the process, that review to be subject to appeal by the peer groups within that particular area. I stress the point that at no stage should a government become involved in that process. That is simply accepting the reality that with the vast number of independent tribunals that are operating in this country, it is inevitable that some of those tribunal members will not be performing, and therefore should be subject to some sort of performance review conducted by their peer groups or the chairmen of the tribunals.

More importantly, I wish to raise the matter of why I am dissenting from the major thrust of the report, which I believe was tacked on at the end of it. That is the recommendation that there should be a further inquiry into the question of compensation for former Justice Staples. My views are based on four major reasons. The first is that the Senate specifically did not require the Committee to investigate the question of Mr Justice Staples and compensation for him. The Australian Democrats moved a motion in the Senate in which they tried to set the terms of reference, in which the case of former Justice Staples was to be examined in detail. That was specifically rejected by the Senate by 57 votes to eight votes. Another motion was accepted which then set the terms of reference. Those terms of reference were formulated to look at the general question of how tribunals should operate, how we can protect their independence and a number of other issues. It was not to be a Staples inquiry.

The Committee examined the case of former Justice Staples, and we devoted a chapter in the report to it. My dissent is based upon the fact that this Committee recommends that we should have yet another inquiry. I believe that the Staples saga should be closed now. If former Justice Staples wishes to follow it through, I have indicated that he has redress through the civil courts. I believe that at some stage throughout this long saga he should have taken that opportunity; but he has not done so.

I do not believe that the Senate, the House of Representatives or any committee which is established by this Parliament has the role or the function of setting itself up as judge and jury to decide on the relationships that have existed over the last six years or more between former Justice Staples and Presidents Maddern and Moore of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As a parliament we are not in the position to act as a branch of the judiciary. We do not have proper rules for evidentiary operations and the protection of the rights of individuals who come before any committees of the Senate. I do not believe that we should be paying out public money in the way we did with one Privileges Committee operation, when $160,000 was spent on legal fees alone, to act, in a sense, as a judge and jury. There is a right and proper place for people to seek redress for personal injustice; that place is in the courts of law of this country, which are established with all the rules of evidence to protect the rights of all individuals involved.

When the Senate or any committee of the joint Houses decides to be judge and jury on an issue, we are really coming to the end of the line or the end of the doctrine of the separation of powers. We are then saying that the Senate ought to take over the role of the judiciary. There is a function for this House of Parliament in relation to, say, the judiciary and that is on the question of misbehaviour of judges. It is only right and proper that, at the end of the day, when a judge or a member of a judicial commission of some sort has misbehaved, his or her case should be judged here. But that is at the end of the day and is specifically provided for under the Constitution. However, on no other occasion do I believe that the Senate should act as a judge and jury in such cases.

I have also indicated within my dissenting report that Mr Justice Staples has been adequately compensated. According to my calculations, under the judges compensation legislation he is presently entitled to an annual salary of $58,708. That is 60 per cent of the amount he would have earned if he had remained a judge. It is equal to the appropriate pension that other judges receive. This amount will rise to $74,566 by the end of this year, subject to the Parliament's acceptance of the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendations. In addition, Mr Justice Staples is entitled to significant long service leave payments.

As we in this Parliament all know, we even brought in a deeming clause to deem former Justice Staples to be 60 years of age so that he could qualify for a judge's pension. He has been compensated in terms of finance. When I look at some of the other areas in this community where individuals have suffered at the hands of authority, the case of former Justice Staples seems to me to be very paltry indeed. Lindy Chamberlain spent 3 3/4 years behind bars. Her reputation and that of her family were absolutely ruined. There were leaks from the police and attempts by the Northern Territory Government to ignore the problem and, in some cases, simply to put her in her place-as they saw it, behind bars again. Lindy Chamberlain has not had an easy time. Similarly, former police sergeant Phil Arantz was dismissed by the Askin Government for releasing figures about the rising rate of crime in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Wran broke his promise.

—A number of people broke their promises in relation to Phillip Arantz. Eighteen years later he is still seeking compensation for that. What about the Queensland policemen who were sacked and harassed and whose careers were ruined by the fact that they opposed the corrupt hierarchy of the police and politicians in Queensland? Where are they? Where is the compensation there? What has happened to them? Where is the noise in this Senate about their particular case? They happen to be low level individuals in terms of their positions in society. I have not heard a word about them in this place.
—Have you raised it?

—Yes, I have, in appropriate forums. I have not heard Senator Dunn raise her voice about it here, yet she talks about Justice Staples. It seems to me that when we talk about justice we have to go for those areas where justice ought to be given, where this Senate can assist. To set ourselves up as judge and jury in an issue where we could not and did not call all the witnesses I believe is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Dunn said, `The trouble with the Senate and the House of Representatives is that somehow or other they outvoted us and got the wrong idea about the terms of reference, but we'-meaning herself and Dr Klugman-`then set about fixing that up during our inquiry'. In other words, Senator Dunn said, `No matter what terms of reference this Parliament gave us, somehow or other we will set the record straight and we will call Maddern, Moore and Staples in'. Former Justice Staples had a very significant amount of time before our Committee. I think he appeared before us for about 2 3/4 hours. That is the longest time I have ever heard of for someone to sit there and tell us what he thinks. He was then allowed to appear again. I think that he was generously treated. I was one who objected to the idea that Justice Staples should criticise our draft report-presumably a copy of which was in his hands-before we had made our final decision. I do not like being pressured like that as a parliamentarian.

Those are the principles on which I am dissenting. I am sorry to have to dissent because I believe that, for the most part, the Committee was very cooperative indeed; worked well together. I believe the report covers the ground rules for the future, which will be extremely valuable for the conduct of governments and members of tribunals. I hope that it may be a guide to those people who in the future may get themselves into the same sorts of difficulties as former Justice Staples and Presidents Maddern and Moore did.

I think that there is great value in what this Parliament did. In no way do I resile from the fact that the terms of reference given to the Committee were, in fact, appropriate; they were appropriate because we needed them. To try to push the case of Justice Staples to make it the Staples inquiry, I think, is inappropriate and a waste of the Senate's time, and I believe that we should be addressing ourselves to the issues that were raised in general about the question of the independence of tribunals, the way they operate and the question of freedom they have in relation to governments.

I thank those people who worked with the Committee, particularly our two secretaries, who had to work against all sorts of tight time schedules to have this report ready before the end of the year. I thank the other members of the Committee for their cooperation. As I indicated, my reluctant dissent is here in order that we get the real issues back on the table again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to deal with this matter I should state that both Dick Klugman and I have been personal friends of Jim Staples for 40 years. What I say, I imagine, should be seen in that context. I think that it is honest for me to say that I find Senator Aulich's contribution to this debate unfortunate. I think it does him no credit beyond the fact that he is clearly prepared to be loyal to the position that his Party has taken, whether that position is right or wrong. In fact, the position is morally indefensible.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that this dispute between justices of the Industrial Relations Commission and Mr Justice Staples began under the Liberal Government, which did not take action, and properly did not take action, on this matter. Mr Justice Staples continued to be employed on various matters-not adequately, and not to his liking-while the Fraser Liberal Government was in power, but no action of an administrative nature by the Government was taken against him.

The Labor Government that Senator Aulich is defending used a device in order to exclude him from an office to which he was entitled. One can come to all sorts of views about the morality of that. I will simply say a few things on this score, particularly relating to Senator Aulich's objections. It is nonsense for Senator Aulich to say that Justice Staples has been `adequately compensated'. That man was entitled to a position in society which carries with it not only a professional accolade, but also a substantial salary. He has been deprived of both of those by an administrative device by this Government. It is nonsense for Senator Aulich to say that the Senate should not be judge and jury in this matter, and that the Joint Select Committee on the Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals has gone against the wishes of the Senate in devoting one chapter out of eight to the Staples matter.

In the first place, it is recognisable that, while the Senate rejected a specific motion limiting the matter to Mr Justice Staples, the replacement motion was an umbrella motion which covered the whole issue in general. In my view, there is no conflict in the specific matter of Justice Staples being dealt with under that general heading. For Senator Aulich to pretend that the Senate, by rejecting the limiting motion, therefore denied any right to the Committee to deal with the Staples matter is utter bunkum.

It is extraordinary for Senator Aulich to say that it would be wrong to set up an inquiry because the Senate should not be judge and jury. Let us see what paragraph 8.36 of the report signed by Senator Durack, as Deputy Chairman, actually says. It starts off, `In view of the foregoing'. What is `the foregoing'? That sentence dramatises that there is a reason, which did not exist at the time of the 28 February resolution, why the specific matter of Justice Staples should be investigated. That is not to say that the Senate should do it; it is just that the Committee recommends:
The Government should establish an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation for former Justice Staples, in view of his non re-appointment to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

There is no suggestion that the Senate should be judge and jury in this matter. But it is the phrase `in view of the foregoing' that I think is absolutely vital, and that is what I want to concentrate on-as I have said, `the foregoing' being information that was not available to the Senate early on when it made its decision. I will deal now with that. I find it most unfortunate that, in a matter of such significance, Sir John Moore and Mr Justice Maddern did not avail themselves of the opportunity given to them to provide fulsome assistance to this Committee.

There is no doubt that Jim Staples made uncomfortable decisions. They were decisions that, according to some people, often appeared unrelated to the evidence, and they have been attacked as being capricious. People did not know what the ground rules were when appearing before Justice Staples. The facts are that he has an imaginative approach; he is uncomfortable; and he challenges the basic beliefs, if you like, of the industrial relations club. But when we heard Senator Aulich talking about reasons why people should be got rid of, why there should be the capacity to remove people if they are lazy or incapable--

TALK.START.PARA: —After five years?

—Indeed, after five years, as Senator Durack says. No-one has ever accused Mr Justice Staples of being lazy or incapable. Senator Aulich let the cat out of the bag in his approach because he wants whoever is in those positions to be acceptable to his peer group and to be subject to removal, apparently, if he offends his peer group. Naturally, someone like Mr Justice Staples, who has no time for the hypocrisy of the industrial relations club, would offend a peer group of that order. Many members of the coalition have very little time for the practices of the industrial relations club, which I believe have been one of the major reasons for the Australian economy suffering so badly in recent years. On those scores I find Senator Aulich's intervention extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to the unfortunate situation where, in this general inquiry on this matter, Sir John Moore chose not to give any assistance to the Committee as to the basis of the exercise of his power to allocate the work of the Commission to include the removal of work-in other words, the question relating specifically to Mr Justice Staples but which could well establish a general precedent-Justice Maddern provided the Committee with a broad statement of the general areas of consideration that he regarded as relevant to his decision without advising the Committee in what areas he saw this as relevant to the removal of former Justice Staples from active work. The Committee concludes:

In view of the fact that it has not conducted an inquiry into the Staples case, the Committee believes that it would be unjustified for it to form an opinion on several of the matters asserted by former Justice Staples.
No evidence has been given to the Committee that former Justice Staples was guilty of any misbehaviour or suffered any incapacity that would have justified his dismissal.

This seems to me to be the crux of the matter. I believe that the Labor Government behaved dishonourably in dismissing him by a device; I believe that it is continuing to act dishonourably in not taking some appropriate action to recompense Justice Staples; and I strongly support the recommendation by the majority of the Committee that an inquiry be established.

In response to Senator Dunn, I agree with various elements of Dr Klugman's and her dissenting report. The fact that former Justice Staples gave evidence that he had made serious attempts to resolve the problem and that this had not been denied I think is fairly persuasive. The fact that Justices Maddern and Moore chose not to deal with the Committee does not give the Committee the right to say that therefore Justice Staples took no effective steps when he may well have, and Moore and Maddern could properly have sought to disprove that had they had a mind to do it. They did not have a mind to do it, and in those circumstances the burden of proof surely should be on someone else to disprove what Staples was saying. So I have that one reservation about the Committee's conclusion.

As I have said, I think it was improper for Justice Staples to be effectively dismissed without any reasons being given. I commend this report for raising this issue so sensibly and rationally and I strongly support its recommendation that the Government establish an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that I cannot let this debate go without making some comment, since it was my original motion that led to the current inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals. Admittedly, the terms of reference that finished up before this Committee bore very little relationship to the ones that we originally moved, and I think that is why this issue will not go away. There is no question in most people's minds but that the former Mr Justice Staples has been appallingly treated and that a device, which everyone recognises as a device, was used to deny him tenure. It was used to deny him tenure because he had become, I suppose, not to put too fine a point on it, a damned nuisance to this Government and to the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some facts that we raised in the original debate that I think are worth repeating. Like other judges, Jim Staples was appointed to the position that he had previously because at the time he was considered capable. One can only assume that that was the reason for his appointment. I would hate to think that we will ever get to a stage of putting people into these sorts of positions for political reasons or any reason other than simple merit and their capabilities to fulfil the function of their jobs. So let us assume that Jim Staples was originally appointed because he exhibited considerable capabilities in the area.

However, he was not the sort of person to sit back quietly and do precisely what he was told, to follow the system and not make waves. He was, I suppose, a pest in the eyes of some people because he challenged the system. He sent people off to negotiate in a more sensible way and he made a few public statements that perhaps a few people did not like. Because he occasionally bucked the nice, cosy little arrangement that was often entered into between employers and employees before they went to the then Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, he offended some people-including some of his colleagues-considerably.

Unfortunately, with section 72 (ii) of the Constitution worded in the way it is, it was practically impossible to remove him other than by the necessary address by both Houses of Parliament. So whether it was incidental, accidental, or deliberate, this device of getting rid of the old Commission, establishing a new Industrial Relations Commission and failing to appoint all the judges who were on the old Commission-in the only case of Mr Justice Staples-was implemented. From that time on Jim Staples has been seeking justice, and explanation and redress. The fact is that following this inquiry no justice has been done to Mr Staples. As I said, not only was my original motion amended to remove any need to address the Staples case, but he has achieved no compensation, no recompense, no apology, no explanation, no nothing.

I took some exception to the rather odd argument put forward by Senator Aulich that, just because some people have been badly treated in other areas of law in compensation, and so on, it is okay to mistreat Mr Justice Staples and to give him less than the justice that he deserves. That is an appalling statement. What we are really saying is, `Gosh, we accidentally, unfairly or incorrectly hanged a man, but let us use this as an example for unfairly and inappropriately hanging a few others. We have now set a precedent, so we might as well build up a whole body of these occurrences'. It is a bizarre argument to put that, simply because some other people have been badly treated and have had to fight for redress, compensation and justice, it is okay if we toss a few more people onto that particular heap and hope that they wear out, die, or go quietly away and leave us all alone.

There is a relationship between the Parliament and the judiciary, of which Mr Justice Staples was a member, regardless of the odd comments about the naming of people on the Commission. There is no justification for saying, `Well, it was only a nice title that we gave them to make them feel good. They were not really judges; they were not really justices; we just let them call themselves that'. If we were not going to treat them in that way, why allow them to use the title and expect to have the same benefits, the same protection and the same treatment as `really truly judges' under the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Real judges.

—Senator Alston, like Senator Aulich, also believes, I think, that if one person is ill-treated it sets a precedent for ill-treating someone else. I am not sure I think that is fair of him either. There is a relationship between Parliament and the judiciary, but it is not one in which the Parliament can intervene willy-nilly, how and when it feels like it. Having seen some obstruction in the Constitution I do not think it behoves this place to resort to the sort of trickery that saw Jim Staples denied tenure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Aulich's argument, that it was jolly nice of us to deem that he was actually older than he really was in order to give him compensation, is a little strange, too. It is as though contravening a law or a normal occurrence in order to avoid actually giving somebody proper justice is okay, and as though that is the answer to what we have done. It is not appropriate to say, `Aren't we good guys because we have given him a pension earlier than he was entitled to, by letting him behave as though he were 60 years old or by redefining him as being 60'. What sort of a ludicrous situation are we reaching when the Parliament, by ignoring its responsibilities under the Constitution, has to go through a whole lot of curly devices in order, firstly, to get rid of somebody who had tenure and, secondly, to pretend to be seen to be doing the decent thing by him.

Our original motion dealt with the major issue-and it is still the major issue; it has not gone away-the question of tenure of people on commissions of this kind and how governments can get rid of these annoying people without being challenged or being brought to answer questions by the incumbent that they have just got rid of.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Parliament.

—My colleague points out that the Parliament is a very important part of all this. The Parliament, of course, has nothing to be proud of. Having colluded in the original changing of the motion to try to get the Justice Staples issue out of all this, it has found that it has come full circle. It is impossible to deal with this issue without dealing with the question of Mr Justice Staples. He and his case were integral to the whole question that was before the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It now appears that the Committee has recognised this fact by recommending that an inquiry into the need for compensation for Mr Justice Staples go ahead. In many ways I see that as an admission of error on the part of those members of the Committee that originally supported the changes to the first motion proposed to this place so long ago. I hope that that recommendation from the Committee is accepted. If it is not picked up by the Government, if an inquiry into compensation for Mr Justice Staples does not go ahead, I venture to say that it will remain a stain on the good name of this place and, in particular, on the current Labor Government. It has shabbily treated a man who deserved justice. It cannot argue, as it so frequently does from its ideological point of view, against the unfair dismissal of ordinary workers and then be party to the engineering of such an unfair dismissal of a man who had been put on a commission because he was considered capable. He ruffled a few feathers and was summarily got rid of, but he refused to go away. If nothing else comes out of this sorry and ongoing mess, at the very least I hope we can look forward to a motion from this Government that a committee will be established, or some other form of inquiry will be set up, in order to look at compensation for a man who has been denied justice, denied tenure, and denied any opportunity to see fair play operate in an area of the judiciary which is intimately involved with seeing that fair play operates out in the work force. The Government cannot have it both ways. It cannot argue plaintively for fairness for the work force and then not extend it to the people whose job it is to ensure that that fairness is put into effect.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 November.
GROUP F
Department of Primary Industries and Energy
Proposed expenditure, $408,377,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that I have had discussions with the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy with a view to expediting the procedure over the plans which he laid down last night. I want to ensure that I get some answers to questions I have put about a few areas in this portfolio. It is probably appropriate that I should beat the air for a moment or two rather than call a quorum. The issues that I still require specific information on are as follows: What are the main objectives of quarantine? I have always understood that maintaining health and preventing disease are the main objectives. How are the levels of acceptable risk fixed? Is it done by meetings of the Government, of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service or of the Ministerial Council of Health Ministers-the State health Ministers and the Federals? Is it fixed by consultation with the industries involved? Who determines what is a fair and reasonable risk in someone else's business?

SPEECH.PARA: By the same token, who determines when it is time to back off when it comes to the fear of accusations of non-tariff protection? How far do we go before we run the risk of having somebody accuse us of non-tariff protection? Is that done in consultation with the industries concerned or is it done by the Government or AQIS? I also want to know whether we have a transmisible gastroenteritis disaster plan. I have asked this question previously and could not get an answer. Is the risk factor one in 3.3 million? Is it one in 15,000, which is still an acceptable risk I am told? What is the acceptable risk at which we cut it off? Is it one in 5,000? Is it one in 500? It would be desirable if I were able to advise the people involved, whose industry we are talking about, as to what is the acceptable risk, who determines it and whether we have made any progress in endeavouring to determine whether the one in 3.3 million is closer or not as close as the one in 15,000.

I would like to know that, as I would like to know whether it is appropriate to use mecadox and, if it is appropriate to use mecadox, in other people's industry, why it is not appropriate to use it in our industry, or vice versa. It should be all in or all out, in my opinion. The same thing applies with the nitrates question, which I have regularly raised. Clearly, an exporter certificate should be supplied with the product to say `This has been manufactured without the use of nitrates'. As far as listeria is concerned, every exported cheese that is likely to be subject to listeria should have a certificate to say that it has been inspected before it leaves the country and that it is free of the disease or of potential for the disease.

Finally, there is the fire blight question. What steps are to be taken as far as fire blight is concerned? Will it be a destruction of orchards? Will it be a destruction of host trees, or will it not? The enormous damage there could be from an outbreak, once it was established, would be impossible to eradicate. What are we doing about it? Who makes the decisions? What are the disaster plans? All these matters are of great importance. I note that the Minister has now entered the chamber. I have been waiting for his arrival. I have been giving notice of the issues that I trust he will be able to respond to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was concluding by saying that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) as a regulatory authority has the difficulty of attracting public attention if there is a mistake but of being invisible when things are going well. I guess that is what one would expect from an organisation whose job it is to make sure that no disease gets into Australia which afflicts our horticultural or agricultural industries.
—Or health.

—Indeed; that is true. However, it is not a very rewarding occupation for AQIS people because they do not get any recognition for success. Their invisibility ensures that is the case. The Government commissioned a report to review quarantine policy in Australia. The report commenced under the chairmanship of Professor Lindsay, from the University of Western Australia, in 1987 and took 12 months. After considering the Lindsay report, the Government responded on 15 December 1988. If there are two organisations which could be characterised as protagonist organisations or, if you like, organisations which argue the toss with AQIS over judgments, those two organisations would be the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Veterinary Association. Both those organisations endorsed the findings of the Lindsay report and the response to it by government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Lindsay report did not, as is common abroad, change the fundamentals of quarantine policy. There was no change to a philosophy that has been characterised as `acceptable risk'. What the Lindsay report proposed, and what the Government has adopted, is to make more explicit what were the previously implied methods of assessing risk and to make more transparent, that is, to make more open and discoverable, the activities of AQIS so that in the context of our international standing in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-our position in the world for free trade-it can be clearly seen that, on the one hand, AQIS is not a non-trade barrier, for which some countries would use their quarantine services, and, on the other hand, the guarantee of protection to the rural community and to the public at large is consistent with its record and objectives. I think there has been some misunderstanding on that point. There has been some misunderstanding that a sea change occurred in policy. What changed was the emphasis and explanation of the policy and the methodology employed to deal with acceptable risk.

I said at the beginning of my remarks that AQIS has the unfortunate problem of being noticeable only when there is a mistake and invisible when everything is going well. AQIS has attracted some attention in the media at present because, to use one example, of the importation into Australia of a partly contaminated container of nashi fruit. This has been hailed as a lack of efficiency or activity on the part of AQIS. It has been used as a criticism of AQIS. That is unfair. If one reflects on it, it can be seen to be unfair. It is a bit like criticising the police force every time there is a drug bust, saying `Hello, there are drugs available in the community!'. We have a quarantine service to protect us from those things. When it discovers an outbreak such as this, reports it and deals with it, to criticise it is totally unfair. If I can go back to the police analogy, we all know that crime exists, as we know disease exists, but to apply the same measure that is now being applied to AQIS to the police would bring the whole of the police force into disrepute for no gain in the community and for no real purpose and would be illogical, anyway. So I make that defence of AQIS.

I turn to some of the points raised by Senator Archer. One of the points Senator Archer raised strongly last night when we were winding up our day's business was that not enough is known about AQIS and that information is hard to extract from that body. I am not endorsing it, but I think that was the direction of the honourable senator's remarks. I believe that AQIS has now answered all the questions put to it at the Estimates Committee and that AQIS is accessible to all the commodity organisations within the NFF and producer groups. Indeed, it is frequently invited to address their meetings. A recent example of that occurred about two or three weeks ago in Northam, Western Australia, when pig producers were concerned about the possible importation of transmissible gastroenteritis into Australia by virtue of uncooked Canadian pig meat being able to enter Australia. AQIS officers were invited, attended and explained the situation in relation to their assessment of that type of disease.

However, it is a problem that attention is focused on a topic only when people become agitated. The Western Australian pig producers were kind enough to say that, when AQIS was going through the consultations in relation to transmissible gastroenteritis, they did not pay a great deal of attention and they said that in a flash of honesty, for which I do not condemn them. In fact I want to encourage this kind of interchange. It was only when the possibility arose in relation to signing a protocol to enable the pig meat to come into Australia and compete with their domestic product that they paid particular attention to the matter. They recognised that they had to undertake a degree of catching up on the information base that was available to the community in order that the inner issues could be debated.

On the basis of the way in which ordinary business is done in Australia, I think it is reasonable for me to observe that, in the throes of criticism, it does not mean to say that the information was not available; rather, at the time, because it was routine, boring and dull, people did not pay attention to it. I cite the example of the Western Australian pig producers in relation to that observation and they were honest enough to say that that was the case. However, AQIS will shortly announce the opening of a hot line for producers, which they can dial on an inward wide area telephone service number anywhere in Australia to inquire from AQIS as to what particular issues are current and to obtain information about possible disease, risk assessment and things of that nature. As an organisation, it can then be more accessible and producers can have direct access to case officers who are dealing with particular problems.

AQIS maintains a regular policy of consulting with the national organisations representing producers. As I will shortly demonstrate when I go to the substantive detail, it does that on every major issue, but a difficulty may sometimes arise in relation to what is conveyed-and it is sometimes complex information-at peak level. There may be some difficulty with that information washing through from national structures to State and regional organisations so that people on the ground who are affected by the problem are seized of all the information. That is a logistical organisational difficulty. All honourable senators are familiar with how national organisations work and we can understand that difficulty. In order to try to overcome the problem, AQIS will now pursue a policy, for want of a better description-and these are my words, not those of AQIS-of having a sort of open day when they will invite people in various centres to come and talk to them. Its transparency goal-that is, that people can understand how and why it acts and the principles it employs-will be met by that mechanism.

Senator Archer endorsed-and I am pleased that he did-the fact that neither this Government nor any other government in Australia should use the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service as a non-tariff barrier. I believe that there is probably no better example of the allegation that it is a non-tariff barrier than in the case of Canadian pig meat. Australia is the only country in the world that maintains a quarantine ban on the importation of that pig meat. In terms of this current General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round, the Canadians have lobbied hard to establish the reason why we maintain that ban when no other country takes the judgment that we have made on quarantine grounds. In addition, when we move to talk to the Americans about their export enhancement finance to wheat exporters so that they can compete on world wheat markets against our producers, who receive no subsidies and must compete against subsidised American wheat, and when we go to Washington and complain about that type of arrangement, they will say to us, `But you use non-tariff barriers: look at the Canadian pig meat example'.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is rubbish.

—I am reporting here; I am not editorialising. I am saying that this is what happens and occurs. The same thing will happen to whoever goes overseas to raise these matters. Should the Opposition wish to send a mission to Washington, it will receive this type of reply when it gets down to taws and debates these matters. I report that. However, I do not say that that is necessarily a reason-and I do not proffer it as such-why we should change our policy in relation to the importation into Australia of uncooked Canadian pig meat if we believe that, for quarantine reasons, it should not come here. Our standards may well differ from those of other countries and we have a right to establish our own standards and we shall defend them. However, that raises the veracity of those standards.

SPEECH.PARA: We have undertaken a series of consultations, investigations, experiments and, as a result, further consultations, since 1985. This is not a new issue; it has been around for a long time. The central construct of the major part of our decision in this matter was based on experiments conducted by the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. In relation to those laboratories, honourable senators must bear in mind that we import muscle tissue and cuts of meat-we are not importing the hearts, the lungs or the tonsils which, it can be argued, are product that could contain transmissible gastroenteritis. There is scientific evidence to suggest that that is the case. But there is no scientific evidence to suggest that muscle tissue would contain the disease. However, as soon as this meat is cooked, it then kills the possibility of transmissible gastroenteritis, so we are dealing with that very fine area of probability. Neither the Government nor AQIS wanted to make this judgment, but the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA) conducted its own assessment of the possible introduction of transmissible gastroenteritis and came up with the risk figure of one in 3.3 million in relation to each item. I would not like to have those odds quoted to me in any contest, but that was its independent assessment, which was uninvited by us.

The AVA's pig veterinarians also conducted their own assessment and came up with a figure of one in 15,500. Those figures are not the foundation upon which we make our decision, but they constitute part of the information base for decision-making. We base our primary decision-making on the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory experiments and what we know as a result of what has happened in parts of the United States of America and other places in the world. We can cull scientific information bases from looking at journals from those places and talking to those people who perform the experiments. We can also examine the case examples. We then come to a conclusion that, in this case, there is no reason why we should not sign the protocol. That is the basis for that decision.

I think that there is then some anxiety as to whether or not that is true. At the present time, we are engaging in further discussions with the Pig Producers Association of Australia, which recognises that the anxiety is driven by concern about the impact on the Christmas trade of Canadian hams competing in the market here. I think that is still the engine of anxiety. The way in which that anxiety is expressed is through quarantine. I believe that we are in one of those classic cases where the real problem is not the issue that is being put forward as the solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. There being no other senator rising, I call Senator Cook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I am taking so long, but I want to be complete and Senator Archer has taken the trouble to ask a series of questions.
—You had a go at me the other day for doing just that-getting up again.

—Well, sometimes I am wrong; maybe I was right then. However, I think I had come to the end of my explanation on transmissible gastroenteritis. The next item on the list is nashi fruit. A disease was detected in nashi fruit which was being imported on an experimental basis. As a result, it was not released onto the market. I would argue that that is proof of the detection ability of AQIS and I do not think much more than that need be said.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the matter of fire blight which was discussed at a public meeting in and around the Orange-Bathurst area last night. What are the facts in the case of this disease? Of course, it would be disastrous if there were an outbreak of fire blight in Australia as far as our fruit crops are concerned. AQIS has produced a discussion paper on the possible importation of apples from New Zealand into Australia from an area identified not simply by our scientists who have responsibility for this type of commodity but by others as being free from this disease. It has been declared an area freedom region without fire blight. Just as we have been able to obtain recognition, for example, in Japan that Tasmania is free of certain diseases that occur on the mainland and we are able to export from Tasmania to Japan because that country recognises the area freedom concept, we have recognised the area freedom concept in a certain area of New Zealand and apples are exported only from this area where the disease is non-existent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not quite the same thing.
—That is the principle; I am explaining the principle.
—It might be the principle, but it is a pretty weak principle.

—If that is a weak principle, then Tasmania's ability to sell some of its produce in Japan would not exist because the Japanese might well discriminate, given that the diseases it is concerned about apply in some regions of Australia.
—The transport question is what it comes back to.

—I am explaining the concept of area freedom. If we can identify an area as disease free, or free of a particular disease, and quarantine that area so that it is protected and so that that disease will not penetrate, it is reasonable to say that we can import from that area-or, indeed, in the case of Tasmania, export from that area-in the knowledge that the disease is not transmissible.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to fire blight, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has published a discussion paper on the area freedom concept and on the concept as it applies in New Zealand to apples. It is now in the midst of extensive consultation with industry groups about that matter. At this point no decision has been taken-and I underline those words `no decision has been taken'. A decision will not be made until after the consultations have been properly conducted and concluded and until after conclusions have been reached and recommendations formed on the basis of that and on the basis of our best scientific knowledge. In terms of fire blight, the consultation clock is now ticking and, following the conclusion of that process, the Government will make a decision.

I repeat, though, that the Government cannot make a decision based on what might be producer pressure. We have to make a decision as a government based on the scientific argument. I might add that the producer groups are attending to the responsibility of making decisions on scientific grounds, rather than bringing vulgar pressure to apply because of what might be perceived as problems. These are difficult areas, and they involve careful judgment. It is not surprising that in this period of consultation there is anxiety and worry about what the implications might be. But we are a government committed to full and proper consultation. That is our record; we intend to keep it, and we will follow it through here.

Senator Archer referred to the listeria organism and said that there was contamination in 3 per cent of a year's shipment of cheese. I have a number of notes, which I will seek leave to table, which will amplify the details that I will now provide. I feel bound, while I am on my feet, to say a few words about listeria, as the honourable senator has raised this as a serious question. I think the point of the honourable senator's question was: why do we not stop the importation of cheese contaminated by listeria at the point of origin rather than apply our detective specialities in stopping it here? The problem with listeria is that the longer the particular cheese, the host for the listeria, is left in refrigeration or storage the more any manifestations of listeria that might exist will occur. We certainly inspect at the point of origin. But we have our strongest inspection deployment here. So, we reserve cheeses which have a record of containing listeria for even longer in storage so that we can be sure that they do not contain this very dangerous disease. I think the record of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in this area is a good one.

The honourable senator next raised the question of nitrates in cheese. He said that other countries put nitrates in cheese and asked why our domestic producers cannot. That is not a decision for the quarantine service. What can be done domestically is a decision for the National Health and Medical Research Council. I am advised now that the relevant committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council has decided to permit nitrates, within limits, to be put in cheese manufactured in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why go backwards?

—That is a decision for the National Health and Medical Research Council. I am not a scientist; I rely on scientists to advise me on what is acceptable in that respect. The codex of international standards would apply in this case. However, I understand that this is a decision for the National Health and Medical Research Council and I am bound to recognise it.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by referring to the other matter that was mentioned, namely, toxic dinoflagellates in ballast water in ships. The problem for Australia is that we are a bulk exporter of commodities, such as iron ore, coal, woodchips. There is nothing to backload those vessels with and they return to Australia in ballast. They take on seawater as ballast in Japan or at some other market and discharge it here. This is a problem if the water these ships take on contains organisms which may be exotic or foreign to Australia and which might give rise to disease.

I have to say that we have done considerable work on this problem in concert with major exporters. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, for example, lent us one of its vessels to use as a moving test laboratory on these problems. We are defining the problem and we are, I think, close to a solution. But we have a problem that the international shipping agencies and their associates are complaining about having to do special investigation and sampling work to assist our monitoring. One of the papers that I wish to table gives details about ballast water discharge.

I have taken some time over this matter, but Senator Archer has raised some detailed and important questions. I have tried to answer them as fulsomely as I can orally.
