I now seek leave to table documents concerning the following matters: controls on shipping ballast water discharge; mecadox residues in Canadian pig meat, a matter that I did not refer to; importation of bison from North America, a matter that I think Senator Archer raised at one time; the emergency response to a possible transmissible gastroenteritis outbreak; estimates of probability of entry of transmissible gastroenteritis in Canadian pig meat; and listeria in cheese. If I can table those documents it may help overcome some of the problems.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a brief comment to make. During his answer, the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) mentioned the fire blight situation. Earlier in the week, in answer to a question he became a little excited and accused the Opposition of trying to stir up and be critical of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I have no argument with the quarantine service at all. I would just like to pass on to the Minister that, in Tasmania, I have had many fruit growers come to me and call me about their concern about fire blight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister referred to the area freedom in Tasmania. I know the work that has gone on in Tasmania trying to convince the Japanese that we do not have a fruit fly problem. In fact, I believe there will be a good market in Japan once this is proved up. I can pass on to the Minister that the growers are very concerned about fire blight coming into Tasmania because, if it does, we immediately lose our area freedom, as it is called, thereby undoing all the good work that has been done with regard to the fruit fly.

Therefore, I want to say that the problems and the fears that the coalition and I have about fire blight are not raised to be critical of the quarantine service but because there is a genuine concern about the matter in fruit growing areas. I was a fruit grower myself in earlier days, and I am quite well aware of what has happened with different insects and pests that have been imported into this country over the years.

Earlier in the week, on another matter, in answer to a user friendly question by Senator McMullan, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) tried to put the Government's case on the Moscow Circus coming to Australia. I was talking to some circus people this morning and they raised with me the question why it is when they import animals from overseas they have to be in quarantine for such a long time. Can the Minister for Resources say what, if any, special arrangements were made with the Moscow Circus for the importation of animals? I believe that these animals will be going to 23 major country areas, and it therefore raises a little query about some disease perhaps being imported into Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first point, I thank the honourable senator for offering me the advice he offered me. I appreciate that there is a degree of anxiety out there. Whatever philosophic base we work on as a government and honourable senators opposite work on as an opposition, we are about changing things and, hopefully, from our own philosophical perspectives, improving things. The art of managing change is not an art that has been properly debated or indeed given enough public scrutiny. I recognise that as soon as we talk about change to longstanding arrangements people become anxious, not being certain about what their role in the future will be or how well they will fare in the face of that change. So I believe that we have to spend a great deal of painstaking time in explanation so that those anxieties are, as far as they can be, quelled. I appreciate the advice the honourable senator gave me.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the circus, we have a series of requirements about circuses and what the quarantine arrangements are. No relaxation of those quarantine arrangements occurs for particular circuses, but circuses from some parts of the world, I understand, would not be acceptable because of disease in those areas. A circus such as the Moscow Circus would be required to observe our special quarantine requirements, which are rigid and which mean that in some cases travelling international circuses do not bring their full range of animals on a tour of Australia; they concentrate on some other part of their circus offering.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Moscow Circus is receiving no different treatment from that received by any other circus?
—I confirm that, yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) back to the earlier inquiries before the Estimates committees about the export of merino semen. At the time, I asked a question about rams going to New Zealand and about whether, with the trade arrangement we have with New Zealand, it was possible that semen or, indeed, live rams were going on from New Zealand. At that time, with regard to my query about semen, I was not given any definite assurance that that was not happening.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has a quota of 900 rams that we can sell from the auction system to overseas buyers. That was quite a reasonable sort of quota but the technology of getting semen and exporting it has virtually increased one hundredfold the availability of genetic material overseas. My main worry at present is to know exactly what is happening in New Zealand and whether our rams going to New Zealand can bypass the system, with no redress on that at all. As I said, I did not get any great assurance, as the Hansard report shows, that that was not happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, with respect to New Zealand, Australia maintains an open and full access arrangement in the trade of breeding animals and breeding materials. That description includes semen, as well as embryos and so on. In exchange for the agreement with New Zealand, New Zealand guarantees a third country embargo, so that a New Zealander could not therefore import merino ram semen, for example, to New Zealand and then re-export it to another country. The third country embargo is designed to protect that situation.
—I presume that the Minister also meant that it would exclude a merino ram being put in an artificial insemination centre in New Zealand and exporting semen from there?
—I am advised yes.

—I thank the Minister for that answer but I do express a fear amongst people in the industry that a certain amount of that could be going on, and I believe that the Department, to the best of its ability, should keep an eye on it. I turn now to the wheat industry. At the Estimates committee stage, I asked a question about how such an exact figure for the wheat industry levy is arrived at. The Minister said where it would be distributed. I also asked at that time how well the Australian wheat crop was being estimated. Since then, we have had a further deterioration in wheat production in Australia. I know that the figure in Western Australia is up slightly on what was anticipated, but in the east the position has turned into a reasonable sort of disaster. Does the Minister have any later calculations on what the final figure for the wheat industry levy is likely to be?

—Unfortunately, I have no later calculations to offer Senator Panizza. I understand that they have gone up and down since the last time he inquired. Because the wheat crop is still being harvested, it is not possible to be definitive on this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move to the deregulated system and the inspection of the grain that is traded. I know that 80 per cent of our production will still be going overseas. It will be controlled by quarantine inspection and that sort of thing, so I am not worried about that. But the 20 per cent that will remain in Australia will be much more freely traded if the deregulated Wheat Marketing Act works as this Government expects it to. The free market will probably not build up much in the first year, but in time it will.

SPEECH.PARA: I am worried about the hygiene aspects of the wheat being traded without going through one of the bulk handling authorities. I know that it will be separated from the main bulk of the wheat for the export market and from the wheat for the internal market that is handled by the authorities. However, there is the matter of contamination and that sort of thing. Whereas at present bulk handling facilities are not too far apart, under the deregulated system in certain areas private bulk handling facilities may be erected on a railhead within 300, 400 or 500 metres of the bulk handling authority in each State. If the private facility does not keep up its inspection for and control of insects, it could eventually affect the other one. Also, a breed of weevil may become resistant to known chemicals and make the chemicals redundant. I wonder what the Department is doing about this. I know we were told at the Estimates hearings that no extra effort would be involved, but I still express fears that that situation could lead to a general downgrading in the standard of hygiene in the bulk handling of wheat around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will allay Senator Panizza's fears as best I can. He is right-and I think it is common ground between us across the chamber-that the 80 per cent of the Australian wheat crop that is exported is protected in the highest possible way by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, and that will remain the case. As for wheat that might be traded outside the bulk handling facilities in Australia-I think that is the area which the honourable senator identified as a potential area for problems of infection-I do not think he ought to be particularly agitated. What will operate in that market, I believe-and there are signs that this will be the case-is a concern by the consumers of that component of the wheat crop to ensure the quality of the wheat they purchase for domestic needs, such as bread manufacturing, as, indeed, there will be a concern by farmers to trade wheat to them of a high standard. The marketplace to some extent can be relied on to guarantee that but we will, of course, maintain an ever-vigilant eye on that development.

—I entirely agree with the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) when it comes to the wheat that goes to the mills for flour making, because it is to the absolute advantage of farmers that the wheat is kept clean. I am more worried about the wheat that will be used for stockfeed. Even though, as the Minister correctly pointed out, about 80 per cent will still be exported and roughly 20 per cent used in Australia, there is nothing to say that some of the wheat set aside for the domestic market will not find its way onto the export market. Wheat can be delivered to the pool up to 30 October. It can be kept in on-farm storage, or a private buyer may buy a large quantity of wheat and store it in a city or country silo he has put up himself. If he has taken a punt that he will make a dollar on it and finds that he cannot sell it, it will go back into the pool. I know that if it goes back into the pool it has to meet the standards of the Australian Wheat Board for delivery from day one, but the point is that if hygiene measures are not taken in those private facilities there is more of a chance of contamination getting past the sampling ramp. If the wheat goes straight from the paddock to the bulk handling authority at the siding, there is a very minimal chance of contamination. One would have to be unlucky to get a weevil in it-it might have landed on the load on its way through. But if the grain is stored in a not so modern facility within 200 metres of a bulk handling authority and is not properly kept, there is a chance that, on delivery back to the pool, contaminated wheat might get past the sampling ramp. After all, the sample that comes from any load-whether it is five tonnes or 30 tonnes-is half a hectolitre. I would like to hear what the Minister has to say on that point.

—Unfortunately, I do not have a lot to say other than that, within the way in which Senator Panizza has defined the quite limited problem he has identified, we recognise that there may be grounds for some worry. Senator Panizza has expressed a worry. We do not share those grounds, but we recognise that some people may have them and Senator Panizza is one who has given voice to them. It is for the State authorities to inspect wheat going back into the pool and, therefore, that is not something for which I can take responsibility. As I said before, we will keep a close eye on this and if our expectation or judgment is wrong we will take the necessary action to improve the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Senator Panizza has raised many of the concerns that were raised during the debate on wheat and its deregulation. As the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) said he would keep a vigilant eye on the concerns raised by Senator Panizza, I would also like to signal a matter to the Minister, and I hope he will keep a vigilant eye on it as well.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister is aware, one of the main concerns of those who were against the deregulation of the wheat industry was that it will simply open the market to two or three large grain merchants, who will have the potential to cartel the market, and that was not seen to be very efficient economics. It has been said that that will affect only the domestic market-20 per cent of the market-and the other 80 per cent of the market will still be controlled by the Australian Wheat Board for export purposes.

Can the Minister keep a vigilant eye on this? What checks and balances does he have in place to prevent these large grain merchants from snookering the export market? By that, I mean that they can simply buy up as much wheat as they like on the domestic market, thus affecting the export supplies. It may be that they will buy so much wheat in one year that they will have a surplus the next. That will affect domestic market prices for the next year and grain merchants will be able to hold large supplies and be in a better bargaining position against the farmers in the domestic market. They could then go running to the Government saying. `We have these huge surpluses. We overbought last year. Allow us to export this year'. That would be the thin end of the wedge. That is the first point: how do we prevent them from snookering the market in that way?

Secondly, in one year they may buy huge surpluses, which they are free to do. Then, when the Wheat Board tries to meet its export contracts, it finds that there is no grain in the domestic market for it to buy up; it has been beaten to the punch. So it then has to buy from these grain merchants-at a premium price-to meet its export contracts. In those two ways the grain merchants can snooker the export market by simply having access to the domestic market and being able to buy as much as they like. We should not think that they cannot do that. Heaven knows, Elders IXL Ltd is a billion dollar company and can go into the market and buy up. I signal those two concerns to the Minister. Are there existing checks and balances to prevent that or will he keep a vigilant eye on the matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —All my four eyes are relatively vigilant. I make the observation that there were many elements to Senator McGauran's question, some of which started with, `What if' and ended, `then that'. I recognise Senator McGauran's interest in the wheat debate and his high profile participation in it. I will refer his questions to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and ask him to comment on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one final question. I reiterate the concerns that I expressed at the Estimates Committee F hearings about the collection of the wheat levy, which is on a purely voluntary system. I know that already in practice the new buyers in the deregulated market are discounting what they pay to the growers by 2 1/2 per cent, so each grower is paying it anyway. I would prefer the levy to go into the research fund than anywhere else. Even though the Minister assured me at the Estimates Committee hearings that the Government has good measures in place to ensure that this levy is collected from the buyers, I still have strong doubts that the Government will collect anywhere near the correct amount. I asked whether the Government will do as it does with other levies around Australia and use the Australian Taxation Office to collect it. I was advised that the Government had thought of using the Taxation Office but either chose not to or did not think it was necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: As this is only the first year of deregulation, I ask the Government to implement measures to ensure that the levy is collected. The growers are paying the levy. In the final analysis, they negotiate a price with the buyers and the buyers then simply say, `Of course, we have to take off the wheat levy'. The growers then say, `But I thought you were responsible for that' and the buyers say, `No, we have to take it off'. As far as I am concerned, the levy should go into the fund. I would like a proper mechanism put in place to make sure that it gets there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take on board Senator Panizza's observations and, as with Senator McGauran's questions, I will draw them to the attention of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Community Services and Health
Proposed expenditure, $1,478,313,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the advisers are changing, I will sketch in the background to the matter that I wish to raise with the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), and why I wish to raise this matter. The Senate will recall-I think it was in the appropriations debate last year-that I raised, under the appropriations for the Department of Community Services and Health, the phenomenon of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) and the need to research it and come to grips with its dimensions and implications for the Australian community. A number of professionals are doing research in this area. I refer specifically to Dr Mark Donohoe and Dr Joachim Fluhrer, whose work has been extensively publicised. From their work in Australia it is apparent that we may have a problem of massive proportions resulting from the uses and abuses of chemicals of various types in the agricultural and secondary industrial context, and also in the domestic context.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the question: To what extent are these problems addressed, and to what extent has the need to research them and to place funds in the appropriate quarters for them to be researched been acknowledged in the appropriations? In speaking to that question, I draw the attention of the Minister to an article headed `Shock poison levels in our blood', which he may have already seen, which appeared in the Sun-Herald on 5 November this year. It reported the work of Dr Mark Donohoe and Dr Joachim Fluhrer in relation to 300 CFS sufferers, the results of samples of their blood which were analysed in the United States, and the quite extraordinary implications of these results for the Australian medical profession and, most definitely, for the Government.

I also draw the Minister's attention to an article which appeared in the Oregonian, which is a newspaper published in Oregon in the United States, on 3 November 1989. It reports the case of the Supreme Court of the United States upholding a judgment and awarding damages of $1.5m in the case of a forest service employee who died of cancer. The court upheld that he died of Hodgkin's disease attributed to exposure to 2,4-D-an extremely widely used chemical in Australia and one which has been widely used for many years. I am citing this case to point out what I think is one of the great sleeping questions of Australian health. I am framing the question to establish the Government's posture and readiness to address the issue of CFS and the extent to which it is acknowledged in the appropriations.

The article in the Sun-Herald to which I referred reports the work of Mark Donohoe and Joachim Fluhrer. Mark Donohoe is a friend of mine and he lives in my own community on the central coast of New South Wales. He has specialised in chronic fatigue syndrome and I am citing his work for two reasons, both of which are already known to the Minister and the Senate; but I think it is worth citing now in the light of this question. Mark Donohoe's research is significant because he has attempted to carry it out in general practice, and in doing so has bumped up against what I might term the obstinancy of the system. To use his term, his practice was targeted-I agree that it is a targeted practice-as one which used pathology excessively. Many of the claims of the patients to whom he was trying to render medical service have been rejected. In a boxed side article next to the main article in the Sun-Herald of 5 November, the case of the Humphries family in Manly is cited. This family is caught in the trap of chronic fatigue syndrome. Their circumstances are extraordinary but, of course, it is estimated that about 15,000 Australians may be suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome. I am simply saying that, if it is of that magnitude or greater, some of these people are making claims for medical reimbursement which are not being met, that the refusals are on a random basis, and that there is a bureaucratic and medical problem here which the system is simply not responding to or acknowledging adequately.

The work of Donohoe and Fluhrer suggests that poisons may be occurring in Australian communities at 10 times the level occurring in similar communities-in other words, urban city communities-in the United States of America. The chemicals which they cite are generally referred to as HCB, DDT, DDE, dieldrin, dichloromethane, chloroform, trichloroethylene and tetrachloroethylene. They indicate the incidence and level of these chemicals in Australian blood samples as opposed to American blood samples. In some instances it is up to 100 times greater than it is in samples taken from people living in similar American urban environments. They go further and say that these levels are probably causal to the chronic fatigue syndrome. They state:
Chronic fatigue syndrome has been dubbed the Yuppie Flu because it usually strikes young, hard-working, active individuals with white collar jobs.
They may start out being allergic to certain substances or food but gradually, their immune systems start to fail them, and they suffer almost constant feelings of fatigue and `unwell-ness'.

Hence, this is dubbed the chronic fatigue syndrome. Dr Fluhrer likens the people who have become ill to the budgies that were taken down into the mines to test the safety of the atmosphere. If the budgie died the conclusion was arrived at that the mining environment was unsafe and that everybody else should stay out. He is drawing an analogy between the sufferers. He says that what these people on the forward edge of this phenomenon are telling us is that we have a major problem and that we must address it, and that to do that we must direct resources to it.
I will very briefly describe the circumstances of Enid Humphries and her family, to whom I referred earlier. An article states:
Enid Humphries dreads going to bed at night for fear that her children will be dead in the morning.
`You live for the moment,' she said from her Manly flat. You just don't know how long you've got.'
Enid, 48, her three children and her husband Jim suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome, caused they believe, by chemicals.
They have moved from Parkes in the country because `the country air is deadly' . . .
It really is extraordinary and alarming when a family find that country air for them is deadly. In quite real terms the family have had to relocate. The article continues:
and have combed Queensland, Victoria and New South Wales in vain search for a safe place to live.

In other words, people who suffer from this syndrome are really in most extraordinary circumstances. If we accept the findings of Donohoe and Fluhrer that we have a major problem and that we are on the forward edge of a major problem, if we accept the rulings of the Supreme Court of Oregon, which sustained an award of damages of $1.5m against the Dow Chemical Co., and if we accept the ruling of the medical experts who gave evidence in that Supreme Court ruling that the Hodgkin's lymphoma disease was attributable to 2,4-D, which, for heaven's sake, as a keen gardener I have used over and over again to kill the weeds in my lawn, and have been doing so for years-and I doubt whether Senator Stone accepts these findings-we have a problem that hopefully the Department of Community Services and Health is addressing.

We hope that it is funding, supporting and showing interest in the research which Donohoe and Fluhrer are conducting and will begin to acknowledge that people in general practice, or general practitioners, who are attempting to address and wrestle with these syndromes and diseases in the community are now being targeted as overprescribers of pathology. Hopefully, it will acknowledge the fact that some people, in good faith, present to those doctors and then find their medical benefits claims rejected on a random sampling basis. Hopefully, it will acknowledge these as serious problems. Hopefully, those problems are acknowledged in the appropriations for the Department of Community Services and Health-the dollars and cents that will be approved this morning, in a few minutes from now hopefully there will be, somewhere, an acknowledgment of the need to expand upon the work of Donohoe and Fluhrer, to parallel them and to pursue these phenomena in the community.

I put that as a broad question to the Minister. I hope that the answer I get in these appropriations is more satisfactory than the answer I got a year ago. In other words, my question is: Have we moved forward? Is that progress acknowledged in the appropriations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should start by acknowledging Senator McLean's interest in this subject. It is correct, as he has said, that a year ago he raised matters concerning the chronic fatigue syndrome. At that time I said that I too was well aware of this problem, as a friend of mine has contracted the disease. A vibrant, energetic, enthusiastic individual now lacks the energy to do menial household chores. It is shocking to see the decline. I fervently hope that she and her family can find a cure for it, as do her family. I have to admit, though, that at the moment I do not have an adviser who can give me a detailed breakdown on what the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) might be funding on research into this area. On that basis, I wonder whether the honourable senator will enable me to take on notice his question on the actual provision within the appropriations, or the relationship with this syndrome. I will reply to him in detail on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean has raised another matter. It concerned the use of chemicals that we, come into contact with in our daily lives. He cited a relationship that Mark Donohoe had found in his investigations between those chemicals and possibly the chronic fatigue syndrome. He referred to the forest service employee exposed to 2,4-D in Oregon. On the question of household chemicals and the claims of cancer risk, the Government and the National Health and Medical Research Council are, as we would expect, aware of the community interest in and concern about chemicals in the environment.

On 2 November the NHMRC met in Canberra and endorsed a uniform code of practice for the safe use of organochlorin termiticides. It is also proposing a new program for the training of pest control operators. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his science and technology statement in May this year, also announced the establishment of a special environmental toxicology unit which will further increase the capacity of the NHMRC to do research into environmental toxicology. Specifically, it will provide basic and applied research in public health toxicology, training of toxicologists at the post-graduate level, continuing education for relevant professionals, an information service, and an environmental health consulting service. That may take the answer as far as I can along the track of the concerns the honourable senator has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the members of Estimates Committee F, I rise briefly to indicate why I will not be asking any questions today. While some of the matters we raised caused some disputation in the Committee I would just like to record my belief that the Estimates Committee itself dealt with the matters adequately. In other words, where we were not happy and we argued about some matters they were made clear and where we sought answers they were obtained.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want the officers of the Department of Community Services and Health who have prepared for the Committee of the Whole to think that there is a lack of interest. I just indicate that, because of the way in which we were able to proceed within the Estimates Committee itself, it is not my desire or intention now to raise further questions in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Department of Community Services and Health a number of questions which I placed on notice. I appreciate the long and detailed answers that I was given but I have two very short questions to ask. I asked a question about the number of hostel beds planned and the number of actual hostel beds. The answer I got included:

SPEECH.PARA: However, recently enacted amendments to the relevant legislation will allow detailed quantification of approved and operational hostel beds . . .

It does not seem to me that the Department has been able to give me the number of actual beds. I would have thought-and I may be wrong-that this could have been worked out from the grants that are given to hostel residents. We ought to be able to know the number of actual beds in each State. Can the Minister answer that question? Is there a problem in being able to provide the number of actual hostel beds?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is a problem in providing the honourable senator with hard figures. The Department is unable--
—That is appalling!

—Let me just explain because I think it will be understandable when the explanation is heard. The Department is unable to be certain about the number of beds being used by residents, the number of beds that might be used by staff, and how those interchange. However, we are in the throes of preparing legislation which will enable us to say specifically the number of beds being used by residents and we will be able to put a figure on that because it will provide a limitation. In order to try to give the honourable senator the best available information, I have asked the Department to give the honourable senator an approximate figure, rather than a hard figure, of the normal ratio or breakup-through general experience-of resident beds and staff beds. I am not sure whether the Department can do that, but it will look at that in a minute and I will supply the honourable senator with that information when it comes to hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think staff attract a subsidy from the Government for their beds. I think it is appalling that we do not know how many government-funded hostel beds there are. My second question to the Department was:

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Department justify-
maybe I should have asked `Can the Government justify', but that would have been a political question-
the fact that older people in a small rural bush nursing home attract no subsidy at all.
I ask this question now of the Minister because the answer I received was:
Residents of small rural bush nursing homes do receive Commonwealth nursing home benefits.

This is the second occasion on which the Department has taken me literally. Once before I asked a question and I got some figures on the day I asked the question; I did not get the up-to-date figures. Obviously, members of the Department took me literally here and I can understand that. Perhaps I should have said `small rural bush hospitals', as there is a difference.

I went to Merino, a small town in Victoria, where over 70 per cent of the population is over 65. They are serviced there by a small bush nursing hospital and eight people in that hospital receive the equivalent of nursing home care. They are subsidised there by their medical benefits fund. They are not acute hospital patients; they are long term patients. I think it is absolutely atrocious that old people in this area do not attract government subsidies. If they lived 20 or 50 miles down the road in a nursing home they would get that subsidy. They are not receiving the sort of care they should be, given that they have paid taxes all their lives.

Can the Minister tell me why the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, cannot work out a creative way in which to fund those small bush nursing hospitals that are looking after long term patients? I know that we now have multipurpose centres but there will be only 14 in Australia and I bet my bottom dollar that that will not include the Merino Bush Nursing Hospital. The departmental officers should go and have a look at those patients who are being cared for there and they should look at the people who are receiving meals on wheels from that small bush nursing hospital. If the hospital closes they will receive their meals from the local pub but they will not get the same sort of attention, despite the publican's concern for them. When they suddenly look ill the nursing sister from the hospital goes down to visit them. A 92-year-old lady in that area goes in once a week for her meals on wheels; she has a spa; she is looked at by the nurse; she has an ulcer fixed up; and she has done whatever else might need to be done. I am sure from my visit that she is being kept out of a nursing home as a result of that care.

I really cannot understand why we cannot get our act together. Because Victoria has these small bush nursing hospitals that do not exist in other States we have a formula that does not fix this problem for those people. I would really like to know whether the Minister has any answers and whether we can have a more flexible system to deal with that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Commonwealth Government funds the States on a block grant basis and it is then for the States to decide across which centres they will disburse those funds and which centres they will fund. As a consequence, the Commonwealth is not directly involved in allocations to individual small bush nursing hospitals; that is a matter for each of the States to decide. Given the closeness to the ground of the departments of health in the States, I think that is an understandable provision. However, the honourable senator raised the matter of the multipurpose centres. I can advise the honourable senator that the Department is currently considering applications and it will be announcing something on that score very soon.

—It is all very well for the Commonwealth Government to say that it will keep its nose out of the nursing home pie when it suits it; yet it pokes around the nursing home pie when it wants to make the sorts of amendments and changes that it has made. Does the Minister think it is fair and reasonable for elderly people in a small town like Merino to be deprived of a government subsidy for care which is adequate, appropriate and, I believe, of the same standard as nursing homes within the State and maybe have to move quite a long way from their own environment in order to receive a government subsidy? They will no longer be able to stay in their own community. Is that the sort of policy that this Government wants to pursue?
—That is a political question. I am not familiar with the circumstances in the centre cited by the honourable senator.
—You live in the State.
—In Merino?
—No, you live in the State.

—I live in a State; that is right. But the honourable senator has given me a specific example and she has asked me to agree with her that those circumstances are not desirable. I do not know the case that the honourable senator is citing so I am not in a position--
—There are many of them, Senator, as you would know if you visited the bush.

—However, the point I make is that this is the basis on which Commonwealth funds are disbursed. If we wanted to change that basis I guess that we would have to put up a fight with the States. That may be what the honourable senator wants; I do not know. I recognise that the honourable senator has an interest in this matter and I will refer her questions to the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only one question in this area. I was a member of Estimates Committee F and we had some complicated areas to handle but we did this all in committee. We wound it all up as satisfactorily as we could. My worry at the moment concerns the strategy proposal for the management of the pharmaceutical benefits program. We were unable to deal with this matter at the time of the Estimates hearings because we were unaware of it. The proposal, sent to all chemists by the Health Insurance Commission on 30 October, is to put computer hardware and software in all the dispensing chemists around Australia, the hardware being capable of taking magnetic tape cards for the purpose of monitoring patients' prescription entitlements. Apparently, this is a response to the Auditor-General's report which indicated an error rate of 40 per cent in determining entitlements to prescriptions. The Government's response to this is to institute a computerised checking system. I doubt very much whether there would be an error rate of 40 per cent in the present system. There may be quite a few clerical errors in the transcribing of numbers, for example, but that does not necessarily mean that people are not entitled to the benefits. If there were any cause for errors it could be delays in the Department of Social Security in the notification, for example, of dates for unemployment benefits stopping and starting.

SPEECH.PARA: The black box, as it is called in the proposal that was sent around, to be installed as part of the existing chemists' computer set-up will be able to take the magnetic cards. This will lock the chemists into whatever system of administration the Government wants for its pharmaceutical benefits in the future-as though the Government has not enough problems with the chemists at the moment. The chemists will virtually have to act as a police force for the Government. They will have to verify the patient's identity and the patient's entitlement, and that verification will be checked with the central computer in Canberra. The system is not only for items on the pharmaceutical benefits list but also for items below $11, because they are involved in the safety net provisions of the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits.

Although only about 10 per cent of the people are in requirement of medication at any one time, if we go for long enough we will eventually have everybody involved in this system, so an identity card is inevitable once the system gets under way. The important thing about it is that it is to be administered by the Health Insurance Commission. It was proposed that the Health Insurance Commission, which administers the Medicare card, should also administer the Australia Card when it was introduced. Of course, the Health Insurance Commission already has computer linkages to the Department of Social Security and, through the Department of Social Security, to the Australian Taxation Office. Many people, including me, see this as ominous. As the Committee knows, a double dissolution was called over the issue of the Australia Card.

I am aware that the Minister answered a question yesterday about the pharmaceutical benefits card being the Australia Card by the back door. He responded in high dudgeon, saying that no such thought had entered the Government's mind. But when we put the whole picture together we can see that the Minister may have protested too much.

The matter of the invasion of privacy must be considered with this sort of thing because the Government will have on its central books a medication history of all of us. It will show not only a list of patients but also the prescribing pattern of all the prescribers and the medication pattern of all of the prescribees, which will, of course, give people in head office an opportunity to examine patterns. As has happened in other countries, if a doctor's figures are too high, if he is prescribing too many medications or prescribing medications that are too expensive according to the bureaucracy, he can be put on what is called a prescriber's budget. That is, if he prescribes more than a certain amount a month, the Government will not honour the prescriptions. If I were such a doctor's patient I would want to get in early in the month before he hit the limit of his prescriber's budget. This, of course, would decrease the quality of care.

I am apprehensive about the implementation of this strategy proposal for the management of the pharmaceutical benefits program simply because it involves a computer link from all the chemists shops throughout Australia to a central computer in Canberra. The new card will have a magnetic tape on it to which a lot of other information can be attached. Ostensibly, it is to be able to eradicate faults and errors in the system, but I think it is quite possible to eliminate errors with the current system. I do not think there is a 40 per cent error rate in that system. The Health Insurance Commission must have reacted with some glee to this Auditor-General's report, because it has given it the opportunity to bring in a computer system which is much like the Medicare card system and the previously proposed Australia Card system that would suit the purposes of the control of the pharmacists very well. As I said, when it is introduced it will lock the pharmacists into the Government's program and into any future alterations in the Government's proposal. I see it as a retrograde step. I ask the Minister to expand on the answer that he gave yesterday, without taking umbrage at the question. I ask him to explain why this is not the Australia Card through the back door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will accept Senator Sheil's invitation. Before I turn to that matter, I acknowledge the remarks that Senator Peter Baume made before he left the chamber. I respect his point that the fact he is not pursuing questions in the Committee of the Whole does not mean that he does not have questions but he thinks it is appropriate to deal with them in the Estimates hearings. On that score I anticipate that in the next Estimates hearing, one of the issues that will be pursued will be the question of performance indicators, and the Department should be well and truly aware of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to Senator Sheil's question. As honourable senators know, the question asked of me yesterday was asked by Senator Calvert. I promised Senator Calvert a fuller answer to the specific detail in his question. I am in a position now to give some detail, which may duplicate my answer to Senator Calvert. Nonetheless, I will keep my promise to Senator Calvert and give him the answer in due course.

The first point to make is that the Government rejects the idea that this is the Australia Card revisited, by the back door or whatever other categorisation people wish to put on it. It is true that there is an argument between the Government and the pharmacists about the level of pharmacy fees. That is notorious. It is in our newspapers daily and on our airwaves daily. It would be a pity though, when the Government is pursuing other efficiency changes in a related field, if the issue of dispute between the Government and the pharmacists were expanded to encompass that field when the intentions in that other field are innocent and, in fact, are complementary to the needs of pharmacists and assist with the requirements on government to act in this area. It is in that category, in the heat and dint of battle, that things are seized upon and used as arguments when in the cold, clear light of day they may not be. If there were no battle raging between the Government and pharmacists at this time, I suspect that this issue would not be alive.

I have a detailed brief on this matter, selected parts of which I will read. The Health Insurance Commission is not looking at an Australia Card but at redesigning processing systems for pharmaceutical claims to overcome, as Senator Sheil has rightly described them, inefficiencies identified by the Auditor-General. So it is in reaction to the Auditor-General's findings that action is occurring. He stimulated the initiation of this process. Pharmacists have always submitted details of scripts filled as part of the claiming process. Over 50 per cent of claims are now submitted in computer form with the full cooperation of the Pharmacy Guild as well as the provision of hard copies of all scripts. It is difficult to see how pharmacists could expect to be paid for dispensing without providing those details for the Commonwealth-axiomatic, I would have thought. All the Health Insurance Commission is doing is looking at how to improve the efficiency of that process. Indeed, one of the advantages is that it would facilitate prompter payment to pharmacists.

The HIC is holding discussions with the Guild on the proposed new system. The Government has made no decision on the proposals. It is waiting to look at the outcome of the consultations with the Guild before considering the proposal. While that process is going on the HIC has invited tenders on the basis of the proposal, which is subject to ministerial approval in the end. That does not in any way diminish the Government's commitment to conclude those consultations with the pharmacists properly. The present argument is one of the things that are pushing this off the agenda and preventing those consultations from being realised in the normal way. Tenders have been sought. That will enable, when we have an idea of the range of services that are available and the costs that might be involved, a ministerial decision to be made about the proposal in the light of all the information that can be garnered and that is necessary for a decision.

It is also not proposed to issue a card that contains the person's date of birth or sex for people who have paid for more than 25 prescriptions. A card is currently issued to persons who reach the maximum number of scripts so that they may obtain medicines free of charge for the remainder of the year. That procedure, I am advised, will continue. The application form for the card requires information such as name, date of birth and sex so as to appropriately identify the persons in respect of whom the entitlement is intended to apply. I think that may answer many of the concerns that Senator Sheil has, but if there are other matters I invite him to raise them or advise me of them and I will obtain information on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister very much for his answer. It all sounds very innocuous. He explains that the scheme is in the process of implementation. But the instructions are that there will be no manually processed claims after January 1991. So the Government is moving ahead at quite a sharp clip with the implementation of this scheme. The scheme will be implemented as per this document that has been circulated. Although the Minister refers to negotiations with the chemists, the ones who have spoken to me about this matter are saying that it is a very one-sided negotiation and that they are more or less being told what they have to do to implement the Government's plan. Although the card has a magnetic tape on it and it is proposed to put only basic information on the tape, the capacity remains for other information to go on the tape.

SPEECH.PARA: An enormous cost is involved in the hardware and software-an ongoing cost which the Government will pay-to install this material in the pharmacies. This shows a certain amount of keenness on the Government's part to get this system up and running. The danger remains that further information can be stored on the magnetic tape. There are connections between the Health Insurance Commission, the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office via computer linkages already. So my fears about the matter are not allayed by the Minister's explanation simply because the scheme is being introduced in this most innocuous manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Sheil's sentiments. We are between a rock and a hard place with this matter. If we are dilatory in implementing the recommendations of the Auditor-General we get criticised for failing to perform properly. If we are not dilatory we are sometimes accused-as we are in this general public debate-of acting too hastily. It is a matter of judgment as to whether we have acted correctly. I concede that but I underline the fact that we are not proposing under this system to change the basis of the information that is sought. We are seeking the same information as was sought under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which has operated for 30 years, and the Pharmpay system. It in no way alters the responsibility of the pharmacists under section 87 (3) (a) of the National Health Act to satisfy themselves that persons are entitled to pensioner or concessional status before supplying a benefit and so on. So in that sense it is a matter of efficiency. I guess that in modern debate, with ever improving and rapidly, exponentially expanding technology, the idea that a computer might be used rather than a more inefficient way is sometimes threatening to people, but this system is simply meant to be a more efficient way of doing things, according to the Auditor-General's report.

-A few moments ago when I was asking questions of Senator Cook I became somewhat indignant that he did not know in detail about the Merino Bush Nursing Hospital. I had a lapse of attention and thought he was Senator Evans. Senator Evans ought to know about the Merino Bush Nursing Hospital because he is a senator for Victoria. Senator Cook looked perplexed. His perplexity alerted me to the fact that I had made an error. Despite the fact that he did not know about the Merino Bush Nursing Hospital, I am sure that he has been made aware, through my comments, of the general problems of older people in long term care in bush nursing hospitals. I apologise to him for my indignation. It was the beard.
—I promise not to tell Senator Evans if Senator Patterson does not. She has probably insulted us both-me because she thinks I am Evans, and Evans because she thinks he might be me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I place on record my acknowledgment of the efficiency with which the Department of Community Services and Health has responded to all but a few of the questions that I asked. As you know, Mr Temporary Chairman, having been Chairman of Estimates Committee F for some time, that has not always been the case. Answers have not always been readily forthcoming and have had to be re-asked of the Department. But on this occasion I feel that an acknowledgment of the efficiency of the Department should be placed on record. Whether that has been the result of a combination of the efforts of the Department and the efforts of the Minister for Resources and Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Cook), or whether it is because of your weight as Chairman of Estimates Committee F, Mr Temporary Chairman, I do not know. Whatever the case, there has been a combination of factors.

SPEECH.PARA: All is not totally well because a number of matters relating to the narrow area of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) have not been adequately answered. Frankly, the responses from the Department of Community Services and Health have not been adequate. The Committee secretariat had to wait an inordinate length of time before the list of the NHMRC recommended grants for 1990 was made available. The Budget contains millions and millions of dollars for NHMRC grants. This document came into my proud possession only very recently and that situation occurs almost every year. I do not think it appropriate that we should blindly endorse the global figure for expenditure under the medical research scheme without being informed as to who will receive the grants and what the grants are all about.

Policy decisions have obviously been taken by the NHMRC in respect of certain grants. Those policy issues relate to a number of areas, including the question of human embryo experimentation. This chamber established a Senate select committee on that subject that recommended that there be no destructive experiments on human embryos. This document appears to contain certain grants which, in the end, would lead to experimentation on human embryos. I might say that the Department, and presumably the NHMRC, failed to answer my question relevant to the Singer-Kuhre-Gase grant. I wanted to know whether the Department considered that the NHMRC funding of papers primarily intended to criticise the findings of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation was appropriate expenditure of funds which were scarce in the medical research area.
The Department also failed to inform the Committee of the number of unsuccessful applications for NHMRC grants. The excuse was as follows:
The Minister has not been informed by the Council-
that is, the NHMRC-
of how many projects considered worthy of support were unsuccessful in 1990.

That is not an adequate answer and the Minister for Resources knows that as well as I do. Parliament should be given the number of unsuccessful worthy applicants in 1990 so that it can make a judgment about appropriateness or whether sufficient funds were going to these researchers. There are two ways that we can do this. I suppose that I could spend half a day, which I do not want to, going through this matter and asking the Minister questions about various details. The other way to go about it is to ask the Minister whether he will give an undertaking to the Committee-I have done this on a previous occasion, so I am not doing anything new-that the questions I asked about the details of the applications and their evaluation and the two questions to which I referred just a moment ago can be responded to very quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the hour, I will be very brief. The answer to that question is, `Yes'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer today to a matter that, by any measure, would be called one of public interest because it relates to the developments in eastern Europe. I do not wish to make a long speech about matters of foreign affairs, important as they may be, but about a matter of potential domestic concern arising from them. Recently I had the good fortune to attend, as a representative of my Party, a meeting in Geneva, the principal subject matter of which was a discussion about the developments in eastern Europe. In the course of that meeting I had the opportunity to have discussions with people from Hungary and from the German Democratic Republic who have been involved with the movements for democracy there and in endeavouring to form social democratic parties to contest the free and fair elections which we all hope are forthcoming.

SPEECH.PARA: While I welcome the changes that have occurred in those countries in eastern Europe and have some optimism that they will continue, I want to refer to some of the consequential questions. I, like everybody in the Senate, support the moves that are being initiated for economic assistance to smooth the transition to democracy in those countries. It is quite clear that in those countries, as elsewhere, economics has been driving politics. One of the significant issues is the extent to which Mr Gorbachev has understood that point and Deng Xiaoping has not. The point I want to make is a very important one. It was raised several times at the meeting which I attended-particularly by representatives of Third World countries, but not only by them-that it is very important that, in looking at the question of providing economic assistance for the development of those countries and their economies, the money is not diverted from what would otherwise be the aid budget provided to developing countries.

Willy Brandt, who chaired the meeting which I attended, raised the matter. It was also raised, I noticed recently, by Russell Rollason, the General Secretary of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. Willy Brandt said at that meeting-and I think he was correct-that the poorest people in the world should not fund the transition to democracy in eastern Europe. If financial assistance has to be supplied, it should not be at the expense of the poorest people in the poorest countries. It is important that that assistance is provided, and Australia has a very small part to play in that. I do not want to exaggerate our role. We have a very small economy and we are a long way from Europe and we have many other commitments, but we have made some small and appropriate commitments.

It is not a time to be mean spirited. It is obvious that there are limits to the amount of financial assistance any country can give and the extent to which that can be additional to its other financial commitments. But I am very satisfied with the initiatives that the Australian Government has announced so far. We are not the first on the list of those who should contribute. I welcome the fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is proposing to visit those countries. I also welcome the statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). But I want to put the matter in context: there are other vital transitions to democracy going on around the world. Media coverage in Australia, and in Europe when I visited it, is very Eurocentric. There is not the same amount of interest taken in the fact that there is a fundamental transition to democracy taking place in Chile this year and that its economy will need a lot of assistance if that democracy is to continue. Because it is not next door to Europe and does not get easy access to all the major European news networks, it is not a big issue, either in Australia or in Europe.

In our region, I refer to the economic changes in Vietnam and the optimism we have for potential change in Cambodia. I am not talking about any particular proposal, or the current disagreement that might exist between the parties in this chamber about the best thing we can do in the short term to assist. But those movements for change are under way and we must keep the matter in perspective. If Burma-or Myanmar, as it is now known-were on the border of Austria or West Germany instead of being where it is, it would have made the front pages instead of Prague. I think Australia has to keep a sense of perspective about the importance of the change in eastern Europe. I do not mean in any way to downplay it; there is no more important change going on anywhere in the world, and I welcome it with enthusiasm.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are having elections in Taiwan, too.

—Yes, I look forward to the continuation of such progress. I think that is not only inevitable but also desirable. As Senator Calvert said, democracy is spreading to a number of countries in which it has been denied for a very long time, and we should all welcome that. The people trying to introduce it often need our assistance. It is a time for generosity. I simply reiterate that that generosity should not be at the expense of the poorest of the poor-the poorest people in the poorest countries. It should not be at the expense of the already stretched aid budgets in Australia and in other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: It should not be the responsibility of the poor people in Asia and Africa to smooth the transition to democracy. They are paying the economic price; they do not have the political benefit. If we feel that that assistance should be provided, it is up to us to put the argument to our taxpayers and for the countries of western Europe and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development to put the arguments to their taxpayers as to why it should be done. I believe they would respond favourably because they appreciate the importance of what is happening. I simply want to put on the record something that I think has not been addressed sufficiently in this country-that is, assistance should be provided but not at the expense of the very important contributions that we and others need to make to the economic development of other countries and in some instances their struggle for or transition to democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about a matter raised with me this morning by Mr Robert Perry, the proprietor of one of the eight privately owned family circuses in Australia. By way of background, they employ about 3,000 people and have been part of our culture in Australia for many years. They have, as my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen would know, provided family entertainment around Australia, including in our remote country areas, for many years. I inform the Senate, as President of the Royal Agricultural Society of Tasmania, that the Royal Hobart Show has recently concluded. At that show, one of the attractions was a family circus which was free of charge for the people of Hobart. It was very well received and many young people, and old people too, gained a lot of enjoyment from it.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted on Tuesday of this week that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), in reply to a user-friendly question from Senator McMullan, who has just left the chamber, made some comments about the proposed visit to Australia by the Moscow Circus. The Minister stated:
The Department has decided to grant visas for the tour and I see no reason to interfere with that decision.

On that same day, in Melbourne, I believe, Mr Hoffman from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs met with representatives of the circuses, Mr Michael Edgley, the Director of Michael Edgley International, the Showman's Guild of Australasia and Actors Equity. The reason for that meeting, of course, was to raise concerns as to the effect that the visit of the Moscow Circus to major country centres may have on the eight family circuses which currently service these areas in Australia.

I want to put on record straight away that I have no argument with the Moscow Circus; in fact, I agree with what Senator Ray said about it. I think it will be wonderful for the people of Australia to be able to visit the Moscow Circus and see its wonderful performers. I quote what the Minister said:
People in country areas will be thrilled to hear that they will see these internationally renowned performers. The capital cities loss, in fact, will be the country cities gain.
I do not argue with that, nor do I argue with the following comment by the Minister:
It will bring joy to hundreds of thousands of Australians in provincial areas. In the long run I doubt that it will do any damage to the Australian circus industry.

I hope that is the case, because I am concerned about the effect it may have on the viability of Australian circuses. I am already led to believe that, as a result of the fact that people know that the Moscow Circus will visit some of these provincial towns, one circus that is currently in north Queensland has suffered a 30 per cent loss of patronage because people are holding back, knowing that the Moscow Circus is coming.

Earlier today I raised with Senator Cook whether any special quarantine deals had been done with the Moscow Circus. I am pleased to say that he assured me that no favoured treatment would be given to the Moscow Circus and no quarantine laws would be breached. That was one of the concerns that were raised with me by the circus people. I do find it unusual that visas were granted on Tuesday, I believe. They may have been granted last week, but the Minister made note of it on Tuesday. I have been told that Michael Edgley's company has spent about $4m on advertising and has already sold 50,000 seats. It begs the question as to whether Michael Edgley may have been given assurances from the Immigration Department beforehand. I find it rather unusual, to say the least, that a person with his business acumen would spend $4m and sell 50,000 seats before he had obtained visas from the Department. I will be asking the Minister at a future date whether the Government did give a favourable nod to Michael Edgley International with regard to the arrival of this circus.

I note that at the meeting that was held with the different parties a slight concession was made in an effort to allay the fears of the circuses. The slight concession made was that two shows have been dropped-one in Mount Isa and one in Darwin. I do not wish to be cynical, but one would have to say that that was a very slight concession. I also note that, as a result of that meeting, Senator Ray stated that Mr Edgley had agreed to share costs with Australian circuses of a research study into the impact of the Moscow Circus on the local circus industry. What happens if that study proves that there has been a significant financial impact on Australian circuses? It will be too late at that stage. Who will pay the wages? It is feared that some of these Australian circuses will go to the wall, thus denying the remote areas of Australia entertainment which perhaps is not up to the standard of the Moscow Circus, but which nevertheless has formed a very important part of our cultural heritage over many years.

I conclude by saying that I have raised these concerns today because I believe it should be put on the record that eight family circuses could be forced into unusual financial circumstances because of a lack of consultation at an early date prior to the visit by the Moscow Circus. I hope, like many others, that I will be able to visit this wonderful circus, the Moscow Circus. However, I hope that its visit will not have any detrimental effect on existing circuses in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last parliamentary recess it was my pleasure to be part of a parliamentary delegation to Canada. I wish to give a short report on that visit. Canadian parliamentarians have made two visits to Australia, the last being when they came to present the Speaker's chair for the House of Representatives in our new Parliament House. A report from the High Commissioner's office in Ottawa stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The visit to Canada of an Australian parliamentary delegation from November 1-12 was seen to be an unqualified success. The effort and generosity expended by the Canadian hosts ensured a smooth programme which allowed for an enhanced understanding of the range of issues currently dominating the Canadian political agenda.

The delegation comprised four members of the House of Representatives and me as the only senator and the only woman member of the delegation. The leader of the delegation was the Hon. Barry Cohen, the Labor member for Robertson in New South Wales, and the deputy leader was Mr James Porter, the Liberal member for Barker in South Australia. Mr John Mountford, the Labor member for Banks in New South Wales, Mr Warwick Smith, the Liberal member for Bass in Tasmania, and me, as the Senate representative-National Party, Queensland-were the other delegates. Despite our differing political opinions in the Australian Parliament, we worked together very harmoniously to represent Australia to our Canadian hosts.

The delegation had the opportunity to observe Canadian political processes at work in both the Federal and the provincial political arenas. The visit occasioned a fruitful exchange of views and experiences across a wide range of subjects. The most prominent topics were constitutional reform in Canada, the environment, native affairs, trade and economic policies, and budget issues.

Our visit commenced in British Columbia. We visited the seat of government in Victoria, the capital of that province, and met with members of the provincial parliament. We were informed that the British Columbia economy is in great shape, with a balanced budget. However, they felt that their most important issue was that of the environment and the problems cause by oil spills. Another important factor mentioned by the British Columbia politicians was their distance from the heart of Federal Government, in Ottawa. However, they would not be further from their national capital than our Western Australian members and senators are from Canberra, and I suppose the same would apply to our representatives from the Northern Territory and, indeed, north Queensland.

The delegation noticed many similarities between Australia and Canada, one of which is the vastness of our two countries. However, where ours in many places is dry and arid, Canada is in a cold region, with many parts of the land being frozen wastes, particularly in winter time. We saw plenty of snow when we visited Banff National Park during the first weekend of our visit, but as it was November, that was to be expected. The area of the Banff National Park is 22,000 square kilometres and there are 2,000 elk and 100 grizzly bears in the area. We saw plenty of elk but missed out on the grizzly bears; perhaps that was just as well. Tourism is worth $625m to the Province of Alberta, in which Banff National Park is situated.

Alberta Province is most anxious to see a different method of senator appointment. At present, Canadian senators are selected from all provinces by the Prime Minister after the provinces provide a list of names. Until recently, if one were fortunate enough to be selected as a senator in Canada, one could rest assured that one had a job for life. However, the age limit has now been brought back to 75 years-which, of course, in some cases might be a job for life. However, Alberta and some of the other provinces believe that senators should be elected and not selected. They talk about the EEE option: elected, equal, and effective. Alberta Province maintains that there should be an equal voice for all the provinces at the national level.

I told the Speaker's luncheon in Ottawa that in Australia our senators are elected on an equal, State basis, but that it is up to the electors of Australia to decide how effective they are. I guess we will know about that after the next election. In Canada equal representation seems to be a sticking point because of the maritime provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and particularly Prince Edward Island, which have small populations. Many people believe that it is hard to justify representation for these provinces being equal to that of the larger provinces of Quebec and Ontario. Perhaps we could apply that same system in Australia. Some people do. In fact, a member of our delegation said very strongly that he did not believe that the smaller States should have Senate representation which is equal to that of the larger States.

We spent three days in Ottawa meeting with Federal members and, whilst we were there, the House of Commons was sitting. We were able to sit in during Question Time and our leader was recognised by the Speaker and applauded. Members used to bang on their desks in the Canadian Parliament to signify approval of what had been said but, with the advent of television, applause to signify approval has taken over. `Hear, hear' seems to be the best sign of approval that we can muster in our Australian Parliament.

The proceedings of Parliament in Canada are televised for general viewing. The cost is $1.4m per year. All the sittings of the House of Commons are televised, not only Question Time. Television coverage is used to provide an electronic Hansard. However, I point out that the proceedings of the Canadian Senate are not televised. The Canadian Privileges Committee is looking at opening up the guidelines for television. It is looking at extending the televising of the work of committees-which is already televised within Parliament House-to general television. Members of the committees, of course, think this is a wonderful idea but the Cabinet Ministers are not quite so sure about the matter.

The participation of the delegation in a public meeting of the House of Commons Standing Committee on the Environment proved to be an almost textbook example of the useful exchange of information facilitated by such parliamentary visits. Members of the Committee evinced strong interest in Australian environmental protection strategies. Of particular note was the enthusiasm expressed by some members of the Committee for the Australian initiative on the protection of Antarctica. I mention also that quite a number of children from a nearby college had come in to listen to the public meeting of the House of Commons Committee on the Environment. I think it was probably quite a useful discussion from their point of view.

The delegation paid a visit to Quebec and also called on the Lieutenant Governor of the Province. He told us much of the history of the Province of Quebec, which was settled in 1608 by the French. Australia, of course, was settled some years after that. However, in 1759 General Wolfe and the English Army defeated the French General Montcalm and his men. However, the Lieutenant Governor pointed out that in 1812 the French and English combined to defeat the Americans, so Quebec remained part of the British possession of Canada.

There is a great debate going on at present in Quebec about the use of French as the main language, even to the extent of having all road signs in French only. Back in 1792 there was a debate about the language to be used in Quebec, as the people of French ancestry believed that French should be the language of the province. There is no doubt that Quebec is a very historical city, and province, and the Moech Lake accord at present being discussed by the Premiers of all the provinces is centred around the desire of the French to have their language recognised, but to still be an integral part of the country of Canada. The more objective English speaking Canadians have no objection to the French Canadians desiring to preserve their language, culture and identity, but urge that English speaking Canadians seek to defend and preserve their heritage.

The delegation also visited Toronto, the provincial capital of Ontario, a city of four million people. We called on the Lieutenant Governor of Ontario whose headquarters are in Parliament House. The proceedings of the Parliament of Ontario are also televised, so that people in the Province of Ontario can choose to view the Federal or the provincial parliaments on television-perhaps they choose neither. Cable channels take the television broadcasts and during the evening Question Time is replayed on various television channels.

One of the many discussions taking place in Canada is about a proposed goods and services tax. While I was there the Prime Minister, Mr Brian Mulroney, and the Premiers of all the provinces met in Ottawa for an economic conference. The Prime Minister has proposed that a 9 per cent goods and services tax be introduced in 1991. Apparently, the Premiers of the provinces do not like the Prime Minister's idea at all. A newspaper article stated that the Premiers, at least publicly, were opposed to this goods and services tax and to high interest rates. It sounds a bit like the debate in Australia at present. They urged the Government to get its own spending in order before taking it out of the pockets of Canadians.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds familiar.
—It does sound familiar, Senator Stone. The Canadian Prime Minister, of course, said that the Government was not making these difficult decisions out of zeal for accountancy. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Reducing the deficit is a means to an end. The end is to ensure that our children will have the same opportunities we enjoy-and better.

I think that a message like that should be sent to the Government that is in power in Canberra at present. It is obvious that in Canada there are monetary problems between the Federal and provincial governments-perhaps even worse than is the case in Australia. But it has 10 provinces and a territory, compared to Australia's six States and two Territories. The delegation had a very efficient secretary in the person of Miss Lindy Smith who will be preparing the official report of the delegation which it will be my pleasure to present to the Senate after it has been presented to the House of Representatives.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
