(3) That this Order have effect till 2.00 p.m. this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an omnibus Bill designed to correct deficiencies due to lack of foresight and sloppy drafting. It contains amendments to correct a major blunder in the drafting of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill which created the company known as AIDC Ltd. There is an amendment to the Bounty (Ships) Act, and minor amendments to the Designs Act and the Trade Marks Act, and amendments to some administrative provisions of the Patents Act.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting, in relation to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC), that this was the Government's first tentative step into privatisation. Senator Button, who regularly gives industry a serve for its failure to be sufficiently efficient, et cetera, and who was given a decent serve on the front page of the Australian today, and yesterday in the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reports, is responsible for this failure to be efficient in relation to the floating of AIDC Ltd. As a result of not getting it right, a prospectus was issued for the float of AIDC Ltd which, under the legislation that then existed, was wrong. This legislation attempts to correct that deficiency. The float has not been a success. The shares were placed at $2 each and since then their value has dropped to about $1.75 to $1.80.

What went wrong was that there was a most peculiar provision whereby there was the creation of what were called `non-transferring assets and liabilities'. The proposal was that although they would remain in the ownership of the Corporation-if I can call it that, as opposed to the new company-these assets and liabilities would be transferred to the subsidiary public company for tax purposes. In other words, the Corporation would continue to own the assets but they would be treated as assets of the new company for tax purposes. The only trouble was that it seems that the Government forgot about the tax Act and, as a result, what was proposed did not work.
The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who introduced this Bill into the House of Representatives, skated over this total blunder by saying:
It has now become apparent that the earlier amendments to the AIDC Act fell short of achieving the result.

That is a nice, euphemistically worded manner of excusing a blunder. The bungle did not end there. The Corporation's staff were transferred to AIDC Ltd, but not the powers of the Chief Executive or, indeed, the government guarantee. What is proposed is that while the subsidiary company-the public company, AIDC Ltd-is not guaranteed, the original corporation, the AIDC itself, will act as the borrowing vehicle for the company. The Government has decided to continue the Commonwealth guarantee of AIDC until 1 July 1994 to avoid uncertainty.

When one looks at that muck-up, one cannot help but realise why our policy to privatise the AIDC totally is the only way to go. Of course, the Government has gone through this nonsense because of the power of its back bench to prevent the Government implementing reasonable policies in this area. We had another example of that this week. The Government has clearly reached the stage where it is no longer making decisions to govern this country; it can only make decisions subject to the power of its own back bench, which has been given a veto right in certain areas.

As to the amendment to the Bounty (Ships) Act, this amendment will expand the maximum size limit of bountiable vessels from 10,000 gross construction tonnes to 20,000 gross construction tonnes. Once again, the Minister skated over the reason for this amendment. The Minister stated:

The reason for the proposed amendment is that conditions for shipbuilders have changed rapidly in the recent past with an improvement in the competitive position of local builders. There is now evidence that certain shipbuilders can be competitive in the international market in the size range of 15,000 gct to 20,000 gct with bounty at the rate of 15 per cent of construction costs.

That is another example of this Government trying to pick winners. The IAC, in its reports presented yesterday-which, as I say, gave Senator Button a decent serve-was quoted on the front page of today's Australian, as follows:
Positive assistance measures which have flourished under the Minister for Industry, Senator Button, should be thoroughly reviewed from an industry-wide perspective.

I ask the Government: Why is it raising the level to just 20,000 gross construction tonnes? I do not think there is much chance of an Australian shipbuilder building a ship larger than 20,000 gross construction tonnes, but if it has this bounty, why bother to put an upper limit on it? If some shipbuilder in Australia could manage to get a contract for a 25,000 or 30,000 gross construction tonnes vessel, is this Government saying that it would not give that company a bounty?' Of course it would. If it is prepared to give Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd a $36m grant, why would it not give a bounty to any company which could build a ship larger than 20,000 tonnes? It is nonsense to impose an upper limit. Once again, it demonstrates that this Government under Minister Button is involved in picking winners.

There are some minor amendments to the Designs Act and the Trade Marks Act. I will talk about one of those amendments in the committee stage, because I will move an amendment, which the Government accepts, in relation to the use of the words `Designs Office'. I will also ask the Government-I hope the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has been briefed-about the two matters raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which raised two concerns about the Designs Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to respond at this stage, other than to say that Senator Lewis will be moving-he has circulated it already-an amendment to clause 19 of the legislation. It is the intention of the Government to accept that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, clause 19, proposed subsection 11 (2), line 7, leave out `` `Designs Office' or''.

My amendment deletes the words `Designs Office' from subclause (2) of clause 11 of the Bill. The reason for the deletion is that, if this amendment were not carried, someone who placed on their office building or door the words, `Designs Office', would be committing a criminal offence. I can understand that the Government would object to someone having on their office door or building the words, `Office for registering designs'. That seems to me to be clearly an offence. But when the Government-or, I suspect, the draftsman-says, `People cannot have the words ``Designs Office'' on their doors', that is a case of trying to limit ordinary English usage to some special government purpose. Shipyards, architects' offices, engineering offices, fashion houses-all sorts of offices-could have an area designated as a designs office. It is my view that, under the legislation as it stands, they would be committing an offence.

The Government, of course, got its usual advice from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. It fascinates me that these people say, `Don't worry about that; no-one would prosecute someone for putting these words on the door of their office unless they were attempting to do something wrong in relation to the patents office'. Mr McKenzie, the Senior Assistant Parliamentary Counsel, has said:
In my opinion, the new section 11 would not prevent a person from describing an office where designs are produced within his or her factory or other business as a Designs Office.

He then says in effect that the person, in any event, if he or she were charged, would be able to bring forward a successful defence. I suggest to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and to the Government that that is not the way to go about enacting laws in this country. The Government should not create a situation where people who do something which is quite common and which in no way contains any criminal connotation commit a criminal offence under an Act of parliament. The only advice the Government can get is, `You don't need to worry about that because they probably wouldn't be prosecuted anyway. If they were prosecuted, they would have a defence that they could raise before the court'. I put it to the Committee that that is a most improper way of legislating in Australia. It is for that reason that I press my amendment to delete these words from the Bill.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Bolkus) read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:

I have only one additional comment to make-that is, to congratulate the growers of these legumes for having sufficient foresight to make a contribution towards research and development in their own industry and to use the Parliament to put through this sort of proposal which will ultimately be to their advantage.

DEBATE.TITLE: COURTS AND TRIBUNALS ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill principally amends the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976. The purpose of the amendments is to remove the control of the administration of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), the Federal Court and the Family Court from the Attorney-General's Department and make the Tribunal and the two courts responsible for their own administration, in much the same way as the High Court has been managing its own day-to-day affairs for some years. The Opposition supports the Bill as it will contribute to efficient resource management and flexibility in the administration of these bodies. We note that the President of the AAT and the chief judges of both courts support the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the provisions of the Bill the President of the Tribunal and the chief judges of the courts will be responsible for administration. They will have a wide range of powers in relation to the administration of their respective bodies, including the power to enter into contracts up to $250,000 in value without the Minister's consent. They will also be responsible for ensuring that proper records are kept. They will be assisted, in the case of the AAT and the Federal Court, by a registrar. In the Family Court the equivalent position will be that of chief executive officer, as the court already has registrars and deputy registrars who fulfil quasi-judicial functions. The registrars and the chief executive officer will have similar powers and duties except that the chief executive officer will not have functions or powers in relation to proceedings before the court.

The registrars and chief executive officer will be statutory officers appointed by the Governor-General. The equivalent positions are currently Public Service ones but it is felt that making them statutory officers will enhance the independent nature of the bodies. We concur with that view. The term of appointment will be five years. The registrars and the chief executive officer will have significant powers and duties, such as the power to engage consultants. In effect, they will have the same relationship with the staff of the court who remain Commonwealth public servants as the departmental secretary does with departmental staff. The senior and responsible nature of the job is underlined by several provisions in the Bill, for example, those which prevent these officeholders from engaging in outside paid employment without the consent of the Chief Judge or the President of the Tribunal, and those requiring the disclosure of pecuniary interests.

The question of financial accountability is addressed by the introduction of reporting requirements similar to those applying to the High Court under the High Court of Australia Act. The AAT and the courts will have to submit a report on the management of their administrative affairs and also financial statements which must have been inspected by the Auditor-General. The Attorney-General is to table the annual report in both Houses of Parliament. Estimates of proposed expenditure must be approved by the Minister and no expenditure is to be made except in accordance with the approved estimates.

The Bill also makes various consequential amendments such as an amendment to the Australian Security Intelligence Act so that the registrar of the AAT will be among the eligible classes of persons who can be appointed registrar of the Security Appeals Tribunal.

We welcome this Bill as a timely effort to improve the efficiency of the operations of the AAT, the Federal Court and the Family Court. Australians are becoming increasingly concerned about delays in the court process and the critical effect that these delays can have on the administration of justice, although I think it can fairly be said that delays in the State courts have more severely plagued the administration of justice than in Federal courts. This Bill is also timely in the sense that the Senate is currently inquiring into the costs of justice. It is becoming increasingly apparent that the courts are accessible only to the very rich and the very poor and are simply out of reach for the vast majority of ordinary Australians. It is to be hoped that the measures such as are contained in this Bill, with its emphasis on accountability and efficient management, will help to ameliorate the situation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.35 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WATERFRONT AND COASTAL SHIPPING INDUSTRIES: GOVERNMENT REFORM

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and I am sure that he will be surprised to learn that my question is about the Industries Assistance Commission's report on international trade in services. In particular, I refer to the report's findings that:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government's program for micro-economic reform will fail to achieve its potential while barriers and impediments to efficient performance in . . . domestic services industries-
and, of course, by domestic services industries it means such things as coastal shipping, ports, telecommunications, domestic aviation-
continue to impose a debilitating burden on the rest of the economy.

Recent government initiatives, when implemented, should make some progress towards improving competitiveness in the transport and communications industries, but these initiatives are too modest and too heavily influenced by the interests of management and employees within these industries.
I ask the Minister: Does the Government accept the IAC's findings? In particular, will the Government review its reform programs for the waterfront and coastal shipping in the light of the report?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has quoted from some passage in the IAC report on international trade in services and, of course, he has chosen the passage which says that the Government initiatives are too modest. One might put that another way by saying `too slow'. The first point I want to make is that this Government has taken initiatives which were never taken by conservative governments in their 27 years in government and the absence of any initiatives taken by conservative governments has led to vastly increased pressure for micro-economic reform at the present time. The fact that initiatives have been taken is very important. I concede the point that might well be made in a supplementary question that a country like Australia has to measure itself against competitive pressures generated by trading partners, and so on, and not measure itself solely against the past. If one measured oneselves solely against the past, when we had 27 years of Liberal government, we would be doomed. If we measured ourself solely against the past we would be absolutely doomed.
—Logically, what you are saying is that we would be doing very well.

—I know; we are doing very well politically compared with those 27 years to which I have referred. The Government's program of micro-economic reforms of the conventional kind will continue, and will continue in respect of both the waterfront and coastal shipping.
—Conventional and slow.

—No; conventional in the sense of the sort of micro-economic reform agenda which the IAC is talking about; that is, conventional micro-economic reform, a whole range of structural reforms which do not fall within this category and in relation to which the Government has taken steps in the past few years. So that program will continue, and the IAC is undoubtedly embarking on the task of giving governments a bit of a nudge. That is not a bad thing.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. From what the Minister has said, I take it that the answer to my question, about whether the Government will review its reform programs for the waterfront and coastal shipping in light of the report, is no.
—Senator Lewis can take that as being the case if he likes, but he would be wrong, because that is not what I said.
—You are not going to change your program; you are going to continue with your existing program.

—No, what I said was that the Government has put in reform proposals in respect of the waterfront and coastal shipping, which are the two areas that the honourable senator mentioned. I believe that the coastal shipping reforms are very significant; the waterfront reforms are perhaps less significant. But in so far as it takes time for these reforms to take place, the Government will be pushing hard for those reforms to be continued as quickly as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIVE SHEEP TRADE WITH SAUDI ARABIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources been drawn to an advertisement by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) in yesterday's Canberra Times condemning mortality rates amongst sheep involved in the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia? Is there any basis to the information about this trade as conveyed in the advertisement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that it gives me no joy to criticise an organisation as respected as the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. That organisation rightly enjoys a high level of public esteem. However, yesterday it placed an advertisement in the Canberra Times headed `Export Trade in Live Sheep Condemned'. The first error in the advertisement was to say that figures had been obtained from my office, with such figures being used to justify some of the copy set out later in the advertisement. The RSPCA did not obtain any information from my office, and there is no record of anyone from that organisation even making an inquiry about those figures. The second error in the advertisement is that it says that there is a 6.55 per cent death rate for sheep in the trade, relating to mortalities at sea only. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Transportation from farm to ship, loading and unloading deaths have not been included.
That statement by the RSPCA is also untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which branch of the RSPCA is this?

—I understand that it is not the national body but the Australian Capital Territory body; I was going to make that point in a minute. The voyage mortalities were less than 2 per cent. The actual figure was 1.87 per cent, not 6.55 per cent as alleged. That is at about or slightly below the average for voyage mortalities in this trade. Circumstances where a higher number of sheep than usual died arose because, after the rejection of the carriers, there was a need to discharge and to transit between various ports in the Persian Gulf. Because of that extended and longer period and the interference in the normally expected flow of trade, there was a higher death rate. I might say that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has advised, and maintains a requirement, that ships sailing to the Gulf with live sheep should carry with them extra water and feed in case there are any obstacles in unloading the sheep.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the reasons why the Government has suspended the trade to the Persian Gulf is our concern about the possibility of sheep dying and our having regard to the question of the natural protection of the rights of sheep. That is one of the key reasons why the Government moved early on to suspend the trade. It is regrettable that the RSPCA did not check with me, and it is regrettable that this appears to be the effort of just the local group. I understand that the national body of the RSPCA is involved in discussions with the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I hope those discussions produce a result which enables the issue to be cleared up, with the RSPCA's rightful and legitimate concerns about cruelty to animals protected. I think in this case there has been an oversimplification, an over-reaction, which does not reflect a great deal of credit on the people who presented the advertisement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Congress of Colombia, led by Senator Ancizar Lopez, the President of the Colombian Senate. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to yesterday's scathing condemnation by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) of the pace of micro-economic reform in the telecommunications arena. Does the Government agree that the areas of monopoly reserved services for Telecom Australia, particularly its infamous first phone monopoly, `appear to extend beyond those basic areas of service required to meet the social policy objective'? Does the Government agree with the IAC that `the extra cost of domestic telecommunications arising through its regulation will be built into the cost structure of virtually every Australian activity, both services and goods, whether internationally traded or not' and that `ultimately the competitiveness of virtually every Australian industry will be adversely affected'? In view of the dramatic urgency spelt out so clearly by the IAC, when will the Government stop pandering to the anti-competition forces in Caucus and release the study by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, which the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, in typical form, has been sitting on for almost three months?

—We have noted the IAC report and will bear its conclusions with such fortitude as we can command, as we have often had to do in the past. The IAC has drawn conclusions of various kinds about the pace of micro-economic reform. We are conscious of the need for that. In May 1988, when I was Minister, we made the most sweeping and comprehensive collections of reforms in the telecommunications industry that this country has seen. With Austel as an independent regulator coming into existence in recent months, we have the machinery through which there can be continued careful and assiduous attention paid on the basis of proper analytical inquiry to such further reform as proves to be justified in the future. The particular question of the study on community service obligations is under close current consideration by the Government and I have no doubt that Mr Willis will be making an appropriate statement in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister able to report on efforts being made by companies reporting to the Affirmative Action Agency on progress in considering provision of child-care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Giles for her question, which gives me the opportunity to comment on the great success with which the Affirmative Action Agency has been able to work with private sector companies over the last two years. It also gives me an opportunity to make some positive statements and to name companies in a positive light in this chamber. We know that there was publicity last week about those companies that had not complied. Of course, media attention was given to that negative aspect of the failure to meet the requirements of the affirmative action legislation. Today, I want to turn the argument around and to focus on and name companies that are making very good progress, particularly in relation to child-care. This matter is very topical and very much of interest to many, many Australians, men and women.

ANSWER.PARA: Twenty-one reports have been identified as having mentioned child-care and they fall loosely into four categories. First, there are reports which say that consultation on child-care has occurred and will continue or that research has been or will be conducted. These companies include the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Utah Minerals, Woodside Petroleum, Uncle Bens, Digital, Ansett Transport Industries, McCain Foods, Berrivale Orchards, Arthur Young, Peat Marwick Hungerfords, and the Capita Financial Group. Then there are companies which have done more extensive work in terms of examining the feasibility of setting up child-care facilities-that is, they are just on the brink of establishing their facilities-and this group includes Johnson and Johnson. I would like to take the time of the Senate to read the following comment from Johnson and Johnson's report:

In 1989 a report was completed on child-minding facilities for the company showing us the options open to us when moving in this direction. The result of the report was to establish a resource file for each of our sites, of the child-mining facilities available in the local area. During 1989 the Personnel Department at each site is required to look at the option of establishing a child-care facility either by ourselves or in partnership with other companies or community groups. The results of this survey will be included in our 1990 report.

Then there are companies, including Nippondenso and Northern Star Holdings, that have actually decided to set up a child-care centre. Finally, there are companies which mention that they have already set up child-care facilities. Those companies include Ford Australia and Lend Lease.

While the emphasis in relation to affirmative action implementation has been to focus on companies that have not complied, I think it is very important to take whatever opportunity we can to commend the overwhelming majority of companies that are doing so. Attitudes are changing and these companies are considering a whole range of options including, as I have identified here today, child-care. We look forward to more companies taking the lead from these companies that have shown the way.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED PULP MILL IN TEXAS, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to the trade journal Paper of November 1989, and I ask: Is it a fact that an Australian company, ANKAL Pty, is setting up a pulp mill for large scale fine paper production in Texas, United States of America, using fibre from a field crop called kenaf? I add parenthetically that kenaf is an African plant related to cotton, resembling bamboo or sugar cane. What process-kraft, thermomechanical or other-will this pulp mill use? Has ANKAL Pty had any form of assistance from the Australian Government or government instrumentalities? Will the Minister explain how it is that old growth native forests in Australia are threatened by the pulp industry and communities around Australia are threatened by the out-dated obnoxious kraft pulp process, while an Australian company operating in America leads the world in environmentally benign pulp production from an agricultural crop?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for drawing attention to the article in the trade journal Paper concerning the company called ANKAL Pty setting up a kenaf pulp mill in Texas. Since I have been Minister, numerous proposals to set up kenaf mills in Australia have floated by me. All of them, I am sure, were about the market potential of their product and all of them were only sure about one thing-that they would need substantial government assistance to set them up. I was aware that this company was looking at the possibility of setting up a mill in the United States. I was certainly not aware that any final decision had been made about that. The same company had looked at the possibility of establishing a facility in the Burdekin area of north Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sanders asked me what process the plant will use. The article to which he referred mentioned that the soda or soda anthraquinone process is to be used. I am unable to say any more than is stated in the article to which the honourable senator referred. With regard to the question about assistance from government, of course, I am unable to say whether this company has had any assistance from other government instrumentalities in any way, but it certainly has not had any from my portfolio. I make the point that Senator Sanders referred in his question to the fact that the Government is currently drawing up guidelines for bleached eucalypt kraft mills. These mills will provide an opportunity to add value to wood chips currently being exported. The kraft process was identified by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) as the appropriate technology for producing pulp from mature eucalypt chips. The guidelines, which will be coming before the Government soon, will be very stringent and, when the Government has considered them, an announcement will be made about them.

As far as the other aspects of the question are concerned regarding the company Ankal, I am unable to add any further information. In relation to its report on kraft mills, CSIRO has indicated that when efficiently operated they will result in no significant short term ecological impact, but that is a matter which can be discussed when the guidelines are brought down.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to various media reports about the establishment by the Australian Telecommunications Authority (Austel) of a register of people who do not want to continue to receive junk advertising. I note that in its report Junk Fax Austel calls on advertisers voluntarily to consult the register to avoid sending messages to those who do not want to receive them. If this measure is largely ignored by advertisers, is it the intention of the Government to legislate to make this practice an offence carrying penalties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The background to this matter is that, in view of the rising concern over the transmission of unsolicited facsimile material, Mrs Kelly requested Austel to undertake an investigation to determine the full extent of the problem and its implications. She announced the outcome of the investigation by Austel into junk fax-or unsolicited facsimile messages-on 26 November. That report concludes that the cost and inconvenience of junk fax is not a significant problem at this stage, but has the potential to develop into a real problem.

ANSWER.PARA: The report recommends that Austel establish and promote a voluntary register of persons not wishing to receive junk fax, that an advertiser should voluntarily consult that register with a view to avoiding sending messages to those who do not want to receive them and that advertisers using facsimiles be encouraged to voluntarily limit advertisements to one A4 size page, if necessary inviting the recipient to solicit further information. Further, it recommends that Austel monitor the incidence of junk fax and report by 15 November 1991 whether any, and if so what, further control is required.

The Government has accepted all these recommendations and has asked Austel to implement them as soon as possible. Both Austel and the Government expect that the majority of advertisers will comply with the requirement that they consult the register of persons not wishing to receive junk fax to avoid sending messages to people who do not wish to receive them. The Government will review the appropriateness of these controls when Austel reports to it again in November 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware that the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on government (non-tax) charges released yesterday finds that Queensland has achieved the most consistent productivity growth in its electricity generation industry during the period 1975-76 to 1987-88 among all the States, particularly in the period following the famous South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute, when the then Government of Queensland turned on the lights which the trade union associates of Mr Goss in that State had been trying to turn off? Is he further aware that the IAC attributes this superior performance largely to changes in management practices including, particularly, the level of manning at all levels of the industry, and the increasing use of contract labour to carry out repairs? Does the Government agree with this assessment by the IAC? What action is the Government taking to apply the lessons of this success in Queensland to a much greater use of contracting out and the introduction of voluntary employment agreements to its own authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am generally familiar with the report of the IAC on government (non-tax) charges in the sense that I have read a brief summary of it, but that brief summary has not taken me to the particular question of the South East Queensland Electricity Board. However, one thing that is certain is that if the productivity of the Queensland electricity board has improved-and one must welcome that-it stands out like a glowing beacon in that morass of government confusion and corruption which exists in Queensland. There is always an exception which proves the rule and perhaps the Queensland electricity board is the exception.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, I know that levels of investment in Queensland are lower than in any other State. Levels of investment in Queensland are lower than in any other State because people have to put something into a brown paper bag to get the approval of Government Ministers in order to make an appropriate investment in that State. The whole ethos of government in Queensland has been so low that people are prepared to put their money where their mouths are. The only people who have put their money there are those who have invested in the tourist industry on which even the Queensland Government of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and others could not put the sun out. That investment followed more from the weather conditions in Queensland than from the Government. If the Queensland Government has to have an obituary written about it, which it will have soon, there will be one chapter in that obituary-if the information in Senator Stone's question is correct-which says, `In spite of all these other chapters, the Government did well in this little area'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the Minister's rhetoric, can I ask him how he explains the fact that, in the last 12 months, Queensland has displayed the fastest rate of job growth in any State in the Commonwealth with, in the last financial year, the rate of immigration into Queensland to take up these jobs amounting to 45,300 people, most of whom were fleeing Victoria and New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I do not believe what Senator Stone says is correct. I do not believe that Queensland has the highest record for job growth in the past 12 months. I think that is quite incorrect. Senator Stone will probably find that the highest record for job growth has occurred in South Australia, strangely enough. One must ask what that job growth means in terms of the base from which it is projected, even if it has taken place to some degree in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone also suggested that people are fleeing the harsh, tyrannical regimes which exist in New South Wales and Victoria, up to Queensland for a whiff of enlightenment and freedom under the National Party Government. I do not believe that is so at all. I believe the largest influx of people into Queensland comprises retirees-people going up there to retire for precisely the reason which I suggested in my earlier answer. They are going up there to retire in order to enjoy Queensland's sunshine and, hopefully, forget about the Queensland Government which will give them all nightmares.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator, Gordon Davidson, from South Australia. On behalf of all senators I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen media reports that Ethiopia is facing a disastrous drought placing millions of people under the threat of a catastrophic famine? Is the Minister also aware of the impact of various wars being fought between the Ethiopian Government and the independence forces in the Eritrea, Tigrey, Oguden and Oznol areas of Ethiopia? Can the Minister give details of what humanitarian food aid has been provided by Australia to alleviate the famine conditions in the general area of the Horn of Africa? Can the Minister explain what actions the Australian Government has taken to encourage an end to the fighting between the various forces in Ethiopia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past Australia has played a major role in trying to assist with the catastrophic famine conditions that have existed in Ethiopia, contributing not only very large sums of money and aid in the mid-1980s, but also in a bad drought year two years ago more than $13m. We have been examining the situation and trying to work out what will be required and what we might be able to contribute in the next year to alleviate the situation that is emerging, again in a rather horrific and tragic way. The reports that have emerged recently from the World Food Program and other sources suggest that in the northern provinces of Ethiopia up to four million people will be affected by total or partial failures of their harvests as a result of drought and that the food aid volume requirements will be about 500,000 tonnes.

ANSWER.PARA: The provinces of Eritrea, where approximately one and a half million people are affected, and Tigre, where it is likely that approximately 2.2 million people will be affected, are the worst hit. Of course, they are the provinces where civil war is effectively being waged at the moment and where the existence of that war, and as a result the inability or unwillingness of the Government of Ethiopia to assist in food distribution programs and delivery in that area, will make things very much more complex and difficult than they might otherwise be.

An Australian team from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has very recently visited the region. In the course of this visit, they examined the most effective means of responding to the situation. I hope that it will be possible for us to make an early decision on the provision of Australian assistance in the light of this examination. In the context of the problems in Eritrea and Tigre, the Australian position has been one of support for a negotiated settlement of those internal conflicts.

We believe that the negotiating processes that have now commenced, particularly in relation to Eritrea, represent positive developments. Regrettably, at the moment the situation in Tigre is much less optimistic, but it is hoped that a further meeting that will take place following one recently in Rome between the Government of Ethiopia and the Tigrean liberation movement will advance the prospects for a cease-fire. Although the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF) proposed at the recent Atlanta talks that Australia participate as an observer at future rounds of those talks, it now appears that the national observers will all be African. However, the Australian Government remains ready to consider carefully any proposal that may be agreed between the Government of Ethiopia and the EPLF for Australia to play a role in the peace process. However, I emphasise that we do not see this as an area of the globe where we have any kind of major diplomatic role to play. Our major responsibility, in common with other civilised and richer nations around the world, is to contribute as best we can to the very distressing drought and famine situation that is now emerging.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of prolonged heavy rains, which in recent days have bogged down and isolated scores of properties and settlements in Queensland's western areas and which will disrupt the process of people in these areas voting in Saturday's election, will he seek the Commonwealth's cooperation to make Commonwealth aircraft available to Queensland's Justice Department and Electoral Office to ensure that votes from these isolated people are picked up and recorded?

—Earlier in the week Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question designed, I apprehend, to influence the result of the election in Queensland. This question today is designed to influence the alibi that will be available to the National Party on Monday after the election is over. I do not know of any circumstances when the Commonwealth has ever involved itself by the means that Senator Bjelke-Petersen suggests in an election in a State when an act of God-to use insurance policy terminology-such as heavy rainfalls and so on, has intervened. Senator Ray is more of an historical expert on that than I. I think it is very unlikely that it has ever happened before. I will try to obtain an answer to her question, although I think it is unlikely that she will get any comfort from the Commonwealth. It is up to the Queensland electoral commissioner to make appropriate arrangements for the conduct of the election in Queensland, and I am sure he will.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to my previous questions regarding the standardisation of the Adelaide to Melbourne railway line. What is the progress of the latest Australian National Railways Commission's study into the conversion of this important intercapital rail link to standard railway gauge? Is a complete financial evaluation of the project now available? If so, what are the latest cost estimates for the conversion to standard gauge, which would be the conversion of the last remaining intercapital rail link in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Ray just remarked to me, `Hold the front page for this one'. I very much appreciate Senator Maguire's ongoing interest in the matter of the standardisation of the Melbourne to Adelaide rail link, an interest that I think it would be fair to say he has demonstrated in this place on innumerable occasions. In addition to being of non-standard gauge, the Melbourne to Adelaide rail link suffers severe curvature, gradient and clearance problems which make it seriously uncompetitive with the freeway-standard road link between the two cities. The standardisation project appears to have merit and studies indicate that the project could offer positive economic returns. Australian National (AN) has now completed an engineering feasibility and costing study of an alternative alignment which would overcome these problems. The cost of this upgraded and standardised link has been estimated at $516m in June 1989 values. There are no immediate plans to commence the project. However, AN is installing a small number of gauge-convertible concrete sleepers in the section of the Melbourne-Adelaide railway east of Tailem Bend.

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics is also assessing the major interstate corridors with the aim of identifying the right mix of infrastructure development and investment requirements as part of the Federal Government's approach to integrated land transport development. The Government recently announced that it would join with the States, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the private sector in carrying out a feasibility study into the establishment of a national rail freight organisation which, if established, will manage intersystem operations and make commercial judgments about investment requirements. The Railway Industry Council is also due to report shortly on its views and measures required for improving the performance of our national rail network. Senator Maguire can accordingly remain assured that corridor developments such as this are matters of very considerable interest to the Federal Government and areas in which we are very actively engaged in finding effective and economically valuable solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of the media reports this morning from independent sources that Federal Government inaction-the media reports describe it as `the Federal Government dragging its feet'-is placing the Cape York space port proposal under threat? Can the Minister say why the Federal Government is apparently setting out to sabotage this project in Queensland? Is there any connection between the Federal Government's apparent lack of action or support for this important national project in Queensland and the fact that there is a State election in Queensland on Saturday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no connection at all. Firstly, I should say that the Cape York space port-I must attribute the first political support for the Cape York space port to Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-was seen by the Queensland government of the day as a very simple matter which involved getting investors together to develop a commercial space port. From the beginning the Commonwealth took the view that the project should be the subject of a feasibility study and the Queensland Government subsequently agreed with that view. However, earlier on, the Queensland Government had taken the view that the space port had nothing to do with the Commonwealth Government and that it could go its own way in developing it. Sadly, that view was incorrect and it was recognised as incorrect by Queensland Premier Ahern. I do not know what Premier Cooper's attitude to it is; I do not think he has pronounced on the space port at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: The development of a commercial space port at Cape York is a very complex issue because there are all sorts of powers exercised by the Commonwealth in relation to foreign affairs, the environment, treaty obligations, the use of space, defence powers and so on which have to be taken into account first of all in assessing whether the space port could appropriately go ahead. There is also the question of negotiations with foreign governments. For example, there would have to be negotiations with the Chinese Government, the Japanese Government, particularly the United States Government, and to some extent with space authorities in the Soviet Union, in order to establish the questions of viability and a range of other issues which are important to the international space community. These things have taken time. For example, they have not been resolved in the United States yet. There are still further negotiations to take place there before a final decision about the space port can be made.

It is a complex issue. There has been no dragging of feet by the Commonwealth in respect of this matter. As to the Federal Government inaction allegation, which the honourable senator says came from an independent source, I have a pretty good idea where it came from: the current Queensland Government is desperate to grab on to any issue in order to garner a little support for Saturday's election. I think I have answered the honourable senator's question. It is not a simple issue. It was approached simplistically by the Queensland Government initially. Under Premier Ahern I think a lot of progress was made, but Premier Ahern has sadly gone now and there is somebody else in this place. I do not think much progress has been made since then, but the Commonwealth has not been dragging its feet as suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to the recently released report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies on sole parents' work histories. Can the Minister tell the Senate the key conclusions of the report and their implications for Government policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report that Senator Crowley refers to was commissioned by the Minister for Social Security as part of the Australian Institute of Family Studies evaluation of the child support scheme, stage one. The report demonstrates yet again the importance of a well researched and comprehensive approach to social policy formulation. We all know that has been made more necessary because we are talking about an area where prejudice and ignorance have often prevailed, especially in terms of some of the utterings from the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: It is an instructive and informative report. It analyses the circumstances of women who separated in 1981 and 1983 and tracks their circumstances over a period. Its key findings totally reject the policies based on prejudice and ignorance, which I mentioned earlier. Its usefulness is that it provides a basis for action for the future. In essence, its key findings are fourfold: firstly, paid work at the time of separation is a key to later economic self-efficiency; secondly, quite clearly, once in employment, sole mothers are more likely to remain in employment than other women; thirdly-this point should be taken heed of by those on the Opposition benches-only 8 per cent of those surveyed had not had any paid employment six years after separation; and, fourthly, the sole parent pension is an important bridge between separation and economic self-sufficiency.

The report is clearly an endorsement of the direction of well researched policies that have been adopted by this Government. We have developed and implemented policies that have done a number of things: firstly, they have assisted sole mothers to overcome barriers to work force participation, particularly through education, training, child-care and other support services. Secondly, we have helped balance caring for children and employment for sole parents. Thirdly, and most importantly, we have maintained the adequacy of the sole parent pension so that it can act as a bridge to self-sufficiency. The policies have been well targeted and they have been successful. I think the evidence speaks very much for itself.

It is illustrative to note that, in 1979, 43.4 per cent of sole mothers were employed. By 1983 this had fallen to 38.8 per cent. Under Labor, and with important programs such as the jobs, education and training programs, the proportion has now risen to 51.9 per cent. The proportion of those who relied also on the maximum rate pension in 1979 was 45 per cent. It is interesting to note that by early 1983 it had risen to 65 per cent and that in 1989 it is back to 45 per cent. These are two important indicators to show that well researched and targeted policies in this area are working. They are working because they have as their basis the criterion of adequacy. Those who rely on full pension and benefits have a guarantee of adequate support. In constant dollars, a sole parent with two children who received $196.50 in 1977 was receiving $182.80 in 1982. That same sole parent will now receive $205.50 in 1990 in constant dollar terms.

As I said at the outset, the report is a useful document as it does two things: firstly, it makes it very clear that the Government's policies of targeting and providing adequately for those people in real need are working; and, secondly, it rejects those policies, espoused quite often on the Opposition benches, that are based on prejudice and ignorance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to his response to my earlier supplementary question to him during which I made the claim that during the past 12 months Queensland had displayed the fastest rate of growth of employment of any State in Australia, to which the Minister responded, `I don't believe that'. Will the Minister now agree, in the light of the following figures, that he departed somewhat from his usual standards of courtesy in this matter when I tell him that the Statistics Weekly shows the following figures for the rate of growth of employed persons in the 12 months ended October of 1989: a rate of 6.6 per cent for Queensland, 5.6 per cent for Victoria, 3.2 per cent for New South Wales and also for South Australia-the state which the Minister claimed had the fastest rate of growth-4.3 per cent for Western Australia, and 5.6 per cent for Tasmania? I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
