TALK.START.PARA: —In light of those figures, will the Minister withdraw his previous comment and apologise for his departure from his own usual standards of courtesy in these matters?
—I would like to look at the figures which Senator Stone has quoted.
—That is churlish.

—Senator Chaney says that that is churlish but, as Senator Chaney well knows, when we talk about productivity, employment or anything else, there are plenty of different figures to look at. I will look at the figures and give Senator Stone an appropriate answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: Did he see a recent Australian Financial Review news brief entitled `Aussat tracks trucks' in which it was reported that Aussat had just completed tests on technology which could lead to closer monitoring of the trucking industry? The satellite tracking technology apparently would enable operators to check the positions and speeds of vehicles anywhere in Australia. In the light of recent trucking accidents, and in a bid to make this country's roads safer, can the Minister inform the Senate of the viability of such a system? Will it be operational by the launch of the next generation of Aussat satellites in 1991?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I not only saw the article `Aussat tracks trucks', but I devoured it, as I do with all the media stories that bear in any way upon new technologies as they relate to my various previous portfolios.
—You must be busy.

—I am intensely involved in all this. All this comes straight out of mind without any assistance from my brief at all. I am aware of reports that Aussat is testing a satellite-based vehicle position determination system which will allow vehicle progress and speed to be assessed. The tests are part of a current evaluation by Aussat of its Mobilesat service, which is to be introduced in 1991-92 following the launch of its second generation of satellites. They are Australia's first land vehicle speed and position tests via satellite. The Inmarsat system, which will be used by Aussat from mid-1990 for early commencement of the Mobilesat service, is being used for the current exercise. Both the early entry service using Inmarsat and the full Mobilesat service will operate in conjunction with Navstar, which is a high precision United States navigational satellite system, to provide these speed and position determination services.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, mobile speed and position reporting will have many applications in a nation as vast as Australia. Within two years organisations such as emergency services and trucking fleet operators will be able to manage vehicle movements effectively over a wide area and to monitor arrival times, departures and progress between centres, regardless of location. Again, the movement of a high value and hazardous cargo can also be managed on a real time basis from the depot with drivers being advised en route of any changes. While services will be able to report on speed, I should say that Aussat's Mobilesat is not primarily designed for this purpose; it is a management tool for businesses in the transport industry. All in all, Mobilesat is a fascinating development which is likely to have some very useful applications in the road transport industry of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows the two questions asked of him by Senator Stone about the employment record in Queensland. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that Senator Stone handed him a copy of Statistics Weekly, which is published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics? Does that document show that, according to the figures that have been updated to November this year, the highest rate of growth in the number of employed persons is in the State of Queensland? Why is the Minister not prepared to admit that simple fact? Is it simply that he does not wish to give the Queensland Government credit for anything in a pre-election situation?

—That is very unfair of Senator Chaney. Twice during Question Time today I made substantial concessions to the Queensland Government: one about the productivity in the electricity authority and another about Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's wrong-headed espousing of the spaceport at the stage of which he did.
—Wrong-headed? Are you against the spaceport?

—No; it was wrong-headed in the way in which it was done. The Commonwealth Government, by virtue of the decisions made by the Queensland Government of the day, was excluded from any consideration in respect of the spaceport, which was absolutely silly.
—You are being churlish. You are an absolute churl.

—No, I am not being at all churlish. I have been generous in spirit. I just make the point that, in all these debates, two heads are better than one, particularly when one of them is Senator Stone's. I think I have been very fair in what I have said about the Queensland Government. These figures certainly show, in aggregate, an improved employment situation in Queensland during the last year.
—The most rapid rate of growth of employment in the Commonwealth. All those retired people you talk about going to Queensland are getting jobs.

—It was not an invalid allegation that I made about retired people-not at all. But the Queensland figures start from a very low base and they do not show whether these people are full time employees, part time employees or what.
—They do.

—They do not. If the honourable senator wants me to go through all the other indicators in this document I will be happy to read them to the Senate, because they show that Queensland has been badly misgoverned.
—Why don't you just admit that you are wrong and sit down?
—The honourable senator is now telling me to sit down, for goodness sake.
—I just said, admit that you are wrong and sit down.

—No. People cast aspersions and throw stones in this place, but that is the most dreadful thing that has ever been said to me at Question Time. I concede the honourable senator's point about the aggregate employment figures, from whatever base, in this document, but that is all.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Resources, refers to Federal funding for the Murray-Darling Basin natural resources management strategy. Has the Minister seen reports of complaints by the Murray Valley League that the Commonwealth plans to reduce its funding for this strategy? Do these complaints have any basis in fact?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have any basis in fact at all, which is the galling aspect of the matter. A report which appeared in yesterday's News headed `Hawke fails Murray plan' gave a quotation from a Mr Camac, who is styled as the President of the Murray Valley League. Nothing is further from the truth. I am at an absolute loss to know how anyone heading an organisation of this sort could have had any basis for making such an allegation. Since the Prime Minister's environment statement in July this year, more Commonwealth funds have been available for natural resource issues in Australia than ever before and, given that the Murray-Darling Basin is one of the areas of greatest need, more funds have been attracted to that region than ever before. So the circumstances are indeed surprising.

ANSWER.PARA: Something else that annoys me is that reporters would actually report a story such as this without even seeking any verification of the allegation from the Commonwealth. We are at least entitled to respond. No effort was made to get a response from us, or from the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, which would equally have scotched this sort of allegation. Instead a newspaper report appeared.

The Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council met in April this year. Under the natural resources management strategy to address degradation in the basin, an indicative three-year budget of $45.2m was drawn up. Ministers then sought agreement to that budget from their respective governments. The Commonwealth Government, through the environment statement, put down a major package of initiatives in July which addressed many aspects of land and water degradation in the Murray-Darling Basin and, on top of that, in this year's Budget specifically allocated other funds as well.

We are allocating $49m over the next two years as part of a national soil conservation program. Should the Murray-Darling Basin attract the same percentage of our total fund allocation as it has in the past when those funds are disbursed, it will get an additional $20m that it did not actually count on. As part of a broadly based package, the Commonwealth has agreed to provide additional funds to the natural resource management strategy for the Murray-Darling Basin amounting to $3m in 1989-90 and $5m in 1990-91. The sum of $12.6m will be supplied for 1989-90 as well under the salinity and drainage strategy-an amount contributed to by the Commonwealth and the States. Decisions for 1991-92 have not yet been taken but Senator Richardson and I have sought triennial funding for the natural resource management strategy for the Murray-Darling Basin.

I conclude by saying that any suggestion that we are cutting back our support for activities in the area is unfounded; the obverse is true. In fact, we have allocated more funds than ever before under a myriad of newer programs better targeted specifically to deal with the natural resource problems of the basin.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to his answer yesterday to a question from Senator Crowley in which he sought to make a point of the fact that the Opposition has had a number of spokespersons on health. Is the fact that our health system remains in such a state of disrepair an indication that Dr Blewett, who has been unable to repair the damage, wants out of that portfolio but, as Labor does not have many people interested or capable in this area, he remains locked into a portfolio that no-one else really wants?
—Have a look at them. They all want it.

—Just for the record, I acknowledge Senator Richardson's interjection in case his point has escaped the notice of someone as dense as Senator Vanstone. He said, `Have a look at the back bench; they all want it'. Perhaps I should start where I intended to rather than worry about the interjections. It is galling to me that this question should be asked as the time allotted for Question Time is about to expire. I therefore do not have time to answer it as comprehensively as I would ordinarily like to. Senator Vanstone has emphasised that her Party has come up with seven different policies and five different shadow Ministers in the period of our Government compared with our one Minister for Community Services and Health, who is regarded in the health community not only in Australia but also internationally as an outstanding Minister.
—As a joke, Senator Cook.

—As an outstanding Minister. The honourable senator is a joke if he persists with that interjection. The most significant social reform in health in the history of this country since Federation was brought into being by Dr Blewett when he introduced the new Medicare reforms. That Medicare is an essential reform remains a matter of opinion not just of the Government but, according to the latest survey, of some 75 per cent of the Australian community. Senator Vanstone obviously read a magazine that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday in which Dr Blewett may have indicated-or it was indicated on his behalf-that he has been a long time in the portfolio. So has the Prime Minister been a long time in his portfolio. The Treasurer also has been a long time in his. And we all expect to have a lot longer time in ours as well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Given that the Minister is of the view that there are a number of people interested and capable other than Dr Blewett within the Labor ranks, I ask whether he would care to explain an article in the Australian Financial Review in October 1988-not last weekend-which is headed `Blewett wants a change' in which Dr Blewett is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: None of my colleagues seem to be greatly interested in health and community services, so I . . . haven't feared any competition.
What is the story? Is he lying or is the Minister out of touch?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what Dr Blewett was referring to was the fact that the quality of the Opposition is not sufficient to stretch his intellectual capabilities. If only the Opposition would lift its game it would provide a bit more stimulation and challenge in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twenty-third report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In its consideration of the papers presented to the Parliament, the Committee has noted an increasing trend among departments and authorities to ignore mandatory production standards as set out in the Commonwealth Printing and Publishing Manual. In some cases it would appear that the primary purpose of preparing a report for the scrutiny of the Parliament is being overshadowed by a perceived need to produce an elaborate and expensive self-promotional document. The Committee is concerned with this trend and intends to continue to monitor this situation closely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the report of the Committee entitled Engagement of External Consultants by Commonwealth Departments.
—by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report presents the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the engagement of external consultants by Commonwealth departments. As a result of adverse comments made by the Auditor-General in relation to several instances of poor management of external consultancies by some departments, the Committee resolved to investigate whether the processes involved in the selection, monitoring and assessment of the cost-effectiveness of consultants were adequate and accountable.

Overall, the evidence taken by the Committee has revealed that the situation with respect to consultants is confused and inconsistent across the public sector. One particular concern of the Committee is that, although service-wide guidelines for the engagement of consultants have been available for some time, scant attention has been paid to them.

The Committee does not have an obsession with detailed adherence to a set of guidelines in the form of a manual of procedure. Certain aspects of the guidelines for the engagement of consultants, however, ought to be mandatory in the sense that if they are not followed poor management practices are likely to lead to waste of public moneys and failure to achieve desired results from the use of consultants.

The fact that such an obvious principle as evaluation is not mandatory-as admitted by the Department of Administrative Services-makes an absolute mockery of them. Surely a major objective must be the development and implementation of monitoring and accountability mechanisms both for departments' own purposes and to assure the public that funds were not being wasted.

The Committee found, however, that there are no consistent mechanisms in place which ensure accountability for the use of consultants. While on the one hand consultants are regarded as merely another input to a program, on the other hand, little progress has been made on the development of performance indicators to assess the cost-effectiveness of the inclusion of the services of consultants in government programs.

Moreover, the Committee found that there are no procedures in place to ensure that consultants who perform poorly in one department will not be engaged by another. We have recommended, therefore, that post-performance reviews be required for consultancies.

There are other aspects of the guidelines that ought also to be complied with as a matter of course including compliance with any legal requirement. The fact that the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories admitted that the law had not been complied with in respect of the former Finance Regulation 52aa (2)-which exempted certain kinds of supplies from the requirement to go to tender-was of concern to the Committee. Evidence was given that this practice had continued for 15 years.

The nature of consultancies varies considerably from major long term contracts such as environmental impact studies costing millions of dollars to short term engagements which address, for example, issues of occupational health or skills enhancement. The Committee recognises, therefore, that different methods of procurement may be justified. However, notwithstanding the differences of magnitude of engagements nor the variety of procurement procedures, the Committee is concerned to ensure that the use of consultants by Commonwealth departments is at all times accountable.

Recognising that situations will continue to arise in which skills required are not available within a particular department or agency, the Committee sees merit in developing a public sector management consultancy within the Public Service. Specifically, the Committee considers that there would be value in expanding The Development Consultants, an agency within the Pubic Service Commission specialising in human resource development issues, into a broad-ranging management consultancy bureau, along the lines of the Canadian Bureau of Management Consultancy.
The Committee has also recommended that consultancy units be established to assist in the selection of specialist consultants from outside the Public Service.

The issue of pubic servants leaving the Service to join or establish consultancies was raised during the course of the inquiry. These situations are colloquially referred to as the `revolving door' and `Friday-to-Monday' syndromes. There is no legislation in place, however, which prevents a Public Service employee from resigning a position only to return as a consultant to do precisely the same tasks at a significantly higher fee. The Committee has recommended that the Public Service Commission review issues concerning post-separation employment, with a view to introducing legislation should this be warranted.

Since this inquiry was commenced in April 1988 major changes have been promulgated in the sphere of Commonwealth purchasing procedures and practices which have implications for the engagement of consultants. The Committee notes that the reforms are in part dependent for their success on a high level of visibility and provision of public information on government contracts and therefore stresses the importance of the Committee's recommendations in this regard.

Finally, I must emphasise that neither the Joint Committee of Public Accounts nor the Auditor-General has ongoing responsibility for monitoring the use of consultants and ensuring accountability and probity. The resources necessary to do this are clearly not available. It is the responsibility of program managers and the departmental organisation to ensure visibility, probity, accountability and the effective use of consultants.

I wish to thank all members of the Committee and the vast number of people who have provided us with both written and oral evidence. I thank the staff who, under considerable difficulties, especially in the last stages of the report, gave us an enormous amount of time and effort in order to get the report tabled by the end of this session. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —These reports have been produced by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for tabling before the end of the House of Representatives session in order that they may be before the Parliament. There are two things that are important to say about this report on consultants. The first is that it in no way looked at consultants as used by Ministers. We looked only at consultants as used by departments. It is important to point out that the cost of consultants to ministerial staff is in the vicinity, I believe, of $2m. It is also interesting to note that many former members of parliament are used as consultants in Ministers' offices.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that is important to make is that the task of gathering hard evidence as to abuses of the system was difficult for the Committee. Indeed, the concrete evidence that was furnished by way of a consultant being a Friday to, in fact, Tuesday case-the example of Dr Thistlewaite is used in the report was gathered in the Estimates committees where there was an opportunity to set out the particulars of this consultant who had been a public servant with the Parliamentary Information Systems Office and with whom I dealt with in the report of Estimates Committee A to the Parliament following the Committee's hearings and the bringing down of the Budget.

The question of consultants and how they are properly to be dealt with in accordance with the guidelines is a particularly perplexing one, as there is no hard and fast rule, as perhaps the United States has with regard to its Defense Department, where somebody who has been a public service employee is prohibited by law for two years from becoming a consultant.

The other interesting fact that turned up in information supplied by way of questions in Estimates was that one firm which supplies a lot of consultants to various government departments had, in fact, supplied 13 consultants to one particular department who were former public servants. It is useful for us to know the particulars and background of those public servants and to know whether or not their becoming consultants is a bona fide exercise or whether indeed it is simply a device to up their salary, as happened in the case of Dr Thistlewaite, who went from being on $46,000 to receiving $101,000 in an eleven-month period.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Joint Committee on Publications I present a report entitled Distribution of Bound Volumes of Hansard, together with copies of submissions and minutes of proceedings. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
In May this year the Presiding Officers requested the Joint Committee on Publications to review the distribution arrangements for bound volumes of Hansard.

Currently 619 sets of the Hansard of each House are bound and distributed, and in the last financial year this cost the Parliament in excess of $460 000. The Committee considers that the distribution arrangements for the weekly Hansard adequately meet the goal of disseminating Parliamentary debates to interested persons, and therefore an extensive free distribution of bound volumes is not warranted.
Accordingly, the Committee recommends among other things that:
Members and Senators be entitled to receive only bound volumes of the House in which they have served, covering their period in office;
Eligibility to be placed on the free distribution list be similar to that for the bound volumes of Parliamentary Papers; and
Subscriptions be raised to a level which acknowledges the cost of production and distribution.

Implementation of the Committee's recommendations would reduce the annual cost to the Parliament by $260 000. Additionally, the Committee expects that further savings are achievable should the Parliamentary Departments rationalise their requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In accordance with provisions of the National Crime Authority Act 1984, I present the third report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has the duty under section 55 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to monitor and to review the performance by the National Crime Authority of its functions and to report to both houses of the Parliament on any matter connected with the performance of the authority's functions to which, in the opinion of the committee, the attention of the Parliament should be directed.

The committee fulfils its monitoring and reviewing function by keeping a watch on what the authority is doing and examining suggestions that the authority has not been performing its statutory functions or that it has abused its powers. At the committee's regular meetings with the authority the committee is briefed on matters such as the authority's staff and resources, legislative and other constraints impacting upon the authority's ability to perform its functions effectively, the authority's relations with other agencies, its strategic planning and procedures, completed investigations and operations which have entered the public domain. The committee is not, however, briefed on matters which the authority considers to be operationally sensitive.

The committee's regular meetings with the authority also provide a forum for the committee to raise with the authority matters of concern in relation to the authority's performance of its functions, thus the committee has sought explanations in relation to prosecutions arising out of the authority's investigations which have failed at the committal stage of proceedings, allegations of interference in the authority's operations by politicians or officers of other law enforcement agencies and suggestions of inadequacies in the authority's arrangements for the protection of witnesses. In addition to the oral briefing provided at its regular meetings with the authority, the committee also receives written briefing material from the authority including detailed briefs of each of the authority's investigations. The committee has also sought and received from the authority specific documents to supplement material provided by way of oral briefing and explanation.

The committee has presented two previous reports to the Parliament pursuant to its monitoring and reviewing function, the first report in November 1985 and the second report in November 1986. In May 1988 the committee tabled a report entitled The National Crime Authority-An Initial Evaluation in which it supported the passage of legislation repealing the `sunset clause' in the National Crime Authority Act 1984 which would otherwise have resulted in the authority ceasing to exist on 30 June 1989. However the committee considered that it was only possible to make an initial evaluation of the authority's performance at that time since many of the authority's investigations were not completed and legal proceedings were before the courts or pending in a number of matters arising out of the authority's investigations.

The Committee therefore recommended that a more comprehensive evaluation of the authority's work, and of the success of the law enforcement strategy underpinning the establishment of the authority, be undertaken after the authority had been in existence for seven years. That recommendation did not mean, however, that the committee did not intend to continue to fulfil its duty of monitoring and reviewing the performance by the authority of its functions in the meanwhile and it is pursuant to that duty that the committee presents this, its third report to the Parliament. Its purpose is to report on matters connected with the authority's performance of its functions during the period since the committee presented its second report and, in particular, to report on the committee's examination of some of the authority's investigations which may have given rise to public concern that the authority was not performing its functions properly.

The report examines in some detail two of five cases arising out of investigations by the authority which failed at the committal stage and proceedings in the course of the past year. The Committee had intended to deal with all five of the cases but three of them remain before the courts. The Committee is satisfied that the authority took action in the two cases dealt with in the report only after careful investigation and after receiving advice from counsel that prima facie cases against the accused existed. The authority cannot be blamed for the fact that other factors, such as new evidence, arose which resulted in the charges being dismissed or withdrawn. The committee is confident that the authority carried out its statutory responsibilities correctly in assembling admissible evidence in relation to these matters and in forwarding that evidence to the responsible prosecuting agencies.

The report touches on a number of other matters, including the need for the authority to be sensitive to the demands it places on individual witnesses appearing before it, the costs of the present system for Telecommunications interception and the authority's resources. It also contains detailed statistics on the authority's investigations, bringing up to date similar tables which appeared in the Committee's initial evaluation report.

The period covered by the report saw the end of Mr Justice Stewart's term as the chairman of the authority and it is appropriate to remark that, as the foundation chairman of the authority, Mr Justice Stewart deserves much of the credit for establishing as a working reality what was a unique and novel concept in law enforcement. This comment is not intended to discount the very significant contribution made by the other members of the authority over the past five years nor the dedication and hard work of the many members of staff who have helped over that time to build the reputation of the authority as an effective element of this country's law enforcement machinery. However nobody can deny that the authority in its first five years bore the stamp of Mr Justice Stewart's personality nor that in significant respects it reflected his experience as a Royal Commissioner inquiring into the `Mr Asia' Drug Syndicate, the Nugan Hand Bank and the illegal interception of telephone calls by the New South Wales police.

The task that Mr Justice Stewart was set as the foundation chairman of the authority was a difficult one. Not only was he required to build a new agency the very existence of which was fiercely resented by many within the existing law enforcement structure of the country but the legislation also contained a `Sunset Clause' which would have resulted in the authority ceasing to exist after a period of five years unless the Parliament passed a further law to the contrary. The authority was thus under pressure to prove itself and to do so quickly even though the investigation of organised crime is a lengthy process and it takes even longer for the result of investigations to be processed by our Criminal Justice System. As the Committee commented in its initial evaluation, there was an expectation on the part of the Parliament in establishing the authority that it would get results: that it would put important or significant criminals behind bars. This the authority under Mr Justice Stewart did.

To mention but one investigation, the authority's operation ILIAD concerns the illegal importation and distribution of drugs, especially heroin, by persons of Chinese origin and their associates, and the financing of the importation and distribution of such drugs. The Australian Federal Police had initiated a similar investigation but had met with little success. At the time the investigation was taken over by the authority (at the request of the Australian Federal Police) some targets had been identified but no substantive police investigation of them had been undertaken. The authority's investigation has so far resulted in the charging of 93 people on a total of 198 charges. Sixty-seven prosecutions have been completed, resulting in 39 convictions and 15 deportations. The significance of this investigation is reflected in the amount of heroin seized-almost 60 kilograms-and the severity of the sentences imposed on those persons who have been convicted.

The measure of the authority's success lies not only in the number of convictions of significant criminals arising from its investigations but also in the fact that it is unlikely that many of these convictions would have occurred without the authority. Other agencies had already attempted investigations in some of the cases and had been unable to launch prosecutions, while in the case of former Chief Inspector Barry Moyse in South Australia, for example, it was acknowledged that the offences might not have been uncovered but for the intervention of the authority. Moreover in some areas it appears that the authority has not only broken new ground but that it has stimulated other law enforcement agencies to follow it. The committee understands that the authority was the first law enforcement agency in Australia to employ Chinese-speaking officers from Hong Kong to assist in the investigation of criminal activity among Chinese elements in Australia. Now the Australian Federal Police are also experiencing some success in this area in co-operation with the authorities in Hong Kong.

While the Committee considers that the complete change in the membership of the authority-apart from the member in charge of the Adelaide Office, Mr Le Grand-which took place in July 1989 was undesirable from the point of view of continuity in the authority's investigations, it has undoubtedly given the new chairman, Mr Peter Faris, QC, the opportunity to place his stamp on the authority in turn. The Committee looks forward to a continuation of the authority's record of success under its new chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —The third report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is a particularly important one because it is tabled at a time when there has been a sufficient opportunity to evaluate the work of the National Crime Authority (NCA). Clearly, the judgment on both sides of the Parliament has to be that the exercise has been a considerable success. Nonetheless, there have been attempts in the media, particularly in the Sydney Morning Herald from time to time, to suggest that somehow there is not a sufficient level of accountability and that the Committee and the National Crime Authority should be much more forthcoming. I think that approach betrays a misunderstanding of the very sensitive nature of the material and the heavy obligation imposed upon members of parliament to ensure that the discussions remain confidential and that they do not prejudice any law enforcement activities. It is a tribute to the members of the Committee on all sides of the House that confidentiality has been maintained. Considerable pressures are brought to bear from time to time. There are certainly demarcation disputes between various police forces and in many ways there are a number of people anxious to discredit the work of the NCA. Every time a prosecution fails, it is very quickly suggested that somehow it must have been a half-baked investigation or that it was the fault of the ineptitude of the NCA officers.

SPEECH.PARA: In my judgment, there has been an ongoing difficulty about the ultimate responsibility for the handling of prosecutions because the client is the NCA but the prosecuting authority is the Director of Public Prosecutions. There needs to be more acceptance of the involvement of the NCA in the course of the prosecutions so that it can be ultimately held responsible if there are shortcomings in the legal process. Generally speaking, the cases that we have examined where prosecutions have failed have not brought to light any serious evidence of incompetence. In most instances, there has been very strong justification for bringing the matters to court.

I welcome the appointment of Mr Justice Stewart's successor, Mr Peter Faris-someone I have known from the Victorian Bar for many years. I have every confidence that he will prove to be a very effective chairman. The circumstances of his appointment were, nonetheless, regrettable in that there was a series of leaks in the media-for which I think the Minister for Justice (Mr Tate) ought to be held primarily responsible-which led to enormous speculation about who Mr Justice Stewart's successor would be. There were various people to whom the job was supposedly offered. Ultimately, there was something a little short of a fiasco whereby it was reported that Mr Faris had been approached thinking he was being offered the top job when all he was being offered was membership of the Authority. The result of that particular episode was that there was a complete changeover of personnel and Mr Faris was ultimately offered the chairmanship, which he accepted. The end result has been a satisfactory one. But there was certainly a great deal of insensitivity and incompetence on the part of those responsible for the appointments in the early stages.

I commend the work of the National Crime Authority. It is doing its best under very difficult circumstances. It will continue to have a fair number of critics, most of whom have vested interests in discrediting its activities. At the end of the day, if parliamentarians take the work as seriously as they have to date, we will find that the body will have the resources and the legislative power to carry out its very important task. There is no doubt that the stakes are getting higher, especially in the drug arena. I am confident that the NCA will prove to be a very effective body in combating that very great number of diseases that seem to inflict not just the community but, indeed, sometimes the law enforcement agencies. I have pleasure in tabling the third report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The third report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, of which I am a member, is a useful report from a number of points of view. For example, the two appendices provide a great deal of information for those people who are interested in the operation of the Authority. Appendix I, for example, has a summary of the Authority's major successes and failures to date. Appendix II includes a whole range of statistics provided by the National Crime Authority to the Committee that give an idea of the scope and work that the Authority has necessarily had to undertake in its task of attempting to combat crime at a high level.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to canvass all the issues that are obviously dealt with in detail in the report; or even the dissent of Senator Cooney, who I understand will speak later. However, I wish to draw the Senate's attention to the section relating to the Authority's resources, because I believe it is particularly important that honourable senators have an understanding of this problem, especially at this time when we are debating the Budget. We must be mindful of the fact that the fight against crime is not cheap-it is a very expensive consumer of the community's resources. In order to enable the Authority to undertake its work properly, it may well be that, in the very short order, there will have to be significant augmentation of its budget. For example, if one wishes to have regard to an item on which the Committee has previously provided a report-our report on witness protection-this report states:

More recent discussions with the Authority concerning its resources have highlighted the problems the Authority is having with the very substantial costs of witness protection. The cost of protecting a single witness for a year can run as high as $900,000 . . .

That may seem a staggering amount but, depending on the value of the evidence that the witness might be able to give, that evidence could well be the linchpin in successful prosecutions of senior figures in various crime rackets in Australia. The report continues:

The Authority cannot predict with any certainty what demands will be made upon it for the protection of witnesses nor can it seriously contemplate saying to an important witness who walks through its doors: `No, we are sorry, we do not have the funds to pay for your protection. Try again in six month's time'.

In those circumstances, it is fairly obvious that the person who required the protection would not be around in six months time to apply for the protection. That is an area, in some ways open ended, that in the next financial year Parliament and the Government will have to come to grips with far more seriously than they have done to date.

This year's augmentation of the Authority's budget by $600,000 was necessary and desirable. However, in the situation I have just outlined, in which there is an attempt to get a supplementary budget of $600,000 while there may be a shortfall of $900,000 with regard to even one witness, the Government may be looking at amounts that are likely to fall far short of the mark. It may very well be that the Government, relying on what it believes to be the community's perception of the needs of the Authority so that it can carry out its task, does not believe that there needs to be a significant increase. If there is an increase, there will have to be decreases elsewhere or an increase in taxes. However, I believe that some wider community debate needs to be undertaken about the issue of the resources that go not only to the National Crime Authority but also to the Australian Federal Police, to the court systems, and to the other law enforcement agencies. It is not good enough simply to say that this or that ought to happen. The effectiveness of these organisations is not totally a function of the resources, but certainly sufficient funds need to be available for them to carry out even an adequate task and to do what seemingly the Authority is doing, at least from our reports to date, that is, to successfully disturb the structure of crime in Australia.

It is an element not sufficiently taken into account that these bodies exist not only to solve crimes that have been committed, but also, hopefully, to prevent crimes being committed. The destabilisation of criminal organisations is a vital element of the Authority's work. The value of that element will probably never be able to be gauged in terms of dollars and cents or even toted up in appendices of statistics, but I believe that ultimately it will be the most effective element of the Authority's work. Because of that fact, I believe that, in terms of any evaluation of the Authority, we must be very careful not to reduce our evaluation to a pure totting up of court success and failures. There must be a far broader and more understanding evaluation of the role and work of the Authority, of the successes that it has already achieved to date in destabilising the organised crime syndicates, and of its provision, along with several other authorities, of an intelligence base from which we are then able to wage a successful-hopefully, increasingly successful-fight against crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I begin what I hope to be a short speech by referring to a remark made by Senator Alston when he referred to the appointment of Peter Faris, QC, as Chairman of the National Crime Authority (NCA). He said that at that time there was considerable speculation as to who would be the Chairperson of the NCA. In fact, I think that one person was named in the newspapers and that caused some confusion at the time. All that was true. He then threw in the line that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was mainly liable for that situation. That is another unfortunate example of the extraordinary tendency of parliamentarians to cast aspersions using what appears to be a most flimsy basis. I do not know, and nor will the people who might read Hansard know, the basis for the honourable senator's statement. It is simply an aspersion cast on the character of a person who has the respect of both sides of the chamber, but he has been gratuitously demeaned by a throwaway statement. The reason, the evidence and basis for the statement have not been explained.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a dissenting voice in relation to the third report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I did not dissent on the basis that the National Crime Authority is not a worthy organisation-it is a commendable organisation which is led by a fine lawyer and an outstanding human being, Peter Faris. I also did not dissent because the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is not a good committee. Indeed, it is a good and conscientious committee which is very ably led by Mr Peter Cleeland, the member for McEwen. Rather, my dissent related to the fact that we must look at the nature of the Authority and of the report. The Authority is an investigative body clothed with powers which, up until this decade, would have been regarded as extraordinary. The Authority has-and will do so over the coming years-subjected many citizens to scrutiny, which until the 1980s would have been exceptional. The scrutiny is not confined to those suspected of crime but embraces people who the Authority considers might be able to give evidence implicating others. It can, for example, compel people to give evidence on oath and to produce documents which the ordinary policing authorities do not have the power to do.

The National Crime Authority is one of a quite amazing number of investigative bodies that have grown up during this decade. Mr Mark Weinberg, QC, made the following comments in a speech in August this year:

In recent years there has been an explosion of quasi-judicial bodies established by Governments to perform investigative tasks. To name but a few, there have been assorted Royal Commissions, sundry Special Prosecutors, the National Crime Authority, the National Companies and Securities Commission (now the Australian Securities Commission), the New South Wales State Drugs Crime Commission, the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption, its new Western Australian variant, the State Corporate Affairs Commissions, and the Commonwealth Special Investigations Unit. In addition to these permanent investigative bodies, one finds specific investigative units within such agencies as the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Customs Service, the Health Insurance Commission, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Trade Practices Commission, and at State levels, various Consumer Affairs Bureaux, Accident Compensation Commissions, and Coronial Inquests (some of which seem to have taken on the role of roving Commissions of Inquiry). Allegations of criminality have also been investigated by, among others, Parliamentary Commissions of Inquiry, Parliamentary Inquiries, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, and the Human Rights Commission.

In fact, the investigation of crime has very much become a growth industry in the 1980s. It is as though crime never existed in the past-which is quite wrong. The number of people throughout history who have been tortured, imprisoned and executed for crimes they have committed is clear evidence that crime is not new. As there has been a growth in the number of investigative bodies and the extraordinary powers given to them in the interests of a humane, just, democratic and free society, some balance must be struck. One of the ways that a balance can be struck is to allow some criticism of those authorities.

Surely a body as robust as the National Crime Authority should be able to withstand some criticism. A high proportion of the content of the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority-a hard-working, well led committee-is concerned with defending the National Crime Authority. It seems to me that a parliamentary committee should not readily rush to the large scale defence of some criticism of the Authority when that process might lead to the scotching of criticism which, when properly made, is a very useful tool in a democratic and free society. The Committee cannot scotch from its bosom all delinquency without searing those qualities it relies upon to remain a just and benign body.

That was the first view that I took. I now quickly want to touch on the second one. The report recommends that the Authority be given money to enable it to play a large part in who shall appear to prosecute cases that it has prepared. In my view, an investigative body should stay separate from the body that is going to prosecute the case that it puts together. In my dissent I quoted the following sentence which appears in the majority report:
If the Authority had in essence a right of veto over counsel it would be as well placed as it could expect to be if it prosecuted its own cases.

It is not for an investigative body, whether it be the police or one of these various bodies that Mr Weinberg has referred to, to prosecute. Those bodies are there to provide the evidence, and it is for the prosecutorial organ to prosecute, to choose what counsel will do the prosecuting and to present the case as it sees fit. For an investigative body to want to do more than investigate creates dangerous trends for a free and democratic society.

My last point of dissent was on the issue of who should carry out interception of telecommunications. That is presently in the keeping of the Australian Federal Police. I remember that when the Bill was being prepared it was a matter of high principle that the interception of telecommunications should be confined as much as possible and that any move from that position would be a dangerous one.

To sum up: I have high respect for the National Crime Authority and for the person heading it. However, like any body of its nature in the sort of society we want, it must be continually scrutinised. A committee such as a parliamentary committee should defend it when the criticism of it becomes unwarranted and of such a nature that somehow it is going to be dangerously prejudiced. However, the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is a monitor and a reviewer, should not rush in to become an advocate for the National Crime Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the report of the Committee entitled Review of the Finance Minute on Report 270-Implementation of the Offsets Program. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I present the 305th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts: Review of the Finance Minute on Report 270-Implementation of the Offsets Program. The Committee's report 270, presented in April 1987, found significant inadequacies in Australia's offsets program. That report made serious criticisms of the program and sought to encourage a general increase in the visibility of the program's administration.

The departments involved were urged to present the program as a single program, present an annual report to the responsible Minister and publish more information on outstanding obligations and acquittal plans. I might point out that at that stage I was not in the Parliament and have come to this inquiry subsequent to that report having been published.

Despite the production of the annual report only a partial cost-benefit analysis of the offsets program has ever been undertaken; there are still no proper notification procedures; no definitive procedures manual; no proper procedures to ensure objective valuation of offsets proposals; and no penalities for non-compliance with offsets agreements.

The Committee has made new recommendations which are intended to ensure consistency and equity in the application of the offsets policy amongst both overseas and local participants, to minimise administrative discretion in valuation procedures and particularly to open up the information process so as to improve the program's visibility and accountability.

Some work has been done to monitor the costs and benefits of the offsets program. The Bureau of Industry Economics has undertaken the first stage of a three-stage study. The major problem for the study was the lack of adequate information databases. The recommendations of the study call for additional database fields.

The Committee was perturbed to find that in some areas corrective action either has not been implemented or has not been completed, despite the fact that criticisms in those areas have been raised several times over the last few years by the Auditor-General in 1984, by the Inglis Committee of Review of Offsets also in 1984, and the Public Accounts Committee itself in a report tabled in April 1987. An example of this departmental failure is the continuing lack of a procedures manual for staff working on the program.

A further concern of the Committee goes to the very heart of the civil offsets program in that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce can still not be certain that it is aware of all Commonwealth purchases to which the offsets program applies. The Committee was further concerned about the apparent low level of awareness of senior officers of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce about industry policies of major comparable countries.
The Committee received a submission from the Department of Finance which stated:

it is questionable whether offsets, with their lack of transparency, uneven application and administrative overheads constitute an efficient instrument; industries deemed to be worthy of assistance could well be much better assisted by bounties (such as presently exists for the computer industry) or even tariffs.

The Committee believes it is regrettable that after nearly 20 years of operation of the program there is no clear evidence that the offsets program was achieving its policy objectives. The Committee has therefore called for an independent full scale assessment of the national significance of the offsets policy. In that regard, I think of interest is a report published in October 1989 concerning offsets in Australia. It has been researched and prepared by the United States and Foreign Commercial Service in Australia. At page 26 of that report, the observations are made and several conclusions drawn that I think are pertinent. The report states:

The Government market is extremely important in Australia and no company, domestic or foreign, can afford to ignore the Government sector in such a small market, which is so geographically isolated. Information technology companies earn on average between 20 and 40 per cent of their Australian revenue from sales to government.

There are two main perceptions of offsets that are of interest, and then a final conclusion is drawn that there is an amount of window-dressing and bean counting in the offsets program which has not been useful in assisting the objects of the program and has disadvantaged companies involved in it.

The Committee has produced detailed recommendations to address these concerns and I look forward to a thorough consideration of those recommendations and a response from the highest levels of the Department and the Government. In conclusion, I want to thank all members of the Committee who have worked on this report. In particular, I know that other members of the Committee would join me in thanking Julia van der Heide for her considerable efforts and professionalism in assisting the Committee with this report. I commend the report to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The documents read as follows-
REPORT 300
I present the 300th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Reports of the Auditor-General: March 1988, September 1988 and April 1989.

Members will be aware that the Public Accounts Committee has a duty to follow-up issues raised by the Auditor-General which have serious efficiency and effectiveness implications for the management of Commonwealth programs or policies.
Report 300 outlines the issues which have concerned the Auditor-General in his two reports of 1988 and his April 1989 report.
Arising out of an examination of these reports, the Committee will monitor developments in nine areas of Commonwealth administration. These areas are:
revenue leasing arrangements affecting Commonwealth property that is temporarily surplus to requirements
management of Aboriginal student assistance schemes
management of the Jobstart and Skillshare programs
administration of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
assignment of operating costs within offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service
administration of the Business Migration Program
effectiveness of fraud control measures in departments and agencies
the development of appropriate performance measures in cases where grants are made to States
asset management by the Department of Defence.
By listing these areas of ongoing concern, the Committee is alerting public service managers to likely future areas of inquiry.

While no formal inquiries into these subject areas are being undertaken by the Committee at the present time, the Committee's `watchdog' brief over public expenditure necessitates a broad overview of the full range of Government activity.
I commend the Report to the House.
REPORT 301
I present the 301st report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on `Finance Minutes'.
The Report contains 21 Finance Minutes covering a broad range of Commonwealth Government activities including:
computer acquisition by Government departments
administration of quarantine services
management of Commonwealth properties
administration of capital grants to non-government schools
management of Repatriation Hospitals
review of the Commonwealth's responsibilities in the area of therapeutic goods.
Members will be aware that Finance Minutes contain the formal response of Government departments and agencies to recommendations of the Committee.
The Committee believes that these Finance Minutes should be made available to Parliament and the public in order to facilitate discussion of the issues raised in the Committee's reports.

The process of accountability is assisted by early release of the Finance Minutes, and to this end the Committee has decided to table future Finance Minutes as soon as practicable after they are received by the Committee.
Because of the importance of the Finance Minute process, the Committee has recommended that in the future each Finance Minute be signed by the relevant departmental head.
Finance Minutes are an integral part of the Committee's activities and represent an essential step in the Committee's oversight of Government program administration.
I commend the Report to the House.
REPORT No. 303-SAFETY PRINCIPLES FOR EXPLOSIVES

On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 303rd Report of the Committee entitled Review of Auditor-General's Efficiency Audits-Department of Defence: Safety principles for explosives and RAAF explosive ordnance.

The Report presents the Committee's findings in respect of its Inquiry into the Department of Defence's administration of its procedures for the safe storage and handling of explosives. It reviews two efficiency audit reports by the Auditor-General on the matter.
In the first efficiency audit report, the Department of Defence: safety principles for explosives, the Committee was most concerned at a number of matters that arose.

As the Inquiry progressed it became obvious to the Committee that Defence's management of the implementation of the NATO Safety Principles left a great deal to be desired, with significant administrative weaknesses being found. Among the Committee's major findings were that:
The Department experienced great difficulty in complying with the NATO Safety Principles since the Department first adopted them in 1981;
The decision to adopt the Principles in 1981 was ill-conceived, in that there was little consideration of the costs, operational effects and legal liability that would be involved;
The level and extent of liaison with landholders and local councils around defence establishments containing stored explosives was less than satisfactory;

Although in 1983 the Department had adopted a policy of distributing to local councils safeguarding maps showing land that would be affected in the event of an accidental explosion, some six years later no maps had been distributed; and
The Department took more than two years to rewrite two instructions which the Auditor-General had extensively criticised.
``A major finding of the Auditor-General confirmed by the Committee was that successive Defence Ministers had not been fully briefed on important matters relevant to the NATO Safety Principles''.

``These instances began as early as 1981 when the Department failed to obtain the Minister's approval to adopt the Safety Principles, despite having received advice that such approval should be sought''.

``Further instances of failure to adequately brief Ministers were identified in subsequent years. The Committee concluded that the explanations offered by the Department of Defence for these failures were unacceptable''.

``The Committee was dismayed to find that after a mandatory Defence Instruction was issued requiring Ministerial approval for explosive operations that could not comply with the NATO Safety Principles and which involved some risk to the public should an accident occur, operations were allowed to continue without explicit Ministerial approval''.

``The committee took an extremely dim view of senior unelected officials of the Department of Defence making decisions to allow the non-compliant storage of explosives when, according to their own Departmental Instruction, such decisions should have been made by the Minister''.

``The Committee noted that all such instances now have the Minister's approval. The Committee has made recommendations designed to ensure that in the future the Minister's approval is sought in a much more timely manner.

The Committee considers the findings of this Report have ramifications for all departments in their relationships with the Executive. It should serve as a reminder to all departmental secretaries of the need to ensure that Ministers are adequately briefed and kept informed.

The Committee concluded that the management of the application of the NATO safety principles had been less than satisfactory since 1981. It noted that the revised Instruction on the safety principles for explosives had recently been issued after a long delay, as well as the recent decision to create the position of an Assistant Chief of Logistics to oversee its implementation. These measures, together with the recommendations contained in this Report, will, it is hoped, markedly improve the management of safety principles for explosives.

In relation to the second efficiency audit report, on RAAF explosive ordnance, the Committee was not able to fully examine many of the issues because the Department of Defence would not allow the Committee access to the restricted version of the report which was not tabled in Parliament.

The Committee is concerned that, where the Auditor-General is critical of matters of public administration that involve national security, the Parliament is being denied the opportunity to consider those issues under the current provisions of the Audit Act. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended in its Report procedures that will allow the Committee to consider future restricted reports of this nature.
I commend the Report to the House.
REPORT NO. 304-
GUIDELINES FOR DEPARTMENTAL ANNUAL REPORTS

During 1989 both the Public Accounts Committee and Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration completed inquiries into aspects of departmental annual reporting. Both committees found extensive non-compliance with the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports. The Senate Committee and some witnesses to the Public Accounts Committee advocated a review of the Guidelines by the Public Accounts Committee and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

The Committee resolved on 4 September 1989 to conduct an inquiry with a view to determining the extent and nature of any revision to the Guidelines which was found to be required. The Committee decided to conduct an initial review before draft Guidelines were prepared by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It was intended by this means to ensure that any basic issues which arose could be considered in the drafting of the Guidelines, rather than only when the Committee considers a completed draft for approval under sub-section 25 (7) of the Public Service Act 1922.

In the conduct of this Inquiry two issues arose which provide the key recommendations of the report. These issues are the reporting of program performance and an extension of Parliamentary review of departments by the Standing Committees of the House of Representatives.
Reporting of Program Performance

The most significant change required in the content of annual reports is an increased emphasis on program performance. This change flows directly from and is a necessary element of, recent managerial reforms.
The increased emphasis requires:
reporting performance at the sub-program level;
including a statement of the performance which had been anticipated for the year; and
including a statement of the performance anticipated for the following year.

These reforms would ensure that annual reports facilitate and encourage the assessment of departments on the basis of their performance rather than merely on the level of activity or on compliance with a decreasing body of centrally mandated processes. In encouraging assessment of departments on the basis of performance, such annual reports would help to bring external perceptions of departments more closely into line with the performance oriented managerial concepts which are being adopted by departments.

In adopting this recommendation the Committee believes that it will significantly increase the focus of parliament and the public on departmental performance rather than on inputs and processes and therefore believes that the adoption of this recommendation is fundamental.
Parliamentary Scrutiny of Performance
The Committee can see scope for benefit through a complementary reform of Parliamentary scrutiny introducing reviews based directly on departmental annual reports.

It is vital to emphasise that while Senators focus on concerns of performance and results in the course of Senate Estimates hearings, two thirds of members of Commonwealth Parliament who are members of the House of Representatives do not have access to a parliamentary review system which could enable systematic review of performance of departments. This gap in the parliamentary scrutiny regime needs to be addressed and therefore issues of performance reporting in annual reports need to be considered in conjunction with proposals for expanded parliamentary scrutiny of annual reports.

To remedy this situation and to make Parliamentary use of annual reports more visible the Committee recommends that the Standing Committees of the House of Representatives be assigned the ongoing role of conducting reviews of departmental operations based upon the annual reports of departments. This recommendation is in line with the recommendation of the House of Representatives Procedure Committee in its report tabled in the House today.

The increase in visible use of reports by the parliament should provide an incentive for improved reporting. The Committee, in addition, has made a considerable number of recommendations relating to the content and presentation of annual reports and to the presentation of the Guidelines.

The intention of the Committee has been to allow this report to be considered by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in drafting revised guidelines. To achieve this objective it was necessary for the Inquiry to be conducted in a tight timeframe. The Committee sought the view of parliamentarians, Commonwealth departments and the public but did not hold public hearings. The timeframe for the Inquiry was reflected in many of the deadlines set for individuals and organisations contributing to the Inquiry. The Committee thanks contributors for their efforts to meet those deadlines.
The Committee wishes to place on record its appreciation to Mr Bert Johnston for his contribution to this report.
Annual reports are fundamental to the increased accountability regime proposed by the Committee in its work during the 35th Parliament.

The Committee believes that the critical focus of this report on annual report performance reporting by departments and intensified parliamentary scrutiny deserve the support of all members of the House and of the Government.
I commend the report to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT GUIDELINES FOR OFFICIAL WITNESSES BEFORE PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) I seek leave to make a statement relating to government guidelines for official witnesses before Parliamentary Committees and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
GOVERNMENT GUIDELINES FOR OFFICIAL WITNESSES BEFORE PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEES AND RELATED MATTERS
Mr President

For the information of Honourable Senators I table the revised Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses before Parliamentary Committees and Related Matters, and seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to make a statement about the guidelines.
As the Senate will recall, guidelines on these matters have been tabled in the Parliament for many years now, by the previous Government and by this Government.
Broadly speaking, the basic principles of the guidelines have remained unchanged throughout this period, and the Government is not proposing any fundamental change in this new version.

The revised guidelines take account, first, of the Senate's resolutions on parliamentary privilege of 25 February 1988 and, secondly, of experience in recent years in the interpretation and application of the guidelines when official witnesses appear before parliamentary committees.

This latter consideration has led to the objective of making the guidelines a simpler and clearer exposition, for both officials and the Parliament, of the responsibilities and rights of officials providing evidence to parliamentary committees, party committees and other inquiries.

Mr President, I draw the attention of the Senate in particular to the first paragraph of the guidelines which refers to the fundamental issue of accountability. Indeed, since the concept of accountability provides the philosophical underpinning for these guidelines, as it has with their predecessors, I read that paragraph in full.
It states as follows:-

``1.1 In the Australian system of parliamentary government, and consistent with the traditional understanding of ministerial responsibility, the public and parliamentary advocacy and defence of government policies and administration has traditionally been, and should remain, the preserve of Ministers, not officials. The duty of the public servant is to assist Ministers to fulfil their accountability obligations by providing full and accurate information to the Parliament about the factual and technical background to policies and their administration. The guidelines are therefore aimed at encouraging the freest possible flow of such information between the public service, the Parliament and the public,''

I emphasise here that the Government is fully committed to the objective just enunciated of encouraging as free as possible a flow of factual and technical information between the Public Service and the Parliament.

I believe, however, that all members of Parliament will accept-as they have in the past-that a basic underlying premise of our system of government is that Ministers should be accountable to the Parliament for the administration of their Departments and for their ministerial conduct, and in particular that it is Ministers and not officials who are responsible for public promotion or defence of government policies.

While these basic concepts can be stated relatively simply, putting them into practice in modern government is not nearly as simple as it used to be, principally because the size and complexity of government has grown so much.

The legitimate role of the Parliament in scrutinising the activities of the executive has also become more demanding and more complex, and part of the response has been to expand the structure and functions of parliamentary committees.
Inevitably, also, there has been a significantly growing requirement for officials to be involved in parliamentary committee processes.
The Government welcomes these developments which it regards as both proper and inevitable.

I note here, however, that it is often the case, when officials appear before parliamentary committees, that parliamentarians seek to gain political advantage from their interactions with officials by seeking to draw them into policy debate or otherwise seeking to elicit comment from them which goes beyond the bounds of their role of providing factual and technical information.

When this occurs, it can place officials in an invidious position. Clearly, they have a duty, as set out in these guidelines, to be helpful to the committee and provide as much relevant information as is available. but at the same time departmental officials are, rightly, aware of the established position of law and principle that their primary obligation is to the Minister and Government of the day-whatever its political complexion.

What these revised guidelines seek to do, against that background, is to provide clear and unequivocal guidance as to the respective roles of Ministers and officials in their relationships with parliamentary committees. They seek to explain, as simply as possible, the practical implications of the basic concept of accountability which I referred to at the outset.

I am, of course, conscious of the growing interest in the Parliament-and particularly in some of its committees-in seeking ways to improve the processes of scrutiny of the executive and to give more practical meaning to the concept of accountability.
The Government has, from the very beginning of its period of office, taken very seriously its responsibilities and accountability to the Parliament.

Many of the reforms which it has introduced in public sector management have been designed in a way which increases the amount of information available to the Parliament-and to the public-of relevance to the establishment of an effective scrutiny process.

In particular, I draw attention to the innovations of the Government in publishing forward estimates of expenditure and in moving progressively towards the provision of far more comprehensive material on the outcomes of government activity. This enables, of course, better assessment of the effectiveness of government activity where such material is added to the material traditionally available on inputs.

Also of particular importance have been the increasing moves towards taking authority from central agencies and placing it in operating Departments, both in relation to financial management and general management responsibilities.

The Government acknowledges, however, that some of these reforms, including those just referred to, have made it necessary to reconsider the most effective approach to scrutiny, and to consider how best to clarify the practical application of the established principles of accountability.

Mr President, against that background, I am confident that these guidelines provide both the Parliament and officials with a sound basis for a continuing productive relationship which, amongst other things, will encourage proper consideration of the issues just referred to.

As I said at the outset, the Government is determined that the Parliament and its committees should have full and proper access to the factual and technical material that officials are able to provide.
For their part, Senators and Members should be conscious in their dealings with officials that the Commonwealth is fortunate to have a Public Service that is apolitical in the best sense of the word.
Ultimately, that is what the guidelines seek to preserve and protect.
That protection will be the greater if all participants in the process understand and support by their actions the underlying principles which the guidelines espouse.
I commend the guidelines to the Senate.

GOVERNMENT GUIDELINES FOR OFFICIAL WITNESSES BEFORE PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEES AND RELATED MATTERS
INTRODUCTION
Accountability

1.1 In the Australian system of parliamentary government, and consistent with the traditional understanding of ministerial responsibility, the public and parliamentary advocacy and defence of government policies and administration has traditionally been, and should remain, the preserve of Ministers, not officials. The duty of the public servant is to assist ministers to fulfil their accountability obligations by providing full and accurate information to the Parliament about the factual and technical background to policies and their administration. The guidelines are therefore aimed at encouraging the freest possible flow of such information between the public service, the Parliament and the public.
Scope of guidelines

1.2 The guidelines apply primarily to the preparation of submissions and the giving of evidence to parliamentary committees by officials, although sections 3-6 also discuss their relevance to contexts outside parliamentary committees, including party committees, Royal Commissions, individual Members of Parliament, speeches, public inquiries and court appearances.

1.3 The previous version of the guidelines was tabled in the Parliament in August 1984. Changes have been made to take account of the Senate Parliamentary Privilege Resolutions of 25 February 1988 (see Appendix) and recent experience with the appearance of witnesses before parliamentary committees.
PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEES
Application of Guidelines

2.1 This section is designed to assist departmental officials, statutory office holders and the staff of statutory authorities appearing before parliamentary committees, by informing them of the principles they are required by the Government to follow. It is recognised, however, that the role and nature of some statutory authorities will require the selective application of these guidelines (see paragraph 2.49).
Parliamentary rules of procedure
