The under-representation of people with disabilities in the labour force and the considerable recent growth in their reliance on income support contrast sharply with increasing community recognition of both the rights and capacities of people with disabilities to take part in the life of the community.

If people with disabilities are to live with the maximum possible independence and to take part in employment, education, training and the other major activities of adult life, then they must have access to effective support services.

A major problem in developing co-ordinated labour market and training services, accessible to people with disabilities, is the lack of explicit linkages between income support programs and rehabilitation services, labour market programs and supported employment services. This has contributed to the labour force marginalisation of people who have, or could develop, employment potential. Development of links between programs which encourage and support access to employment should reduce reliance on income support and would acknowledge the rights and capacities of all people with disabilities to take part in the mainstream of community life.

In response to the Review of Client Services and Regional Structures (the Halton Review), the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) is improving its service delivery to disadvantaged clients, including people with disabilities, by:

establishing Job Seeker Specialist Services Units to provide a caseload-based, in-depth counselling, assessment and referral service to clients and developing a support infrastructure for disadvantaged clients within the local community;
integrating existing CES labour market programs to better target the specific needs of people with disabilities; and

increasing the number of staff servicing clients with labour market disadvantages, including disabilities, and training staff in specialist counselling skills and knowledge of programs and services available through CES and other government and community agencies.

A more responsive approach to people with disabilities by the CES through the provision of more intensive procedures will be important in placing those people whose needs are unlikely to be met by standard procedures. In this regard, two trials will be undertaken in CES offices to test measures to improve early identification of people with disabilities. Furthermore, the Departments of Social Security, Community Services and Health and Employment, Education and Training are testing ways to improve access for people with disabilities to labour market, training and rehabilitation services. The models being tested are:
interdepartmental teams, consisting of representatives from the three Departments;
departmental brokers from the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) or the CES; and
community brokers attached to community organisations.

Clients will be interviewed by a team or a broker who will assess their situation and develop and implement an action plan in consultation with the client, based on labour market, training or rehabilitation services available from the Departments or from local community organisations.

Teams and brokers will provide a single contact point where a client can be provided with information on, and referral to, the most suitable assistance available from the participating Departments and local community organisations.

Early intervention by the CRS for Social Security recipients has the potential to shorten the period that people with treatable disabilities spend on income support before returning to work. This rationale is in line with the recent changes in the compensation laws which have provided improved access to rehabilitation to injured workers in the recognition that early intervention encourages these people to remain in the work force.

There is scope to make existing links more effective and currently the Department of Social Security is testing a means of improving the rehabilitation referral process by systematically identifying clients who could return to work via CRS rehabilitation. The effectiveness of early rehabilitation will be assessed by an exit survey of this group.

The CRS provides a wide range of social and vocational rehabilitation to people with disabilities. The value of offering rehabilitation programs to appropriate pensioners and beneficiaries is recognised not only in economic but also in social justice terms. A recent independent study of the CRS demonstrated that clients completing programs substantially increased their time in the work force and were less dependent on others. It found that for every $1 expended, a CRS program returned an economic benefit of $6 to the individual and $2.25 to the Government through reduced income support and increased taxation.

However, there are groups of clients who are perceived as not capable of achieving substantial gain including those with low motivation, acute psychiatric conditions and drug and alcohol dependence. These people are often labelled unemployable because of their multiple labour force disadvantages. We need to address whether specialist rehabilitation services would deal more effectively with these groups.

The issue of access to appropriate rehabilitation and labour market services is particularly relevant for women with disabilities. The National Agenda for Women noted that about one-third of women with disabilities are in paid employment compared with 50 per cent of men and that rehabilitation services are under-utilised by women. The reform process outlined in this Statement links in with the National Agenda action plan for women with disabilities. The action plan emphasises the need for social security assistance to minimise disincentives to labour force participation and for better access to and co-ordination of training, labour market and rehabilitation services.

Another issue of significance is the Sheltered Employment Allowance. Consistent with the principles of the Disability Services Act, a progressive changeover of sheltered workshops to supported employment services and competitive employment training placement services is taking place. Supported employment services are designed to support the paid employment of people with disabilities who would otherwise be unlikely to be employed in the open labour market and who need ongoing support to continue to work. There are currently 320 people in supported employment and a further 1,100 in competitive open employment.

These changes make necessary a review of the Sheltered Employment Allowance, which is paid to those entitled to it indirectly through the management of the sheltered workshop. This can disguise the very low rates of pay being received by some workers in sheltered workshops. There is a strong argument that income support should be paid directly to those eligible to receive it who are in supported employment, rather than to the organisations providing these services to pass on to recipients.

This also raises the issue of productivity based wages and slow worker permits. The Government is investigating ways of improving access by people with disabilities to part-time work and to work for productivity based wages under award conditions. The Minister for Community Services and Health has approved a consultancy arranged by his Department to examine in detail the issues associated with the determination of appropriate wage payments people with severe disabilities who may be working alongside workers who are not disabled in an integrated work place. The consultancy will also examine the issues of union membership and the legal protection of workers' rights, particularly protection against discrimination.
Cost Issues

It is widely recognised that people with disabilities incur financial disadvantages and must bear extra costs which people without disabilities do not have. One of the most frequently raised issues in the consultations following the release of the Social Security Review Issues Paper on disabilities was that of additional costs, particularly for those seeking or in employment.

Transport costs for people with a disability may cause substantial barriers to participation in the work force, education and training programs. The ABS 1988 Aged and Disabled Persons Survey pointed out that, of those who have a severe disability, those with a severe mobility disability were least likely to be in employment.

To minimise disincentives and maximise opportunities for people with disabilities to take part in employment and training activities and to reduce the costs incurred in participating in the work force, accessible and affordable transport is vital.
In addition to the costs of transport, however, the cost of medication and the high costs of aids and appliances for people with disabilities are of concern.

There is a range of existing provisions to assist in meeting these costs such as a mobility allowance for those engaged in gainful employment or vocational training; the attendant care scheme; and sales tax exemptions. In addition, there is a wide range of concessions relating to transport, medication and aids and appliances available to people who qualify for a Pensioner Health Benefit Card. However, there are concerns with these arrangements. For example, pensioners who undertake employment lose eligibility for fringe benefits and the associated concessions; mobility allowance provides only limited assistance for a small group of people; while sales tax exemptions are available only to those who can afford a new car. The existing arrangements need examination.

The Treasurer recently announced that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) is to provide him with a report, by July next year, on the costs of imported aids and appliances. The inquiry is to examine the effects of tariffs and other measures on the availability and costs of aids and appliances used by people with disabilities and the reasons for any high costs of imported aids and appliances.

The IAC has begun its inquiries and will be holding public hearings in December this year. Following a draft report next March, it will receive further submissions and hold further hearings with the intent of presenting its final report and recommendations by July 1990.

The question of cost is closely related to the objective of achieving economic security. Studies are required to provide more information on these costs, in particular the extent to which there are extra costs as people with disabilities seek to engage in training or employment, and under what circumstances those extra costs are incurred.

There are then subsequent issues to be resolved about what, if any, additional income support should be provided. If additional support is warranted should it be as an addition to the basic pension? As a once only employment entry payment? As a mobility allowance? As a tax concession or in the form of direct service provision? If there was some acknow- ledgment within the income support structure of the extra costs of disability, and assuming that payment was confined to those seeking employment, should it be confined only to those with a severe disability or should it be more widely available? These questions indicate the difficulty of the income support issues relating to the costs of disability.
To assist in addressing these issues, research will be undertaken on the financial barriers people with disabilities face when they move from income support to employment.
Attitudinal Change

The greatest single barrier preventing an improvement in the quality of life for Australians with disabilities is the attitudes of Australians: attitudes of employers, of workers (including those employed in government agencies), community attitudes generally and the attitudes of some people with disabilities themselves. Fundamental attitudinal changes are required away from a focus on people's disabilities toward a focus on what they can do.

Many people who have disabilities are not waiting for community attitudes to change but are forging ahead the hard way. They are pushing out the expected boundaries of what they are capable of, challenging the stereotypes and fighting to make decisions about their lives. Others, however, are doubting their own capacities and are forced into exclusion from mainstream activities because of the attitudes of their fellow Australians, attitudes which define and confine their capabilities to the detriment of us all.

As we move into the 1990s, the challenge ahead is to shed our old prejudices and jolt ourselves out of restricted thinking so that we share a vision of an Australia which can provide real choices for people with disabilities to enable them to develop their potential fully.

There are encouraging signs of change. For example, employers are responding positively to recent Government initiatives to assist sole parents and long-term unemployed people back into employment. Many people who are benefiting from the Jobs, Education and Training (JET) program for sole parents and the Newstart program for long-term unemployment beneficiaries do in fact have multiple disadvantages, often including an actual physical impairment as well as disadvantages such as age, lack of skills or a low level of literacy. Employers are finding that programs such as JET and NEWSTART, which are tailored to the needs of the individual, produce productive members of the work force.

The philosophical basis of JET and Newstart is to enhance the sense of self worth and dignity of participants as well as their level of skills and to encourage employers to see their true worth. The same principles can be applied to assist people with disabilities to develop their potential.

It is readily understood, however, that an employer could hardly be expected to take on a person with a disability if that person has been put on an invalid pension because of a ``permanent incapacity''. The ambivalence of our attitudes is reflected in this eligibility criterion combined with general community concern for the growth in the numbers of people who move onto invalid pension but who never come off.

For too long we have considered individuals with a disability or multiple disadvantages too hard to help. So often this becomes a tragically self-fulfilling prophecy. Yet, because so many people currently on a pension or benefit do have a capacity to get into some form of labour market activity with assistance, it makes economic sense to provide that assistance. This is especially so for the young.

There is a hard task ahead to turn around deeply ingrained attitudes. We must get rid of the preconceptions which have prevented people realising their full capacities. The ability of people with some disabilities often equals the ability of others without disabilities. Legislation and educative methods will need to be used to combat discrimination and facilitate the process of reform. The Government will consider, in consultation with employers, unions and community groups, an Australia-wide education campaign on the employment potential of many people with disabilities.
The Way Ahead
Activities Over the Next Year

This Statement has identified the concerns with the current income support and related arrangements for people with disabilities and the critical policy issues which are being addressed through the pilots and research projects.

The Government has directed the Task Force of officials to oversee the projects and to give advice on specific policies based on their outcomes in time for Budget deliberations next year. Further, in the process, the Government will liaise with the Disability Advisory Council of Australia and seek advice from the Social Security Advisory Council which, in turn, will develop mechanisms for carrying out consultations, including hearing the views of representatives of people with disabilities.

It will also ensure that consultations will be undertaken with major ethnic organisations in the course of developing assistance for people from non-English speaking backgrounds. Aboriginal people also have special needs in this area and the Government will be looking closely at ways of improving their access to income support and rehabilitation and training programs.

In recognition of the value of rehabilitation in getting people back to work, the Government has increased the number of rehabilitation places in the CRS from 15,260 in 1988-89 to 18,000 in this financial year-an increase of some 2,740 or 18 per cent.

The Government is committed to increasing the number of rehabilitation places in the CRS over the next three years. We propose to provide 21,000 places in 1990-91, 23,500 places in 1991-92 and 27,000 places in 1992-93. This represents growth of 9,000 new places over the triennium or a total of 17,500 additional services.

The Government also intends to ensure that people with disabilities have proper access to Australian Public Service employment. They must also have the chance for proper advancement. The Government has long had a commitment to equal employment opportunities for people with disabilities. Unfortunately, statistics show that further efforts are required to ensure that the vision becomes a reality.
The Government made additional resources available in the Budget for a number of measures to foster the employment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service (APS). These included:
additional resources for the Selective Placement Officers in the Department of Employment, Education and Training;
funding for community agencies to enable access to the APS for people with intellectual disabilities; and
funds for promoting employment of people with disabilities among APS managers.
The Department of Employment, Education and Training is also promoting its programs of assistance for people with disabilities seeking APS employment.
These measures are seen as important next steps in ensuring equitable employment for people with disabilities in the Government's own work force. We must lead by example.
The Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs is currently enquiring into both employment and housing issues for people with disabilities and plans to report in March 1990.

Employers of people with a disability who are appropriately placed and trained on the job are enthusiastic about their commitment and high standard of work. Even in areas of high unemployment employers are looking for more places because of their satisfaction with the reliability and competence of these workers.

In recognition of the advances that have been made in securing open employment for people with disabilities, the Prime Minister has agreed to sponsor the ``Prime Minister's Employer of the Year Award'' to go to an employer who has a record of excellence in employing people with disabilities. The first award will be made early next year.
Over the next year the Government will also benefit from the work of consultants to the Department of Community Services and Health who will advise on key disability work force issues.

There are no well developed overseas models for reform in this area which are applicable in the Australian context. This is despite the fact that other industrialised countries are experiencing problems similar to our own and have similar concerns with their disability related income support payments. In many ways, therefore, Australia is blazing a new trail.

Precise details of reforms must await the outcomes of the pilots and research projects. However, the Government is giving consideration to a number of crucial areas of concern to people with disabilities. These are:
the appropriateness of the assessment basis and income test for invalid pension to encourage greater labour market participation;
the scope for improvements to the delivery of services, particularly rehabilitation and labour market programs;
the issue of the costs of disability; and
the scope for strategies to assist people with low levels of disability but other labour market disadvantages to undertake education, training and employment.
Toward a Better System

Change is on its way. In the 1990-91 Budget the Government will be deciding on the first stage of a two to three year program for a new deal for people with disabilities. To facilitate transition to work within the social security system will not be an easy task, particularly because of the potential resource implications. Resource constraints may, therefore, require a staged approach to reform.

There will always be people with disabilities who, for lengthy periods, if not their lifetime, cannot participate in the mainstream labour market. The Government is sensitive to the fact that these people need a secure income support system which provides them with adequate income.

However, there are also many people with disabilities who do have some capacity for employment and want to participate. These people must be given access to the types of assistance which are available to other disadvantaged job seekers to help them obtain either part or full time participation in the workforce.

A new deal for people with disabilities must focus on opportunities for rehabilitation, training and employment. Particular attention must be given to integrating disability-related income support payments and rehabilitation and labour market programs. While existing arrangements may appear to provide some security for people with disabilities, the cost of that security is very high if it means a lifetime of dependence. A system of income security which provides real options and real opportunities is the aim of our reforms.

There are strong arguments that young people with disabilities should be a priority group for more active forms of assistance. The reality is that there are substantial social and economic implications which give a 16 year old no option but to go on a pension. We must provide opportunities for these young people to explore their potential for obtaining some independence and for participating in the mainstream of our society.

The Government will pursue its reforms with sensitivity. It will be essential to have the active support of employers and the trade union movement. The Government has committed itself to wide consultation throughout the policy development process since resolution of the issues will involve all community groups.

It is also important to emphasise that current invalid pension arrangements will continue while these policies are being developed. Existing pensioners can be assured that changes will be undertaken with care and compassion. However, they too should have the opportunity to share in any improvements in access to labour market and rehabilitation programs.

It is important to get complex reform right. The aim is to achieve a much improved quality of life for Australians with disabilities and their families; to ensure fairness, opportunity and security for everyone in Australia.

We are at another important milestone on the road towards a new system. The vision is of a new system which more actively encourages independence for people with disabilities; a more humane system with better community understanding of basic human rights which apply equally to people with disabilities; a system with integrity and accountability that reduces welfare dependency but provides comprehensive assistance; a system based on the co-operative effort of relevant agencies to address the individual needs of clients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The Opposition welcomes the fact that the Government has made a statement on disability reform. We think that the fact that the statement is made is an acknowledgment of the point which has been made by the Opposition for some time now that we are very concerned at the provisions for disabled Australians and believe that the Government does need to give attention to this matter, as indeed the Opposition has given attention to it.

I remind the Senate that two aspects of the Government's administration of programs relating to the disabled are currently under examination by a Senate committee at the suggestion of the Opposition. Those aspects are the employment of the disabled and accommodation for the disabled. With respect to the reference on employment of the disabled, I must say that my own attention was drawn to serious deficiencies during the 1987 election campaign in what can only be described as a non-campaign mode period when, in a country town of New South Wales, a constituent of yours, Mr Acting Deputy President, proceeded to enlighten me on the enormous difficulties which face many disabled Australians in obtaining satisfactory employment. I am very hopeful that the Senate committee inquiry will produce some useful recommendations for both the Government and the Opposition. However, unlike the Government, the Opposition has not merely identified this as a problem and been prepared to do nothing about it.

In the Economic Action Plan which was released by Mr Peacock on behalf of the Opposition last month, in October this year, the Opposition made it clear that it thought a number of changes were required. We made changes which involved both, I suppose one could say, positives and negatives, although we would see both the expenditure reduction exercise that is part of that program and the expenditure increase as being positive from the point of view of individuals who are disabled. I do not think many Australians understand just how many people are on disability pensions in Australia. The numbers are in the hundreds of thousands, and it is a $2 billion program. Indeed, the statement of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) which has been tabled today deals with some of the difficulties in this area, which arise from the very large numbers, and the difficult policy issues which arise. For example, the Minister says:
There is also concern at the long term dependency on disability payments.

That is a problem which is identified by the Government in this statement. Under the heading `Income Support Issues' the Government identifies some of the sorts of dilemmas that face policymakers in this area. For example, on page 7 of the statement, talking about the threshold of eligibility-in other words, just how disabled people should be before they are entitled to a disability pension-the Minister states:

If the threshold is set at a relatively high level, large numbers of people qualifying under current criteria would be excluded who would, nevertheless, be in need of some form of assistance. If, on the other hand, the threshold is set at a relatively low level, large numbers would become eligible with consequent high cost implications as well as possible disincentives for labour market participation.

Those last words mean that, if we allow very easy access to an invalid pension, that impacts upon the attempts that some disabled people will make to enter the work force. That can be a very great negative for those people, because being part of the normal working life of Australia can be an important part of ensuring that one identifies as a member of the community in a full sense.

There are quite difficult policy decisions to be made and they are not helped when they are made the subject of political point scoring and abuse. There is in this area, as in other areas, a tendency on the part of politicians generally, but I would say on the part of Labor politicians in this present Government in particular, to reduce any discussion of these serious issues and any proposals about these issues to a pretty low form of political debate. For example, the statement that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has incorporated states:
The Opposition proposes to introduce punitive and discriminatory review measures on the pretence that these would magically reduce the numbers of people on invalid pension and sickness benefit.

I simply reject that proposition. As I say, it is an example of political point scoring. If honourable senators look at the last Budget Papers they will find $270m worth of expenditure reductions in social security brought about by a series of measures undertaken by this Government to reduce the costs of social security by reducing abuse or changing and refining programs, and so on. I think it is silly and, indeed, rather base of the Government simply to focus on anything which is put forward by the Opposition in the terms that it does.

What the Opposition is actually proposing is that individuals who are subject to or are receiving invalid pensions should be encouraged to seek rehabilitation for re-entry into the work force. It is proposed in a positive sense that greater access to rehabilitation and labour market programs, tailored to meet the special needs of the disabled people, will be provided. I would have thought that was something that would be warmly welcomed by the Government. Indeed, our announcement of a month ago has now been, in a paler sense, reflected in this statement, where the Government has agreed to give some increase to the rehabilitation services which will be made available to disabled Australians. I welcome that. I make the point very gently that what is proposed by the Government is considerably less than what was put forward by the Opposition some weeks ago.

It is absurd to try to categorise the changes which are advocated by the Opposition as being some form of punitive attack on the disabled. What is being referred to is the simple proposal that people who are on sickness benefit should be subject to a monthly check by a Commonwealth medical officer, and some invalid pensioners should be subject to an annual check of the same nature. The Government in its own statement draws attention to the fact that there is a real problem. One of the problems which the Government identifies is the question-and I use the Government's words-of `the growth in long term dependency on disability benefits'.

What is the Opposition's response? It is to say that on the one hand we need a more careful monitoring of the hundreds of thousands of people involved, some of whom are not severely disabled. We are not suggesting that people who are clearly, obviously and permanently disabled require this, but people who are on the margin should be subject to at least an annual check and they should have access to increased services to assist them to return to the work force. In those ways we are seeking to contribute to an improvement in the situation of the people who are the subject of this statement from the Government today.

I also draw attention to the fact that much of what is in this statement is a repeat of what was already announced in the Budget. The rest of it seems to be statements of intention about matters which will be inquired into and investigated. I do not despise the idea that there are ongoing inquiries and investigations as to how we should improve the lot of disabled Australians. Indeed, the Opposition is currently putting forward proposals for public consideration. A Bill was introduced into the other place today by Mr Ray Braithwaite, the shadow Minister for community services-essentially a tabled draft Bill which is to be a vehicle to enable people who are concerned with the Government's administration of the Disability Services Act to come forward with suggestions as to change.

The concerns that have been raised frequently with the Opposition, and certainly frequently with me personally, are concerns about the overly doctrinaire and bureaucratic way in which the Disability Services Act is being administered by the Government. This is a matter which I have taken up directly with the Minister and with some of his officials. The complaints are legion. The complaints are not about the directions that the Government set with the new disability services legislation. Those directions have received broad support, including from the Opposition. The problems which arise are problems which are almost automatically present in the administration of programs of this sort. We have on the one hand people who are theoretically involved, such as researchers and administrators-in a broad sense, people who are looking at how to change services for the better. On the other hand, we have people in the field who, on a daily, hourly, and minute by minute basis are grappling with the real on-the-ground problems of disabled people. And, of course, we have the disabled people themselves who are operating on the same hour by hour, minute by minute basis.

There properly is a creative tension between those who are devising new approaches and those who are administering services or are the subject of services which are provided. On the one hand, there is a natural conservatism in people; there is a natural desire to enhance security by making sure that things are predictable and stable. On the other hand, one can point to the real changes that have been made that have enabled many disabled Australians to go from positions of real dependency to positions of full or near full independence. That applies to people with mental disabilities and to people with severe physical disabilities.

Indeed, some wonderful and inspiring things are being done in Australia. I agree with Ray Braithwaite who said in the Parliament today that Australia is seen as a world leader in some of these fields. Some great efforts are being made in Australia to improve the quality of life which is available to people with disabilities. The problem is that some of those who are enthusiastic for change sometimes forget the practical realities which are faced by those who are actually benefiting from the programs. In putting forward a private member's Bill we are suggesting that, in particular with respect to people who have mental disabilities, there needs to be some parliamentary check on the procedures which are being followed by the Government. The Act leaves too much to administrative discretion, too much to rule-making by the Minister. We are looking to greater parliamentary supervision of the principles which are applied in the administration of the disability services program.

I suppose the basic point that I want to make is that this is a field where political involvement is actually very important. I think the role of the politician, and the role of the Minister in particular, is to act as a monitor and a check on that process of dialogue and change which is occurring. It is vital that the Minister is personally involved and personally cognisant of the real difficulties that face people on the ground and in the field. I think it is equally vital that this Parliament-which is full of the elected representatives of the people, many of whom have direct contact with their disabled constituents and with the organisations which provide services for them-plays a role in making sure that this whole thing does not get of hand and become doctrinaire, ideological and impractical. My experience as a Minister in the previous Government was that, with the best intentions in the world, there was often a need to moderate the ideological bent of people who had power over organisations and individuals through the administration of programs.

In speaking to this paper, I say: yes, the Opposition welcomes it; yes, we agree that there is a need for further reform and progress in this area. We have specific proposals which we believe will advance the interests of disabled Australians. But my personal plea in all this would be for the political involvement to be, as far as possible, of a non-partisan character. I do not believe that any party has a mortgage on wisdom in this area. I think we need to act as the umpires in a situation where sometimes the creative tension can spill over and become quite destructive. I commend to the public the legislation which we have introduced in the House of Representatives today. I do so for the express purpose of inviting people with expertise, including those people most fundamentally involved, the disabled themselves, to make their views known and to come forward with suggestions on how the many difficulties, which are currently being raised, can best be met.

Finally, there has been no aspect of administration in which I have been involved from which I have learned more than in the area of working with the disabled. One learns it from the disabled themselves as well as from those who quite often devote a lifetime to advancing their interests. It is an area which is full of hope because of the amount of progress that has been made over recent years. But we, as members of the Australian Parliament, must make sure that that progress continues. I hope that this statement will be a step in the right direction. As Senator Macklin wishes to speak in this debate, I will not seek leave to continue my remarks, but I hope that there will be another opportunity to debate this statement further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also welcome the statement put down by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in this very important area. I agree with quite a number of the latter comments that Senator Chaney made, particularly with regard to the way in which the Disability Services Act is being implemented. I, too, have had a lot to do with people working in this area. I agree with the analysis that Senator Chaney made that there may well be a clash between people working on the continuing services that are necessary and people in the community who are devising new modes and ways of doing it. This is what is really causing the difficulty. I have not yet met anybody who really wants the Act changed, but I have certainly met hundreds of people who want the administration of the Act altered dramatically and radically. I have made a plea before in this chamber and I thought I had had a sympathetic response from the Minister. However, there seems to have been very little movement at the peripheries where the work is actually happening. That same rigid attitude still exists and, unfortunately, is causing massive problems to those people who have to do the work on the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: The guts of the statement that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has put down is to be found in the following words on page 17:
A new deal for people with disabilities must focus on opportunities for rehabilitation, training and employment.

I think that is the essence of what we have to be about, but how we go about it is also vitally important. Within the last four or five weeks, on a study tour to the United States of America, I had the opportunity to spend some considerable time specifically dealing with the issue of new technology as it applies to people with disabilities. It is really quite amazing what is available in the world at this time.

The problem is that, in Australia, we have not seen fit to get a clear model of what we want to operate. If we read this statement carefully we see an oscillation between the old mode-that is, that we are all going out there to help somebody-and the new way of doing it, which is providing opportunities for people with disabilities to help themselves. Quite frankly, it is the latter mode that has to be taken up. Increasingly, those groups representative of people with a variety of disabilities are becoming frustrated, annoyed and angry at the patronising attitude taken by people working under the old mode. Unfortunately, it is obvious that this statement has not been written by a single person. If it has, that person is schizophrenic in his attitude to this matter as the statement moves backwards and forwards between those two modes. I do not think we have the opportunity to adopt both modes any longer.

What is available is exciting and dramatic. One of the people working in this area, with whom I worked for some time in the States, said to me, `We are not about weaving baskets any longer'. I spent an inspiring afternoon with a totally blind person who is a computer programmer. People who have any understanding of the difficulties of computer programming for anyone with sight would be amazed. This person is working on developing computer programs for satellite technology-an incredibly complex and difficult area. On the side, this person runs his own computer consultancy. Of course, since most of his business is done over the phone, he retailed to me that generally, when he arrives with his white cane and dark glasses, people are shocked and really quite taken aback. I think that is an interesting example of how one can have the wrong impression. But, when one questions why, one realises it is because one has in one's head a model which leads one to say, `This is not possible'. We carry those limitations. Those of us who do not suffer from mental or physical disabilities to any great extent carry around in our heads a model which limits other people. The problem of disabilities in our community ultimately is not one for the people with disabilities; it is for the people with abilities. It is they who are causing the problems. The people with disabilities are quite happy to get up and go but, often, they are restricted and encompassed by a mind set that does not allow them to do that, that says, `No, you will not'. To have a policy directed by people with disabilities seems still far away.

I remember very clearly and vividly an impassioned speech given in this chamber quite some years ago by former Senator Grimes, who was responsible, as Minister for Social Security, for taking very large steps in this area. Unfortunately, with former Senator Grimes's movement out of the Parliament much of that energy and thrust dissipated. What is needed is not new, nicely worded statements; we need that type of energy that former Senator Grimes gave to this area. He had a very clear and concise view of what should happen and that was that the policy directions for people with disabilities should be driven essentially by the people themselves, not by others. It is said on page 17 of the statement that a new deal for people with disabilities must focus on the three elements of rehabilitation, training and employment. Let it not be done in such a way as to continue to push on to people with disabilities what we believe they should be doing. Rather, let us, for once, have a bit of humility and ask them what it is they want to do with their lives. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, noting the continued international concern about the fate of Swedish diplomat, Raoul Wallenberg, who disappeared into Soviet hands in January 1945 following the defeat of Nazi forces in Budapest, and (b) recent discussions between Soviet authorities and Raoul Wallenberg's family about his fate, the Senate:

(a) affirms its admiration for the selfless and heroic work of Raoul Wallenberg in saving the lives of tens of thousands of potential victims, both Jewish and non-Jewish, of Nazi terror during the Second World War;

(b) urges all interested parties to continue to co-operate in a comprehensive and conclusive examination of the circumstances relating to the detention of Raoul Wallenberg by Soviet authorities from 1945 onwards; and

(c) resolves through its own work on human rights issues, to continue to apply the universal principles of freedom, justice and humanity that so vividly manifest themselves in Raoul Wallenberg's work.
I seek leave to incorporate a statement relating to this motion in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Next January will mark the forty fifth anniversary of the date of Raoul Wallenberg's disappearance.
He was by all accounts a truly remarkable man.
His actions during the Second World War against appalling odds and possibly at the cost of his own life were simply heroic.
Raoul Wallenberg's example shows the power that lies within us all to rally in defiance and eventually to triumph over depravity and intolerance.

He personally saved the lives of tens of thousands of people who would otherwise have fallen victims to Nazi butchery: ordinary people-workers, mothers and grandmothers, school children-all marked for execution through the frightening and perverse twist of Hitler's call for a Final Solution.

But tragically, having survived and helped so many others to survive the Nazi occupation of Budapest, Raoul Wallenberg was himself swallowed up by the bloody creation of another dictator: lost into the clutches of Stalin's NKVD whence he was never to emerge.
Raoul Gustav Wallenberg was born on 4 August 1912 into a distinguished Swedish family.
After studying architecture in the United States he embarked on various commercial ventures, and through his business activities came to learn of developments in Nazi-occupied Europe.

By 1944, Allied leaders could no longer ignore the horrible fact of Hitler's Final Solution and tentative international moves were started to save Jews and other potential victims in Nazi-occupied territories from death camps.
President Roosevelt set up a War Refugee Board for precisely this purpose.
Attention focused on Hungary, which had at the start of the Second World War a Jewish population of 750,000.
Discussions took place between the War Refugee Board and the Swedish government to expand Swedish diplomatic and consular representation in Hungary to work to save human lives.
It was in these circumstances that Raoul Wallenberg was appointed to the Swedish Legation in Budapest.

In the period from his arrival in Budapest on 9 July 1944 to his disappearance at the hands of the Red Army on 17 January 1945, Raoul Wallenberg and his colleagues in the Swedish legation saved perhaps one hundred thousand people from certain death.

They did so through mustering every resource they had at their disposal; sheer energy, tact, determination, forgery, bluff, and bribery. Ever vigilant, ever present, they were ready to issue Swedish identity papers and passports to anyone under threat.

Joni Moser, who worked in running errands for Wallenberg, describes one incident when Wallenberg learned that eight hundred Jewish labour service men were being marched to the Gestapo concentration camp at Mauthausen.
Moser and Wallenberg drove to the Hungarian frontier and caught up with the column.
Wallenberg asked that those with Swedish protective passports should raise their hand.
On Wallenburg's order, Moser ran between the ranks, telling everyone to do so, whether they had a passport or not.
Moser explains:

``[Wallenberg] then claimed custody of all who raised their hands and such was his bearing that none of the Hungarian guards opposed him. The extraordinary thing was the absolutely convincing power of his behaviour.''
In his work, Wallenberg was pitted against the ruthless killing machines of the Gestapo and the dreaded SS.
His antagonists included the infamous war criminal Adolf Eichmann.

At the very end of the Nazi occupation of Budapest, when he learned of Eichmann's plan for a total massacre of the 69,000 or so Jews who were still alive in the so-called General Ghetto, Wallenberg intervened in a final flourish of threats and brinkmanship to prevent the order being carried out.
When Soviet forces took control of Budapest some few days later, they found some 120,000 Jews who had survived the Final Solution-the only substantial Jewish community left in Europe.
Tragically, within a week, Wallenberg himself had disappeared.
He had devised a relief plan for the Hungarian Jewish community, and was on his way to present his ideas to Marshal Malinovsky, the Soviet commander, and the provisional Government.
His colleagues last saw him in the side-car of a Red Army motorcycle, on his way to discharge this mission.
What happened to Wallenberg after this still lacks satisfactory explanation.
There has been much speculation about Raoul Wallenberg's fate, with some-including, importantly, his family and his close colleague from Budapest days, Per Anger-believing that he may still be alive.
Soviet authorities, however, have maintained that Wallenberg died of a heart attack in 1947 at the NKVD's Lubyanka prison in Moscow.
Only last month, Raoul Wallenberg's family went to Moscow to get to the bottom of his disappearance.

They were given a small box containing his belongings-a blue passport embossed with the Swedish crown, some old currency notes and yellowed note pads-together with a reiteration of previous claims about his fate.

Sadly, despite the new openness and willingness on the part of the Soviet authorities to discuss the case, the examination of the circumstances relating to Raoul Wallenberg's disappearance is still not conclusive.
I for one believe that forty-five years after the disappearance of this remarkable man, efforts should continue to be made to clear up this matter once and for all.
But what then does Raoul Wallenberg's story mean for contemporary Australia, so far removed in time and distance?
In the first place, he and his colleagues from the Swedish Legation in Budapest saved the lives of many people who subsequently made their homes amongst us.
One such person was a 19-year-old woman, Anna Boskovitz, who had recently married.

After being arrested in the middle of the day on the streets of Budapest for ``looking Jewish'', she found herself released from detention by the Hungarian fascists into the hands of a stranger from the Swedish legation.

That stranger extended her the protection of his Government-protection that literally saved her life and allowed her subsequently to establish a new life in Australia. Not only does Anna Boskovitz owe her life to Raoul Wallenberg, Australia is a better place for having her and many like her among us. I understand that she is watching a debate on this resolution in the House of Representatives today.
Mr President, the story of Raoul Wallenberg also serves to remind us of humanity's capacity for cruelty on the one hand and its resources for compassion on the other.
In the words of one person who was saved by him, ``Raoul Wallenberg symbolises the ideal that one person can make a difference''.
At a time in human history when there is so much cause for optimism, so much evidence of change, Raoul Wallenberg's legacy demands that we not be complacent.
The violation of human rights internationally is still, sadly, a daily occurrence.
In too many countries we see daily evidence of suffering and oppression.
In many parts of the world we continue to witness unlawful detention, torture, starvation and poverty, the displacement of large groups of people and refugees.
It would be easy to turn our backs on these problems.
It could be as easy as flicking a television switch.
But to do so in the fact of Raoul Wallenberg's example would be to betray the legacy he left us.
In the same Budapest that formed the backdrop for Raoul Wallenberg's heroism, we have this very year seen the determination of ordinary people to turn back the tide of totalitarianism.
And as in Budapest, so too in Warsaw and Berlin and Prague.

The universal principles of freedom, justice and humanity that so vividly manifest themselves in Raoul Wallenberg's work still fire the spirit of humanity today, just as the dark forces he worked to counter still have still to be eliminated.
Earlier this year the Prime Minister presided over a tree naming ceremony here in Parliament House in Raoul Wallenberg's honour.
He also paid homage to this remarkable man in July this year in Budapest, when he laid a wreath at a memorial erected to his memory by the people of Hungary.
Today, I am pleased to commend this motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the motion that has been moved by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus). The life and work of Raoul Wallenberg, his courage, inspiration and determination are a lesson to us all. He reminds us that in the horror of man's inhumanity to man there is always something that each and every individual can do to combat such horror. What Wallenberg did has become legendary. He saved in Hungary perhaps 100,000 men, women and children from Hitler's final solution. He put his own life at risk every day working in appalling conditions. His reward in the end was that he himself became a victim of Stalin's Russia, another horrific totalitarian regime. His family and, in fact, the whole world community are still entitled to a proper investigation of his disappearance. In part, that is what this motion calls for. It is the very least that we owe to his memory.

SPEECH.PARA: We also, of course, must never forget the atrocities of Nazi Germany and the lessons learnt from that awful experience. Wallenberg's memory helps remind us of those awful events. We must also remember that atrocities are still occurring daily around the world. Wallenberg reminds us, as I said earlier, that there is always something that each and every individual can do. It is not someone else's responsibility to combat the horrors that we witness throughout the world each day; it is the responsibility of each of us.

This is an occasion to remember that the weapons of one man's fight against arbitrary violence were idealism, courage and compassion. If I might use the words that were used in the House of Representatives on our side in a much more full contribution to this debate, it is an opportunity for us to re-dedicate ourselves to the advancement of individual human rights and freedoms, which he so bravely defended and which have always been at the heart of our beliefs. We support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleagues I wish to express our wholehearted support of this motion. The speech that has been incorporated by Senator Bolkus expresses in a very powerful way the reasons this motion ought to be supported. I take up a point that Senator Hill raised-in respecting and honouring the memory of a person who had undertaken such deeds, we ourselves should be mindful of the fact that it is necessary for everybody to at least attempt to have the courage to undertake such deeds when one's fellow human beings are put under such suffering and, in this case, where one's fellow human beings were threatened with total annihilation.

SPEECH.PARA: The stories that have been written about Wallenberg's work are many. The one that has been reiterated in the statement expresses very clearly, I think, the essence of the person. When many Jewish men and women were lined up to be taken off to a concentration camp, he arrived on a motorbike and simply demanded that all those people with Swedish passports hold up their hands. He then had someone go through the crowd and tell everybody to put up their hands, which they did. He simply took them all away. The fact that he was able to do that suggests a person with incredible personal charisma and power.

It is one of the ironies of fate, as Senator Hill has said, that a person who devoted himself so marvellously to his fellow human beings should himself have suffered at the hands of a tyrant. He seemingly died not knowing that his memory and his work were so honoured around the world. It is with very great pride that my colleagues and I support the motion before the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Statement of Heads of Expenditure for Year Ended 30 June 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 September.
In Committee
Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That the Committee approves the Statement, for the year 1988-89, of the Heads of Expenditure and the amounts charged thereto, pursuant to section 36a of the Audit Act 1901.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Consideration of House of Representatives message.
Schedule of the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed:
Page 4, clause 4, after proposed subsection 221ec (9), add the following subsection:
`` `(10) This section does not apply to:
(a) a public hospital;
(b) a public benevolent institution;
(c) a public university.''.
Motion (by Senator Richardson) proposed:
That the Committee does not insist upon the amendment of the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not impressed with the reasons given by the House of Representatives in transmitting its message No. 577. The House of Representatives, in rejecting the Senate's amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill has put forward five points. In disagreeing with the Senate's amendment the Government has said that the amendment would reduce the effectiveness of the 1989-90 Budget measures seeking to overcome the deferral of tax payments. In response to that, I remind the Senate that the reduction in revenue has been estimated by the Government at $50m. While this is a deemed loss to the Government, it is an imposition of $50m on public hospitals, benevolent institutions-perhaps only one would qualify; the Australian Red Cross-and public universities. Interestingly, the Government talks about a loss to its revenue but later, in its fifth reason, it shows its inconsistency. It says that government assistance to public benevolent institutions, hospitals and universities is provided for by means of outlay measures which are subject to review.

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) convince us that that $50m has been given back, by virtue of payments to the States and others, to public hospitals, benevolent institutions and universities? If so, we would be quite happy to allow this amendment to lapse. But he cannot. The Government is trying to claw back, by a backdoor method, revenue to these vital institutions.

We will make another deal with the Government. If it is prepared to review the financial situation of these institutions and to provide supplementary finance to them via their intermediaries, we will withdraw our amendment. But what we are not prepared to do is, by a backdoor method, have these people pay additional costs. It is just not on. In pious reasoning it was put to us that it was wrong for government revenue-in other words, tax instalment deductions-to be kept by the employer body, be it a hospital or any other employer, for up to a month. Therefore, bodies that have group remittances in excess of $5m under this legislation have to make two remittances a month. So there is not only the direct cost to universities and public hospitals but also the extra administrative costs of handling it.

So, as I mentioned earlier when the Minister was not listening, or when he was on the telephone, we would be only too happy, as would the public hospitals, to drop this amendment if the Government could guarantee either of the following: firstly, that as a result of this legislation being passed it will immediately review the financial situation of those public hospitals, universities and benevolent institutions affected and offer funds to cover any shortfalls experienced as a result of the legislation. That is quite reasonable. Or, secondly, that all costs incurred by public hospitals, universities and benevolent institutions are fully covered by government outlays to them. That is not unreasonable.

The fact is that the Government cannot guarantee either of these options. If Senator Richardson can guarantee these options, we will withdraw the amendment forthwith. That is not unreasonable. As there is no provision in the Bill to reassess the funding to public hospitals, universities and benevolent institutions once this Bill has been enacted, I do not see how the Government can put forward reason No. 5 as a reason for disagreeing with our amendment. It has no basis in logic or fact. It is a concoction, in other words, to get the Government off the hook. There would not be one public hospital of the 70 which will be affected by this Bill which has all its costs fully covered by government outlays. That is the problem.

These public hospitals, universities and benevolent institutions are not for the benefit of private enterprise but, rather, they are for the benefit of the public and community. All these institutions and bodies have special recognition and status in the Income Tax Assessment Act. So, we are not including all public bodies across the board, because these are specially recognised under section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. We are not asking for something that is unreasonable; rather, we are asking that the Government fund these bodies adequately and that it does not claw the funds back through the back door.

These bodies, particularly public hospitals, operate on deficit finance or overdraft arrangements; they are nearly always in the red, with their funding from the public purse in arrears rather than in advance. Therefore, most are faced with making interest payments on their overdraft; so the Government's interest gained is their interest lost and that is what we must recognise. Those interest payments are currently at rates of between 20 and 25 per cent. Should they now be expected to make twice-monthly remittances of pay as you earn tax, this will disrupt their planned cash flows and place them further in debt.

In many instances, it will not be possible just to transfer this debt to the public funding body; rather, it will have to be covered by the institution itself. So, what will happen? These bodies-the public hospitals, public universities and benevolent institutions-also rely very heavily on donations and bequests from individuals, particularly for capital works and equipment purchase projects. So, what will happen? People donate money to the Melbourne Royal Children's Hospital for beds and redecorating children's wards but, in the future, as a result of this legislation, some of that money will be used to pay the debt interest. What will people do? Potential donors will say, `No, I'm not going to donate money just to pay interest'.

People will not donate money to Senator Richardson's Australian Labor Party just to pay its debts. They will pay to win an election, but they will not give donations to pay off a debt or to pay off interest. The same thing will happen to these public hospitals. So the losers will be the kids and the facilities that are provided. This money will have to be transferred into the other account because the Government will not give us a guarantee that it provided adequate funding in its last Budget to meet this debt. It will not provide a guarantee that it will make a supplementary payment to cover this debt, so it is not unreasonable that the Australian Democrats should join with us in knocking back this legislation.

This type of legislation is not the humanitarian sort of thing which governments should be involved in. I believe it is disgraceful. It will not be possible to transfer debt to a public funding body. The other donations account will be heavily drawn on. An instance has been relayed to me where in one public hospital government funding covers only a quarter of the money required for equipment replacement and it does not supply funds towards refurbishment, so in that case my argument applies 100 per cent.

Thus, hospitals make up the shortfall from donations and bequests and utilise the interest on these funds to purchase vital items of equipment and, as I said, to refurbish hospital wards. Our proposed amendment, which has been rejected by the other place for what I believe to be inadequate and insufficient reasons, has not come back to us. The Minister at the table says that the Government does not agree with our amendment and that the position in the other place should stand. It is disgraceful. It will impose costs which will be detrimental to the financial welfare of these institutions and to the welfare of the people whom they serve. This legislation will deprive those institutions of this finance and it will make them less viable. The number of services available will be reduced. I ask the Minister to give us a guarantee that he has either already covered it or will cover it. If he does, we will withdraw the amendment, but otherwise it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had expected the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) to do something other than sit there smirking. I thought that he would find something to say in response.
—You are ever the optimist.

—Senator Stone said that I am ever the optimist, but I thought that Senator Richardson would find something to say in response to Senator Watson's comments on this legislation. The Australian Democrats supported Senator Watson's amendment when it was introduced early in November and will continue to support it for the very reasons just outlined by my Liberal Party of Australia colleague. All sorts of assurances can be-and are frequently-given by governments that we know can be withdrawn at the whim of either the same government or a future government. That is one of the reasons why I do not trust governments that say that they want to introduce a broad-based consumption tax and that they will offset that with personal tax cuts and will provide a safety net for those who are on low incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: Those sorts of matters can be eroded in a variety of ways and can be taken away by a government that is under some sort of economic pressure. It was shortsighted on the part of the Government in the first instance to include in this legislation organisations such as universities, public hospitals, benevolent institutions, et cetera. It is now arrogant pigheadedness for it to continue with its position. The Government cannot ensure for all time that the guarantees of protection that it has apparently promised with regard to funding will continue and remain as an obligation in future years of either this Government or another government.

We must remember that, of all the organisations affected by this legislation, groups such as universities, public hospitals and so on are, in the main, deficit funded. In any event, their main source of finance is from Federal Government grants, capital works grants and so on, which we all know are subject to negotiation at Premiers conferences, to say nothing of the fact that they are likely to be reduced if the Government wants to increase its surplus or to reduce its deficit at some later stage.

The next favoured move by this Government when it wants to get a little more money in its coffers is to change the amount of grants to these sorts of instrumentalities and to cut expenditure on welfare and so on. As a result, most honourable senators are very reluctant to accept any sort of assurance from this Government that all will be well if only we trusted it. Over the past few years it has lost any chance it had to be regarded as trustworthy.

As was pointed out by Senator Watson, those organisations that do not receive sufficient funding from the Federal Government find it necessary to raise money through fund raising ventures, or by way of donations or bequests from people who may not, as the honourable senator said, be too happy about providing that sort of money, simply because the Government has decided to bring forward payments in this way. I think it is bizarre for the Government to compound the problems of funding and of meeting the financial obligations that are already faced by organisations like Australia's major hospitals, the universities, benevolent organisations and so on, by requiring pay as you earn tax payments to be made fortnightly instead of monthly.

The Government states that a revenue issue is involved and that it will be in receipt of, I think, $50m in one shot and that this will boost the surplus for this year and, presumably, make it look better in the eyes of Moody's Investor Service Inc. and Standard and Poor's, or some other organisation that from time to time give us ticks of approval, or crosses of disapproval. That is fine as far as the Government is concerned. However, it is a once only benefit that it will accrue, but the damage that will be done to the institutions is ongoing. As I have said, most of them are deficit funded; very few of them have money to play around with. To require those sorts of institutions to come up with tens of millions of dollars, just because the Government wants this one-off boost to revenue, is bizarre, to put it mildly. They will have to acquire this money from somewhere, and that means either cutting their expenditure in some area-and I suspect that they do not have the sorts of overflows that they can cream off in that way-or borrowing the money, which will impose additional stresses on their finances for repayment, to say nothing of the additional pressure that it will apply to lending institutions.

This is one of the problems that we see in the Government's other piece of tax legislation-that which is requiring companies to bring forward their tax payments. When we start forcing businesses, public hospitals or tertiary institutions to go to lending institutions for fairly sizeable amounts of money, not only will that put a strain on existing capacity to lend but it must inevitably force interest rates up further because of the increased demand. I do not know what the Government is trying to do by this measure. For a miserable $50m-and let us face it, it is miserable in the general context of a government's annual budget-it will place enormous administrative and financial strains on institutions that are already reeling from government cutbacks and could lead to ripple effects down the track within the finance area that it may live to regret.

The Democrats have absolutely no intention of allowing either of those things to happen. I echo Senator Watson's comments: while the Government cannot guarantee that its guarantees will ever be met, these institutions have to be protected by this place, in the only way we know how-that is, by excluding them from the compass of the legislation, protecting them from further financial constraints, and asking the Government to rethink its position on this matter, to accept this amendment this time and proceed with the rest of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the Senate's amendment are set out in a schedule attached to the amendment. I ask honourable senators opposite to reconsider their position. The provision in the Bill that the Senate is seeking to amend is a Budget measure and, of course, it does have revenue implications, of the order of $50m. I think all honourable senators would agree that that is a significant figure. I know that the Opposition has questioned this revenue loss; however, we have been able to confirm the figure.

SPEECH.PARA: Many institutions that are covered by the Senate's amendment are large employers. The Government does not accept the argument that, because the bodies that will gain from the amendment are public bodies, they should be given the benefit of the use of public funds. As was indicated at the time the Senate agreed to the amendment, government outlays to public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities are appropriately provided by means of outlays which are subject to review and which are compared with competing demands for Commonwealth funds in the budgetary process. They are not provided by way of the use of funds that are prepayments of income tax by employees intended to be paid to the Commonwealth.

The Budget measure does no more than seek to overcome the deferral of tax payments by the closer matching of remittances to collections. It should be remembered that it is not the remitter's money. It is necessary to realise that the Budget measure is part of a Government strategy aimed at eventually reducing the administrative burden placed on small businesses by the tax instalment deduction system, by moving small employers, which comprise the majority of remitters, to a system that would require less frequent remittances than at present.

The Government aims to continue with this strategy, despite the obstacle placed in its way by the Opposition parties in this amendment. However, the strategy should not be interfered with by making adjustments on the fringe, otherwise the system will become an administrative jungle. The amendment previously moved by the Opposition would effectively condone the back door financing of public institutions with Commonwealth funds through the use of extended retention of tax instalment deductions made from the salaries or wages of their employees. That is not acceptable to the Government, and again I ask honourable senators to reconsider their position on this matter, particularly given that it is a Budget measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —All that has proved is that the Minister can read what someone else has written for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am suitably grateful to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) for his remarks. I emphasise the word `suitably', because, as Senator Haines has just interjected, what we heard from the Minister was simply a rendition, in virtually the same words, of the remarks that were made in the other place by the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris). As Senator Haines has said, it proves that the Minister can read-which some may have doubted, but I give the Minister my personal assurance that I have never doubted that he could read.
—But it has not proved he can think.

—But, again as Senator Haines suggests, it perhaps does not prove very much about his capacity for thought about these matters. The House of Representatives has returned to the Senate the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, indicating its disagreement to the amendment made here and, as is always the case, it has provided certain reasons for that disagreement. One of those reasons is that the amendment would reduce the 1989-90 revenue gain from the measure by an estimated $50m. The Minister has re-confirmed that estimate this afternoon. I take note of that. It is a serious point and one that we are not in the business of diminishing by jeering at it or something of that kind. I assure the Minister that we understand that that is a significant loss in revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: However, having acknowledged that aspect of the Minister's remarks, I want to say that the next reason for disagreement given by the House of Representatives is less convincing. It is that `the income tax instalment collections to be remitted twice-monthly by major employers . . . do not belong to them'. Again, taken at first blush that is incontrovertible. Obviously, the income tax instalment collections do not belong to the employers, but I suspect that the implication in that reason is that they belong to the Government. Indeed, I think this is not the first occasion when we have seen the Government apparently take the view that basically everyone's income belongs to it and that if we are good it will leave us a little bit, and that taxpayers should be appropriately grateful. I think we have here an example of that general syndrome.

As I said before, no-one on this side of the chamber could claim that these deductions, having been taken from the wage and salary packets of employees, are in any sense the property of the employers who, acting as agents for the Commonwealth, have made the deductions. We are not claiming that. What we are saying is that in the particular cases that are under reference here, namely, the public hospitals, public universities and public benevolent institutions, rightly or wrongly-and without spending too long on, shall I say, the theory of the matter-the fact that these deductions are made and have been made for some considerable time and remitted once monthly at present to the Australian Taxation Office has come to form part of the whole agglomerate of cash flows of these bodies.

What Senator Watson has been rather cogently pointing out since he first moved here the amendment relating to this matter when the Bill originally came to the Senate is that whether we like it or not those bodies are going to be significantly financially disadvantaged by the change that is proposed. I emphasise that this is not a matter of tax theory, because I think on the tax theory side I would not perhaps find myself totally in disagreement with the Minister. But it is a matter of the practicalities of the positions of the bodies concerned. There is not the slightest doubt that in order to meet the requirements of the proposed legislation, these bodies will be very much more considerably out of pocket than they now are. Indeed, the Minister's estimate of a $50m loss of revenue itself confirms that. The most obvious way in which these bodies can overcome the problem which will be created for them by this Bill is to borrow the amount to increase their floating debt, working capital or whatever one wants to call it-their borrowings from the bank, in most cases, I suppose.

I am not even sure that in every case they would be able to do that, and I would like to know from the Minister whether he is sure. Will the Minister give the Committee an assurance that all the bodies in the categories affected by the amendment originally passed by the Senate will be accommodated by their bankers in relation to the additional borrowings that they will have to make? That is the first question to which the Minister might address himself when he responds.

A further point-and Senator Watson also referred to this-is: even if these bodies can be given the initial financial accommodation to tide them over, shall I say, the effects of this legislation upon their cash flow position, will they then be able to sustain the interest costs on the borrowings that they have to make? What will that do to their overall finances? In the case, say, of public benevolent institutions, will it mean that they will have to cease carrying out some of the public benevolent activities that they presently carry out? In the case of a public university, will it mean that it will have to cut back a course or two here and there, employ less staff or, in some cases at least, increase fees? I do not know, but these are obviously the possibilities that present themselves when we start to think about this matter.

I suppose a further possibility is that some of these bodies would have to go to their respective State governments-I suspect that that would be the first port of call for public hospitals-and ask for a greater subsidy or subvention from the consolidated funds of the State government concerned. Without wanting to take that line of thought to its ultimate conclusion, I just want to know from the Minister whether the Government has given any thought to what in fact these bodies will do. So far I have heard nothing from the Minister to that effect. He simply got up here and made almost word for word the same speech as was made in the other place by Minister Morris.
