I hope that I am not misrepresenting the Minister; I read Mr Morris's speech earlier today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you are misrepresenting me.

—I did not think that I was misrepresenting the Minister. I do not think that what we have been told is good enough. We are in Committee of the Whole, asking some questions, and we would like some answers.

SPEECH.PARA: The last of the reasons from the House of Representatives to which I propose to refer is as follows:

Government assistance to public benevolent institutions, hospitals and universities is appropriately provided by means of outlays measures which are subject to review and compared with competing demands for Commonwealth funds in the budgetary process.

Again, I want to say, so that there is no mistake on the Government's part as to where the Opposition stands on this matter, that I agree with that principle of public finance. Of course I agree with it. But, what we have here is a particular situation that has arisen because of a Government decision to impose this measure, the effects of which have not been properly thought through in relation to the institutions covered by the amendment originally passed by the Senate.

In that connection, I also want to say that the remarks made by Senator Haines were, I think, entirely apt, when she referred to the fact that this measure and, indeed, the companion measure to bring forward very considerably the timing of company tax payments, both of which were included in the Budget at the last minute, were pieces of quite shameless adhockery. I am not quite sure whether she referred to them in that way, but I do not think she would dissent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I used to teach English; I would not quite use that expression.

—I also balk a little at the word `adhockery', so I understand the honourable senator's sensitivity. But I am afraid that the word has crept into the language. The fact is that both this measure and its companion measure were very much dreamed up at the last moment by a Treasurer desperate-and I mean that-to present to the Parliament last August a Budget which appeared to produce a significant increase in the Budget surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have this measure, which drags forward into 1989-90 a sum, I think from memory, of $550m, which otherwise would have been payable in 1990-91 and, therefore, improves the cosmetic appearance of the Budget surplus by the major amount of over half a billion dollars. Without straying too far, I point out that its companion measure brings forward the payment of what I might loosely call provisional company tax initially to the fifteenth day after balance date including-and this was the key point-in the case of so-called early balancing companies a measure which would have the effect of bringing into 1989-90 a sum, I think initially estimated in the Budget Papers at $885m, that also otherwise would have been collected in 1990-91. So between those two measures, we have a total amount of about $1.4 billion brought into 1989-90 that previously would have fallen due for collection in 1990-91.

It is precisely because of this kind of ad hoc approach to budgeting that we have these two hastily constructed pieces of legislation-we have only one before us today-which are having the kind of fallout that is now detaining the Committee for the second time because of the unintended consequences. I am prepared to concede that the consequences probably were unintended. But that is the problem we face when we have the kind of government that we have today which rushes these measures through the Cabinet process and into a Budget for quite other reasons and which then has to face up to the consequences of having done so.

It is instructive to recall that, in the case of the other company tax proposal, we have subsequently had not one but two successive retreats by the Treasurer from the initial decision. Since that proposal is not before us this afternoon, I will not embark at length on that point. However, it is a fact that, in that case also, a hastily constructed piece of legislation had to be amended before the Treasurer (Mr Keating) introduced the Bill. The Treasurer retired in an absolute rout when finally the Bill was about to be debated in the Parliament. The Opposition announced its position on the matter and he beat a retreat. Quite frankly, we could not see his dust.

I conclude by saying to the Minister that, on the basis of what we have so far heard from his side-which is no more than a reiteration of what was heard in the House of Representatives-the coalition is disposed to maintain its objection to this aspect of the legislation and, therefore, to maintain the amendment that we originally moved to the Bill. The Minister may be able to remove our objections. Perhaps if he were to address the objections rather than merely addressing the piece of printed paper that someone has given him to read out to us, he might have more hope of doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily concede to Senator Stone that I was reading from words prepared for me by advisers, but I do not think that is unreasonable, given that this is not a Bill of which I have had carriage. While I always miss Peter Walsh's attendance in this chamber, I particularly miss it now.
—He might not be missing yours, though.

—I am sure he is. He is a very charitable and very nice person. If the worst Senator Stone can accuse me of is that I was repeating words uttered by Mr Peter Morris in the House of Representatives, I have to say that all that has happened here today is that Opposition senators have repeated what they said when they first moved an amendment here. We have just had a rerun of that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson and Senator Stone have raised the question of interest costs and suggested, I think, that they are a big problem or a big deal for those affected. All I can say is that according to the Government's calculations interest costs, if any, faced by institutions would be minuscule. While interest costs may be minuscule, the revenue implications are very big indeed.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it! There is a very big revenue implication indeed for this year's Budget. The Senate is blocking legislation which involves $550m in revenue for this Budget. When it comes to figures of that dimension, it really is a time for Opposition senators to give very--
—Somebody can't add up.

—The somebody is Senator Watson; he has demonstrated that. Given the scope for the implications of that figure on the Government's Budget, the Opposition ought to give very strong consideration to what it is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clear up a couple of points which have been made by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in his reply. First of all, he has not addressed any of the questions which were put to him. I noted that, and it will be part of the basis on which we form our own attitudes to the matter. I want to pick up the comments which the Minister did make because, with such respect as I can retain in the circumstances, I have to say I find his comments extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, he has described the interest cost to these bodies as minuscule. Of course, I do not know what interest rates these bodies would pay, and no doubt every one would be different. If the revenue loss, were this amendment to be accepted by the Government, would be $50m, and if one assumes, for example, that the average overdraft interest rate being paid by those bodies is 22 per cent-I doubt that it would be less, but we can quibble about a million or two if we want to-22 per cent of $50m is $11m, as far as I know. While admittedly this would be spread over a number of bodies, I do not regard-and do not think they would regard-their share of that as minuscule.

The Minister then appeared to try to distort that point by talking about the revenue cost of the whole Bill. We are not rejecting the Bill. We are not proposing to reject the Bill. The Minister was talking about a revenue loss of $550m. That is the revenue to be had from the Bill as a whole. Our amendment would not cause that revenue to be lost. The Minister has told us-and I accept his estimate-that it would cause $50m to be lost. The revenue loss would not be $550m; it would be $50m. As to the word `minuscule', I leave the public benevolent institutions, the public universities and the public hospitals to judge whether they consider this amount to be minuscule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated earlier in this debate that public hospitals, by and large, operate on deficit financing. When this Bill comes back from the House of Representatives would the Minister be good enough to split the amount up State by State-as it is only `minuscule', it will not take a lot of calculation-in relation to public hospitals and the other bodies? Then we would be in a better position to accept this so-called `minuscule' figure. If it is minuscule, we have to doubt the propriety of the $50m. I am disappointed that none of the challenges that I have issued asking for proof have been taken up. If need be, show us the working papers-show that funding for these institutions has already been allocated in the Budget and we will accept it. Alternatively, agree to make a supplementary appropriation to cover the shortfall and we will withdraw our amendment. We will be satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: Previously, the Minister was not even prepared to give us the figure. He has now been good enough to give us the figure. Hotfoot it back to the House of Representatives-it has got until 22 December to look at this, and there is plenty of time to make the calculations-and then we will look at it. We are very distressed that the Minister was not game to address the issues and challenges we have raised-deficit financing and the two challenges. There is time to amend this Bill tonight and to get it right. It is up to the Minister.
Question resolved in the negative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Richardson)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 be taken together for their remaining stages.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 October and 24 November, on motions by Senators Button and Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with this package of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bills-Nos 3 and 4-the position of the Opposition is that it basically support the Bills on the basis that they represent a perhaps much lamented tightening up of the welfare system. After all, it has only taken five years of fairly lax administration by this Government for it to realise that there is a need for a tightening in this system. However, we will be monitoring the application of the various provisions, particularly those which have been brought to our attention by various groups who have a particular interest in these matters, to ensure that the administration of the provisions is equitable.

SPEECH.PARA: In that regard the shadow Minister sought in the House of Representatives an undertaking from the Minister concerned that, in particular, those sections dealing with de facto or marriage-like relationships would be dealt with in a fair and equitable manner. Similarly, the shadow Minister, Mr Connolly, has given an undertaking that we will continue to monitor the administration of these provisions and, indeed, when in government, take any action deemed necessary should our monitoring show that there are unfairnesses resulting from the provisions.

I think it is probably fair enough to say that, when the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 was introduced into this chamber, Senator Powell moved a motion to suspend Standing Orders so as to refer parts of the Bill to a committee for scrutiny. We did not support the suspension of Standing Orders on that occasion, but the arguments that I voiced then in refusing to support the suspension of Standing Orders remain basically the same.

The term `marriage-like relationship' as a phrase seems to have supplanted the old term `de facto relationship'. The aim of the Bill seems to be to ensure that people who are not in a marriage situation but who are in a marriage-like situation are not advantaged above those people who are married. I think that there was a feeling of some resentment in the community hitherto that people who did not, in fact, enter into formal marriage but remained in a marriage-like or de facto relationship were somehow advantaged above those who were married. I suppose that the way in which the Bill is drafted gives a statutory code and a more precise meaning to a marriage-like situation than has existed in previous legislation.

I do not intend to take up the chamber's time in going through all of the clauses of the Bill. I notice that the Australian Democrats will be moving various amendments in the Committee of the Whole and we will deal with those then. Basically, it is our intention to support the thrust of this package of Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to touch on various aspects of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4). As my colleague Senator Bishop has said, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 was introduced by the Government to implement some of the details that were announced in the 1989-90 Budget and in the April 1989 economic statement. The Bill encompasses a number of features that I will briefly detail. My colleague has already referred to some of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill introduces new arrangements to determine whether recipients of certain social security payments are in what could be considered a de facto relationship. It also introduces a waiting period for unemployment benefit where the recipient moves to an area which can be considered as reducing his or her chance of gaining employment. It provides that unemployment and sickness benefits will not be payable to those who do not provide the Department of Social Security with their tax file number. It also includes changes involving deferment periods for education leavers, a tightening of recovery procedures where a person receives both compensation payments and social security benefits, changes to the income test arrangements for the family allowance and the family allowance supplement and some small changes to the administration of the child support scheme.

Perhaps one of the most controversial aspects of the Bill is that relating to the definition of a de facto spouse, which Senator Bishop touched on earlier. The implications of this definition are far-reaching as they affect many areas of social security determinations which impact on pension payment rates and also on the payment of the supporting parent benefit. To be eligible for many of these benefits, an applicant must be unmarried. In that respect, the definition is widened to exclude those with a de facto spouse. A de facto spouse is often defined as a person of the opposite sex who is living as the spouse of an applicant on a bona fide domestic basis. Obviously, given the wide range of relationships that exist in today's society, when people of the opposite sex choose to cohabit there is considerable confusion. It may be that such a relationship involves merely a sharing of facilities or it may be one which on all accounts is identical to what would be considered a normal marriage. The current lack of an objective test results in considerable confusion not only for the potential recipients of benefits but also for those within the Department who must determine eligibility for the supporting parent benefit.

To give some idea of the number of people involved, as at 30 June 1988 some 182,000 people were receiving the supporting parent benefit-an increase of 2,900 on the previous year. There were also 95,369 new grants of benefit and 90,565 terminations during the same period. Of those terminations, 11,810 or 13 per cent were due to the recipient living with a de facto spouse. In Budget Paper No. 1 it has been estimated that the supporting parent benefit will cost the Australian taxpayer $2,236m in 1989-90, which is an increase of 4.9 per cent over the previous year.

There has been quite a deal of concern amongst community groups regarding changes to the de facto definition. It is perhaps to be expected that there should be an outcry from these groups, who may feel that some people will be disadvantaged under the terms of the Bill. Principally those concerns have centred on what they see as the continuing confusion over the definition of de facto relationships because of the lack of uniformity between State and Federal legislation. It is obvious that these concerns are genuine. However, the coalition believes that in this instance it is important to support the Government's attempt to tighten up an area of the social security system in which there is clear evidence of abuse.

In my State of Tasmania I am personally aware of many areas of abuse, but I do not claim that this abuse is by genuine recipients. However, Australian society being as it is, there will always be those who seek to exploit loopholes for their own benefit. The coalition will monitor the legislation to ensure that those people who are abiding by the rules are not disadvantaged. Accordingly, we will seek assurances from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) that the appeal mechanisms will be maintained. The savings that will flow to the Australian taxpayer are significant and should not therefore be discounted. Under the legislation, which will come into force on 1 January 1990, $8m will be saved this financial year and $29m in 1990-91.

I now turn to the area dealing with the unemployment benefit. As a result of the almost universal opposition within the community to the Australia Card proposal, the Government introduced a tax file number system. I do not need to spell out that individuals who fail to produce their tax file number suffer a tax rate at the top marginal rate plus the Medicare levy. No doubt the tax file number has served to reduce the incidence of tax evasion. It therefore does not seem unreasonable that those who fail to produce their tax file number should be denied unemployment or sickness benefit, as obviously there would appear to be some illicit reason for the non-production of that tax file number. Should applicants not wish to provide the tax file number themselves, they may give the Secretary to the Department authorisation to seek out their number or, alternatively, lodge an application for one.

Another measure mentioned in the Budget was a tightening of the work test for the unemployment benefit. This legislation will, therefore, amend the Act so that people who choose of their own volition to move to an area of higher unemployment than the one that they leave, or who may otherwise reduce their opportunity of gaining employment by moving, will be subject to a 12-week waiting period for that benefit. It is estimated that this measure will save $3.7m in 1989-90 and $9m in the next financial year. Again, I must stress that these savings will, hopefully, pass on to the ordinary taxpayer. Naturally the provisions of the legislation will not apply when the person concerned moves to be closer to his family. However, the coalition recognises that this, too, is an area of the social security system which has been subject to abuse. It is difficult to justify why people who are experiencing difficulty in finding employment can be supported by the Government in the dubious practice of moving to another area where their employment opportunities will be reduced even further.

Under the existing situation school leavers must wait for 13 weeks to receive unemployment benefits if they are single and have no dependants. This legislation will allow school leavers to reapply for either a job search allowance or unemployment benefits after four weeks, as compared with 13 weeks for the initial application. The coalition takes the view that people should not leave school and expect an immediate hand-out from the Federal Government before they have even had their first job. Therefore, under the Liberal-National Government, all secondary school and tertiary leavers who are over the age of 18 and have no dependants will qualify for a job search allowance only until they have their first job. The coalition sees the present unemployment benefit scheme as being sadly out of date with the reality of modern society. It does not reflect the needs or the wants of the Australian community. Quite simply, it is an unemployment scheme which should be reformed.

To respond to this situation, the coalition has put together an unemployment relief scheme package which we believe restores incentive. Unlike the present Government, we do not wish to condemn those who are unfortunate enough not to have a job to a never ending dependence upon unemployment benefit hand-outs. Unemployment benefits should not be seen as an alternative to employment. To reflect this philosophy, our police will provide unemployment benefits for a maximum of just nine months. When the existing unemployment scheme was initially devised, I do not believe anyone considered that unemployment would be such a long term problem. There is no doubt that as the problem has grown beyond the control of the Government there are some in our society who have simply grown to accept unemployment benefits as an alternative to work. Again, I wish to stress that this is by no means a broad generalisation; nevertheless, it is indicative of an element of those who abuse the system.

The knowledge that unemployment benefits will continue indefinitely reduces the urgency to seek employment, particularly in a situation where government sponsored income support may be on a par with, or perhaps even better than, that which could be expected from an independent income and there being no likelihood of the never ending supply being withdrawn. It is also apparent that officers within the Department find it extremely difficult to administer the existing work test arrangements and staff reductions will ensure that there is less verification of the extent to which applicants are genuinely seeking to gain employment.

To respond to this situation and to provide assistance which is obviously required by job seekers, the coalition is committed to ensuring the provision of intensive job interviews and assessments of the unemployed by officers from the social security, employment and education and training areas. This will facilitate the contact with the Department which the unemployed need if they are to receive the guidance they require. The staff resources of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training need to be maximised to assist the unemployed during the initial nine months. This is crucial to ensuring that the persons concerned return to the work force while they are still motivated and still possess their skills. There is no doubt that a period of long term unemployment not only makes the individual less attractive to a potential employer but also detracts from the skills which the employee can bring to that position.

The Government's response to the initiatives which we have put forward have been very weak, to say the least. In fact, the Government has admitted that there are savings to be made in the area of unemployment benefit. However, it has provided no explanation as to why it has taken so long to acknowledge that the situation even exists. Part of its response has been an attempt to discredit the financial basis on which the coalition's plans are based. Once again, its arguments have been based upon facts which simply do not add up. The coalition believes that special benefits should be made available only to those who are making a genuine attempt to find work and not just to those who may of their own will have chosen to lead an unemployment lifestyle. The Government has cited figures, attempting to claim a leakage from long term unemployment benefits of 80 per cent. This assumption has been politically motivated and is definitely designed to discredit our policy. The Department of Social Security indicates that about 75 per cent of the long term unemployed are under the age of 45, about 65 per cent are single, and over 75 per cent do not have dependent children.

The legislation also includes a provision which attempts to make adjustments to the income test arrangements for the family allowance and family allowance supplement. Section 74b of the principal Act deals with reductions in the rate of the family allowance supplement where there is a decrease or an increase in taxable income. In relation to a decrease, the provision will apply only if the income is at least 25 per cent down on that of the previous year and the threshold level based on the number of dependants. It cannot be denied that the family allowance and family allowance supplement provide significant support for Australia's families. As with other pensions, the coalition supports reasonable indexation arrangements. We have an ongoing commitment to ensuring the protection of the Australian family.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Hawke's promise?
—I was just going to say that when Prime Minister Hawke delivered his election policy speech on 13 November 1984 he made a very hollow promise to the Australian population. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Government sets the welfare of the Australian family as its top priority.

We would have to agree that that promise has come back to haunt him almost as much as his famous words of June 1987 when he said that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990. Unfortunately our present Prime Minister has a habit of making promises on which he fails to deliver. I, for one, am confident that the electorate will remember Labor's string of broken promises when it returns to the ballot box next year.

The very future of the family structure as we know it is under threat-not from an enemy from without, but rather from an enemy from within. The high taxing policies, the high inflation, the crippling interest rates and the unemployment, all of which have been inspired by the Hawke Government, are the things affecting Australian families of today. We do not need reminding that real disposable household income has fallen. An estimated 2.5 million people, one in every eight households, are living in poverty, and 440,000 children are in families living below the poverty line.

Tonight when we climb into our comfortable Canberra beds-those of us who are staying here-we need to remember that 70,000 young Australians will be going to sleep in the streets. They will be found under bridges, under newspapers, and in any area where they are able to provide themselves with some form of shelter. This is a record of neglect that no government should be proud of. It is one that this Government should be condemned for. Not surprisingly, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission has found that in the period from 1981 to 1986 the proportion of marriages ending in divorce increased from 14 per cent to 35 per cent. This is seen as a direct consequence of the pressure the Government is placing on Australian families.

Another consequence is that an increasing number of women and children are being forced to enter the work force in order to supplement family budgets and to cope with the ever increasing living costs, not to mention the ever increasing interest on their housing mortgages. If I remember correctly, that matter has been raised once or twice this week. It is certainly a dramatic increase and that can be shown by the fact that, in July 1980, 41.4 per cent of women with dependent children were working. By June 1988 this figure had risen to 51.2 per cent. Whilst the previous coalition Government increased the rate of the family allowance by 50 per cent for the third and subsequent children in 1981 and by 50 per cent in 1982 for the first and second children, up until April 1989 the present Hawke Government had not seen fit to make any meaningful increases in this allowance.

Quite clearly, there is no doubt that this Government has ignored the family and its importance to our society. The real value of the family allowance, the dependent spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate remains about 20 per cent lower than it was when this Government came to office. The effects of this poverty on the children who are to become our future adults will be that they will be required to leave school earlier, generally they will have more health problems, and many will be permanently disadvantaged by their parents' lack of financial resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989, which is currently before the Senate, I suppose has provoked in the community more outrage, because of the contents of some of the clauses, than I have seen for some time. The major point of contention is the proposal that postpones the unemployment benefit for three months for people who move to an area of high unemployment. The aim of this clause, presumably in the minds of the Government or the departmental adviser who in his or her wisdom dreamed it up, was to discourage people from prolonging their period of unemployment by deliberately going to an area where they knew jobs were scarce so that they would have an excuse to stay on unemployment benefit. I find that a most outrageous suggestion. I think it has taken the syndrome of blaming the victim to new heights or, probably more appropriately, new depths.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the Government and its advisers have bothered to work out just what the demographics are in most of the major cities and most of the major retail areas of this country. Has the Government not worked out not only what the demographics are but also what the income distribution is? If it has not worked out either of those, I suggest that it should have a look at a few figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), or at some of the studies that have come out of the University of New South Wales-or the University of Sydney; I forget which one it is-which recently brought out a report delineating the distribution of income in this country. It is patently apparent to anybody who has a look at the demographics and the income distribution in this country that the two have a tendency to coincide; that the major groups in poverty are families headed by women whose marriages have broken down, or who have been widowed; who are left raising children; who are dependent on some sort of social security benefit; and families where one or more of the adults are unemployed. Those two groups make up two of the three major low income groups in this country, the third group, of course, being those people in their retirement years who are solely dependent on the age pension and have no other source of income.

So the Government should have been able to work out, if it tried even a little, that the unemployed are among the poorest in the community. They are, therefore, the ones who are most likely to need low income housing. In case greater minds than mine have not noticed this in the bureaucracy, low income housing has a tendency, certainly in South Australia, to be public housing units. The cheapest housing that is available is that housing which, in the case of South Australia, comes from the South Australian Housing Trust. Again in South Australia-and I presume that this is true of other States-the largest pools of public housing and the cheapest private housing rental accommodation are, surprise, surprise, in areas of highest unemployment. The two have a tendency to go together in places like Whyalla, the Riverland, Elizabeth and some parts of the south-east where jobs are rarely available in the long term and only occasionally available to some unemployed people on a seasonal basis.

Yet here we have the Government saying, `If you are unemployed and you are seeking low-cost accommodation and you live in a State where that accommodation is predominantly found in an area of high unemployment, we will deny you a further three months of unemployment benefit'. So, presumably people who move there, or who are actually sent there by the public Housing Trust authorities, will be hit harder than they have ever been hit before. What do they do when they go into the Adelaide office of the Housing Trust? Do they say, `Please put me on your list for a unit that is suitable to my family's needs, but make sure you do not put me in an area where there is high unemployment because, if you do, the Government will deny me unemployment benefit for a further three months and I will not be able to pay the rent anyway'?

Does the Government really intend-is it a deliberate intention-to penalise those families where unemployment is a problem, by delaying unemployment benefit by a further three months because they have to move from an area and accommodation they can no longer afford to an area where rents are low and, coincidentally, unemployment is high? Is there some sort of deliberate policy? Does the Government think that this will suddenly magically produce a job or magically produce the skills in the individual that will make him suitable to take a job that previously he had not been able to take? I suggest that, if that is the idea behind it, a few people on sizeable salaries, both on the Government benches and in the bureaucracy, need to get out there into the community and have a look at what life is really like. Simply to exclude from this loss of benefit people who move into a targeted area where other members of their family already happen to live-and that seems to be the only exclusion-is bizarre and, I might add, gives a whole new meaning to the term `family reunion'. Why should the people who move into an area where housing costs are low and where unemployment is high be entitled to retain unemployment benefit if, and only if, some other member of the family coincidentally happens to be living there? What if there are not any additional members of the family even living in that State, much less in those sorts of areas?

So we have a ludicrous situation where the Government is compounding an already serious problem of poverty, low self-esteem, family problems and other sorts of social problems that stem from unemployment and from low income households by saying, `If you choose to ease your financial problems by moving from an area where housing costs are relatively high to one where they are relatively low, and in doing so you move into an area where unemployment levels are high, bad luck, buster. You are going to be further financially impeded because we are going to take unemployment benefit away from you for a further three months'. No wonder we saw demonstrations held outside the Department of Social Security offices today, like the one in Footscray in Victoria where people met to protest against these cuts to unemployment benefit when people move to these areas of so-called low employment. I think it is worth while quoting what one of the speakers there had to say. She said:
It is an outrage that the Government intends to place a further financial burden on people in receipt of unemployment benefits and falsely assumes that the unemployed do not want work.

This is precisely the sort of assumption that was made by the Opposition and echoed by Mr Elliott, when the Opposition decided that it would penalise the long term unemployed, when he said, `This is not hitting at social welfare recipients; it is taking from the bludgers to give to the workers'. That is a nice, trite statement that certainly played on the prejudices of many Australians who believe that the long term unemployed are lay-about teenagers, and who do not bother to look at ABS figures that indicate that people who are long term unemployed fall into two main groups: males over 40 who have been made redundant by their previous employer for one reason or another, frequently because the firm has moved towards high technology or high mechanisation areas; and women over the age of 45 who have been at home for 20 or more years raising children and who are now seeking work. Quite often it is because the marriage has broken down because her husband has found somebody younger and more exciting and gone off with her, and she is forced to support a 15- or 16-year-old who possibly wants to go on to university. Those are the people who are finding it difficult to get jobs. The statement from the speaker at the protest rally in Footscray today went on to say:

This cynical money saving exercise is grossly unfair and discriminatory. It effectively denies freedom of movement and increases the financial burden on an already financially disadvantaged group in our community.

Where is the Labor Party's commitment now to those who voted it into government, those people who supported it in 1983, who believed its political propaganda at that and subsequent elections that Labor would improve the economy so that by 1990 no child would be in poverty and that all people who wanted work would be able to get it, and that it was really there to look after the workers of the world and people who were least able to look after themselves-that is, age pensioners and people living in poverty?

Where are the Labor senators who were here in 1982 and joined the Democrats in defeating the iniquitous legislation introduced by the Fraser Government in relation to the wives of strikers? Where are the Labor senators who got up in the Senate chamber and decried attempts by a conservative government to blame the wives and children of men who had gone out on strike as though they were responsible for what their husbands and fathers were doing? Yet here we have another Bill aimed at blaming the victims for circumstances which are frequently beyond their control. I know where they are-or at least I know where they are not. Where they are not is in this chamber. Where they are not is in here either defending this legislation and letting us hear some of their reasons for voting for it in Caucus or saying why they believe this Government has gone wrong yet again. They are all, more or less, absent from the chamber, as they have been increasingly since 1983 as the current Labor Government moves further and further to the Right and becomes increasingly conservative and almost indistinguishable from the main Opposition party in this place. It is no longer true that there are significant differences between the Labor Party and the Liberal-National Party coalition. It is only a matter of degree. The Labor Party says it will cut expenditure in welfare, health and education areas, and the Liberal Party says that it will cut it a bit more. The Labor Party says that it will penalise people who do not have jobs, and the Liberal Party says that it will penalise them a little bit more.

It was bad enough, I suggest, in 1986 when the Government decided to increase its surplus and decrease its expenditure by delaying consumer price index increases to age pensioners by six weeks, just before Christmas. Not only was that an enormous impediment at that time to the elderly, who normally look to that half-yearly increase to give them the extra money that they need to stock up for Christmas or to buy their grandchildren presents, but it also hit very hard the small business sector, in particular the small retailing sector, which depends on its pre-Christmas trading to make up for losses in the low income parts of the year. But that did not seem to concern the Labor Party, nor the Opposition members who supported that legislation. Much more important, apparently, was to get a significant surplus to impress Moody's Investor Services Inc., Standard and Poor's Corporation, the big business community, or whatever.

On top of that the Government then moved to discount ex-service and defence pensions by 2 per cent and went on in 1987 to take Austudy payments away from those low income families who had a 15-year-old in one of the last two years of school, something which did not much affect New South Wales and Victoria but which had enormous effect on low income families in South Australia. I do not recall another piece of legislation that has led to so many women ringing my office in tears with stories about the effects of that loss of income-and it amounted to something like $40 a week maximum. The families concerned had to be very poor indeed to qualify for it. They were then going to be forced to take their children out of school. Of course, at that time the Government made quite sure that there were no benefits for youngsters of that age who were unemployed. So Austudy went out the window for those groups. Again, they were sacrificed on the altar of a high Budget surplus to impress the big business community and presumably to keep the Government in power in the election that followed that year.

Forty-five-year-old widows copped it in the neck that same year when the Government decided that once their youngest child turned 16 they did not need to be on the class B widows' pension any more, that they did not need to be a recipient of government assistance, that they could go out and get themselves a job, and that, if they could not get themselves a job, they could go on unemployment benefit. The latter, of course, meant a cut in income since the class B widows' pension was bringing in, with its size and its additional benefits, a greater income than the unemployment benefit.

They also lost significantly in another area, an area which is just as important as the financial one. They lost out psychologically, because their self-esteem took an incredible battering. Those business people who argued that the Government had to get an increased surplus by cutting expenditure in welfare areas and who were quite happy to see 45-year-old women on the class B widows' pension targeted are the very people who will not give a job to a woman in her mid-forties who has been out of the work force for 20 or more years. Why? It is because they give those women absolutely no credit at all for developing any sort of managerial, budgetary or personnel skills in all the years that they have spent raising their families. This Government, it seems, is hell-bent on proving that it can bash the less well off, that it can penalise those people who are the most powerless, and that it can blame the most victims even better than the Opposition can. So much for no child living in poverty by 1990. So much for putting families high on people's list of priorities in government.

I would like to know from the Minister or anybody else in government how the Government believes that denying these benefits will keep people out of poverty. How does the Government believe it will keep families together? I ask how it can argue that its aims are fairness, justice and equity for all when, on the one hand, it is prepared to spend $2,000m cutting company tax by 20 per cent, from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar, at a time when some businesses are paying no tax, thanks to the use of negative gearing and then, on the other hand, to cover the costs of that, make it up by taking widows of 45 years of age off the class B widows' pension and sending them out to try to find work, taking Austudy payments away from 15-years-olds, depriving ex-service and defence personnel of an overdue increase in their pension and saying to the unemployed: `If, in order to save costs on housing, you move to an area where unemployment is recognised as being high, we will take your benefits away from you altogether for another three months'. I say to the Labor Government: it is about time it had a look at the roots from which it claims it sprang and saw just how far it has moved away from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to make before making my substantive contribution to this debate. Firstly, I say to Senator Calvert that I am very disappointed that he, too, should join the serried ranks opposite who clearly have the same speech, full of the same inaccuracies and wrong figures. Senator Calvert seemed to suggest that there had been no drop in unemployment benefit paid out or in the number of unemployed people in the term of this Government. Indeed, he suggested the reverse. For the record, I say to Senator Calvert, who has long since left this chamber, that there were about 630,000 unemployed people when we came to office. There are now 350,000 unemployed people, with long term savings of $5 billion. That is a lot of people who are no longer unemployed. If Senator Calvert keeps on saying that unemployment numbers have increased, one can only doubt his capacity to understand simple figures. There were 630,000 unemployed people when we came to government. There are 350,000 unemployed people now. Those figures are fairly clear and easy to understand. They are contrary to his claim.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I say to Senator Haines, `Good stuff, but very wide of the mark'. To suggest that there is no difference between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party is a measure of Senator Haines's lack of understanding. The Labor Government has been very concerned to address the problem of unemployed people, the problem of poverty and the best ways to assist people out of poverty. We have had, within our own ranks as well as across this chamber, considerable debate about the best way to assist people out of poverty. Paying them benefits to keep them on a modest income for the rest of their lives is no way to do it. The Liberal Opposition's policy-to forget them after nine months, to never speak to them again and to put them on special benefits-is probably the very worst strategy. I am advised that it would not be unlike a return to the good old Chaney-led social security days, way back then.

The Opposition's policy is to say to anybody else: `The best we can offer you is $100 a week for the rest of your life and if you are'-as Senator Haines wanted to say-`a little behind; if you are out of a job because you have had insufficient education, what we will do is keep paying you unemployment benefit, but we will not speak to you. We will not care if you never come in for an interview. We will not care if you do not have the skills or the bridging courses to get back into a job. We will not worry about that'. The best we can do, according to Senator Haines, if we are to help people, is to keep on paying modest unemployment benefits and forget people. That is not this Government's policy. It should be clear to people that this Government is concerned to assist those who are on unemployment benefit by saying that we think the very worst thing that can happen to people is if they are left on unemployment benefit forever.

We have established Newstart and the jobs, education and training (JET) program specifically targeted, in the first case to long term unemployed, and, in the second, to sole parent beneficiaries. We have said to both of those categories of people: `We think the best way out of poverty is the income security of a job. To get a job we know that you need education, bridging courses, or other assistance'-even in establishing the confidence that Senator Haines referred to. Absolutely. It is this Government and its specifically targeted policies that are addressing those needs.

Unemployed people do not get ignored by this Government. They get assistance to become employed because the Government knows, and so do the people out there, that it is much better to have a job than to have unemployment benefit. That is unarguably the fact. Senator Haines took us way back to when the pensioners, for example, had to contribute to all of this by taking a six-week delay in the payment of their pensions. She did not also say that, in the last Budget, that payment is now brought forward, not only by the six weeks but by a further six weeks. It is brought forward by 12 weeks to compensate pensioners and to restore the pension, as well as increase it. We did not hear that from Senator Haines. We did not hear Senator Haines say that, at the time that was done, the Government faced one of the worst economic crises this country has ever faced. It spared no group in the community when it asked the people to make their contribution.

I have spoken to pensioner groups and I have heard people say, `Yes, it was terribly tough but we are not sad and we are not ashamed of having made our contribution to the economic recovery of this community'. I say to Senator Haines: if none of those things had been done, where would this country be now? Arguably, it would be much worse off.

It is also true that widows with children over 16 moved from the widows' pension to unemployment benefit. Senator Haines would seem to suggest that only 45-year-old women with no work force skills for the last 20 years suffered. But in all of this I did not hear Senator Haines saying, `And what about the workers of this country who have actually seen a real wage reduction traded off against the social wage, traded off against the creation of 1.5 million jobs in the last six years?'. This is the party of concern and consensus across the board. It involves the whole community. It does not pick off one section or another when it is asking for the tough stuff or when it is handing out the good stuff. It has its priorities but it says, `Everyone will be involved'. Senator Haines's speech was out of date. It was also wrong.

Ultimately, Senator Haines is very good at pointing out the insufficiencies, as she sees them, of the Liberal Party or the Labor Party, but I have never yet heard her declare what she would do. I presume from her speech today that the Australian Democrats would continue massive unemployment benefit payments to anybody who wanted to be unemployed, would do nothing to encourage people to cease to be unemployed and would persist with women being on class B widows' pensions and not encourage them, at whatever age, to get jobs. Senator Haines should also know that there is legislation lying on the table of the South Australian Parliament, introduced by a person who is no longer, I suspect, the member for Hayward, June Appleby, to make sure that there is no age discrimination against women, or men for that matter, who apply for jobs when they are over 35 years. That anti-age discrimination legislation is still lying on the table of the South Australian Parliament. So yes, we are aware of the problems, but the difference between a Labor government and a Democrat leader is that we are in a position to do something about them. I have never heard Senator Haines say what she would do. However, she is very good at complaining-again and again.

This is a significant cognate debate, covering the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4). It covers a number of significant areas of change and policy measures announced in the Budget. They include aged care, youth policies, and matters concerning the unemployed. In particular, I want to talk about the arrangements for sole parent beneficiary assessment, about eligibility for the sole parent's pension. I appreciate the time constraints; so I will try to make my comments brief. For the record, the Labor Caucus and the Labor Government have been very concerned, in addressing this issue, to pay considerable attention to the concerns of women in the community. Those concerns have been raised with a number of us over the last six months or so. I assure any women listening that those concerns have been taken very seriously. They have been addressed by the Government and the Caucus in the form of a special working group to make sure that the changes in this legislation did take account of the concerns raised by women in the community.

One thing that was clear was that the assessment of who was eligible for sole parent benefits sometimes became quite arbitrary, because there were no clear guidelines, rules, or indicators for departmental officers to follow when making that assessment. This legislation makes the list of indicators that departmental people must follow much clearer. It sets out a thoughtful and considered process in order to help people. It is designed to curtail any invasion of the privacy of the people concerned. It also allows the person applying for the sole parent pension or its continuation to give the Department all the information it needs by filling in forms or attending interviews in the departmental office. The home is not to be available for interview, unless a person makes that decision. Essentially, it is now a departmental procedure, and I think this will be helpful to both the people involved and the departmental officers. It is much clearer, much more accurate and much less arbitrary.

Those things are not done, as Senator Haines would suggest, because we are cruel or harsh but, rather, because we are fired by exactly the opposite-a concern to ensure privacy, accuracy, fairness and equity in relation to making those payments. I think this matter will be much better addressed with these clearer indicators and procedures outlined under this legislation. I hope that, if any women in the community who have raised concerns are listening, they will appreciate that considerable thought and effort has gone into addressing the problems that they have raised.

It is particularly useful in the legislation that, after the information has been provided in a series of sequential interviews, one leading to the next if necessary, the Secretary must make a decision, near enough to forthwith, on that evidence that the person is or is not eligible for a pension. This legislation requires that decision to be made. There is no possibility for the decision to drift on, with people living in a state of indecision. If pensioners or prospective pensioners are unhappy with the decision, they will be advised of the opportunity to appeal. If they are already on a pension, the pension will continue pending resolution of the appeal. If they are not, of course, they will still have the opportunity to apply for that appeal. So, in all sorts of ways I think the properly voiced concerns about this area of the legislation have been dealt with very sympathetically and constructively in the interests not only of the departmental officers who will have the administration in this area but also of those single parent pensioners who are applying either for the first time or for a continuation.

Once a person is assessed as being eligible for a sole parent pension, that assessment will apply for 12 weeks, and the pensioner can be assured that, during that three-month period, there will be no further examination of his circumstances or a requirement to provide information about their circumstances, unless of course he advises the Department of a significant change in his circumstances. As I said earlier, because of the time constraints I will confine my remarks to those I have made. I urge support of these very significant and comprehensive pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will restrict my remarks to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) and speak specifically to clause 35. Clause 35 seeks to amend the Social Security Act 1947 so that people will not be able to claim an invalid pension once they reach 65 years of age in the case of males or 60 years in the case of females. The Government has said that it has introduced this legislation in order to prevent older migrants claiming invalid pension. Instead, an older migrant will have to claim special benefit, which will be recoverable from the person's relatives if they have signed an assurance of support in respect of that person. The Government claims that this step is necessary because the current legislation is inconsistent with age pension residence requirements. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) stated in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the clear purpose of invalid pension as a payment related to incapacity for work for people of work force age.

However, I put it to the Senate that this step will create an inequitable circumstance. In fact, various ethnic groups have lobbied to this effect. It will be inequitable because the families of older migrants will be forced to meet the cost of unforeseen injury and illness which occur after the person has arrived in Australia. At present people have to wait until they have completed 10 years of residence before they are eligible for an age pension, which of course is a foreseen circumstance. A person knows how long it will take to reach pensionable age, but people who come to Australia able-bodied and able to work cannot foresee that they may have an accident or, because of unforeseen illness, find themselves unable to work. If that occurs, that person is placed, correctly, on an invalid pension. It is quite unnecessary to target and discriminate against older and newly arrived migrants and put them in a different class of citizen from other Australian citizens. Under the current Social Security Act, any working person, regardless of age or length of permanent residence in Australia, is eligible for the invalid pension.

The special benefit is to be available only to people who are deemed to be destitute. Further, the special benefit will not be a benefit at all for newly arrived migrants, because the Government is in a position to recover this payment from those migrants' relatives who have signed an assurance for support. That is now mandatory for migrants who seek to bring older relatives to Australia under the family reunion program. Therefore, the introduction of these changes would constitute a gross violation of the Government's social justice principles of access and equity and the Government's stated commitment to multiculturalism. Only a few weeks ago we had the launch for the multiculturalism agenda. It would also partly dismantle the very reform introduced by a previous Labor government to alleviate hardship faced by migrants.

Since 1908 the invalid pension has been paid in respect of permanent incapacity for work, and at present there is no age limit in recognition that people's capacity for work does not necessarily vanish on the day that they turn 65 years in the case of a man or 60 years in the case of a woman. In fact, a substantial number of people continue to work for many years after they reach pensionable age. This has been recognised by the Government in its change to the taxation of non-pension incomes for age pensioners and in allowing many of those holding government appointments to continue to work until they reach 70 years of age. However, the proposed changes will confine eligibility for an invalid pension to working age people. The Government has justified this change on two grounds. The first is that the current eligibility guidelines are inconsistent with age pension residence requirements, but this is an illogical claim because the invalid pension has the same residence requirement as does the age pension unless the person became ill or injured after arrival in Australia.

It must also be borne in mind that, in the case of workers injured on the job, the Government has a clear responsibility to ensure an adequate income for an individual and for his or her dependants. This is, and will continue to be, the case for those younger people who are injured at work or become ill. Therefore, the proposed changes are clearly inequitable, forcing families of older migrants to meet the costs of injury or illness occurring after arrival in Australia and promoting a dependence which does not apply to other members of the community. The second justification by the Government for this step is that the change will prevent older migrants from receiving invalid pension.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the revised Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations which came into effect on 25 July 1989, for what reasons have the following items been deleted from the new version:
(a) armour plate designed for warlike purposes (original Item 5);
(b) assault bridges (Item 6);
(c) equipment designed or adapted for making smoke screens (Item 10B);
(d) factory and tool equipment designed or adapted for the maintenance of any goods specified in Parts 1A and 1B (Item 12);
(e) factory and tool equipment designed or adapted for the production or maintenance of goods specified in Parts II and III (Item 12);
(f) personal appliances and equipment designed or adapted for warlike purposes (Item 23);
(g) towed target equipment and photographic equipment designed or adapted for warlike purposes (Item 30); and
(h) training equipment designed or adapted for warlike purposes (Item 31)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Armour plate designed for warlike purposes is now covered by Item 17 Part 1A of Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations.

(b) Assault bridges of the type mounted on tracked vehicles such as the assault bridge derivative of the Leopard tank are now covered by Item 4 Part 1B. Other types of bridges such as the old demountable Bailey bridge are not controlled under Schedule 13 in view of being neither lethal nor likely to be of major military significance.
(c) Military smoke screens are created by shells and grenades which are controlled under Item 6 and Item 7 Part 1A.

(d), (e) Factory tools and equipment for production are now controlled under Item 5 Part 1B. Maintenance equipment is not controlled under Schedule 13 in view of being non-lethal nor likely to be of major military significance.

(f) Personal appliances and equipment of a lethal type are controlled for example under Items 1, 3, 4, 6 and 7, Part 1A and any equipment issued to servicemen likely to be of major military significance controlled under Part 1B e.g. manpack radios under Item 6. Personal items such as military uniforms, mess tins and eating utensils are not controlled under Schedule 13 in view of being non-lethal nor likely to be of major military significance.

(g) Vessels, aircraft and vehicles designed or adapted for military purposes (other than those controlled under item 13 Part 1A) which are used for towing targets are controlled under Item 4 Part 1B. Photographic equipment designed or adapted for warlike purposes is controlled under Items 2 and 3 Part 1B.

(h) Training equipment of a lethal or explosive nature is controlled under Part 1A, for example training ammunition under Item 6 Part 1A. Non-lethal training equipment likely to be of major military significance is controlled under part 1B, for example target aircraft under Item 4 Part 1B. Items such as rifle range targets being neither lethal nor of major military significance are not controlled under Schedule 13.

Except for maintenance equipment, the few items referred to above as not controlled under Schedule 13 are however controlled under Schedule 14 as amended on 25 July 1989 and export may be prohibited to South Africa and Namibia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to an announcement made on 14 October 1986 on a package of measures designed to assist Australian industry to bid for Defence work and to develop and export military and related products: (a) what assistance has been provided to exporters or potential exporters of defence products by the Department of Defence since October 1986, and what was the cost of this assistance; (b) what indigenous defence products have been evaluated by Defence and to whom have the evaluation reports been supplied; and (c) has any arrangement been reached with overseas customers to establish and draw on spares holdings belonging to the Australian Defence Force; if so, who are these customers and what spares or parts were involved.

(2) In the same announcement, the Minister announced that discussions were proceeding between Defence and AUSTRADE to enable the latter to better exploit export opportunities for defence products: (a) what is AUSTRADE's strategy for facilitating the export of defence products; (b) what products are being marketed; (c) who are the principal targets of the export strategy; (d) what is the annual cost of implementing the strategy; and (e) has the strategy been considered by Cabinet.

(3) On 14 June 1988 it was announced that the Government had agreed to new principles for the control of defence exports, and that the revised guidelines would be published in order to make the new export control system transparent and to facilitate `necessary and welcome dialogue between exporters and responsible officials': (a) what are the revised policy guidelines for the export of defence material: (i) do exports to New Zealand, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada still require an End User Certificate stipulating that the items will not be re-sold to a third country without Australian concurrence, (ii) do the guidelines continue to divide items of defence material into Category I, II, and III items and how are these used in the consideration of export applications, and (iii) under what circumstances is the Department of Defence required to consult with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce in the consideration of export applications; and (b) when are the new policy guidelines being made available to the public.
(4) How many applications to export defence products or material were received by the Department of Defence in the financial years 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1988-89.
(5) What proportion of these applications came from non-government enterprises.
(6) What proportion of the total applications for each financial year were: (a) approved; (b) declined; (c) withdrawn; or (d) remained under consideration.
(7) What was the value of the approved applications in each financial year.
(8) What proportion of the approved applications for each financial year resulted in sales and what was the value of those sales.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Assistance provided to exporters has included:
issue of export permits and advice on acceptability of proposed export markets
evaluation of products and provision of test facilities
co-ordination of industry missions overseas, product displays and attendance at exhibitions and trade fairs
advice to exporters on doing business in particular markets including provision of market research data
loan of personnel and equipment
Service stewardship of in-service products being promoted overseas and in Australia including the use of Defence Attaches
licensing of defence products/technologies for sales to third parties
negotiation of various collaborative agreements
publication of `Doing Australian Defence Business' and `Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods'.
Direct costs above those required for Defence purposes are recovered from or paid separately by the exporters.

(b) The majority of indigenous defence products are developed to satisfy specific Australian Defence Force requirements. During the course of the development the performance of the equipment is evaluated and the manufacturer advised accordingly. Two examples are the 1 and 2 tonne vehicles for the Army and the Minehunter for the Navy. There are occasions when the manufacturers of military equipment not destined for service with the Australian Defence Force, have the equipment evaluated by the Department. In these instances the manufacturer is required to meet the costs of the evaluation and is provided with a report.
(c) Arrangements are in place with the Governments of the United States, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Fiji (currently inoperative), and Tonga.

These arrangements cover a wide variety of spares from within the 1.4 million line items in the ADF inventory. They generally cover the less complex technical spares and include minor spare parts for radios, rifles, other field equipment, aircraft and ships electronic system components, and general mechanical equipment.

Issues of spares are made on a cost recovery or replacement-in-kind basis. There are no additional stockholdings established to support these arrangements. Issues are made at no detriment to the operations of the Australian Defence Force.

(2) (a) An export strategy is being developed between Defence and Austrade for defence related products and is planned to be considered by a number of other government departments, including the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Industry, Technology and Commerce early in the new year.
(b) The export strategy will involve the complete range of defence products, services and capabilities available in Australia.
(c) The strategy will list the main target markets as USA, Middle East and South East Asia, recognising the sensitivities where appropriate.
(d) Detailed cost estimates for implementation of the export strategy have not been done since the strategy has yet to be formally agreed.
(e) The strategy has not been considered by Cabinet.

(3) (a) I understand the Department of Defence has provided your office with a copy of the publication `Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods-Guidelines for Exporters' (July 1989). This 21 page document sets out the revised policy guidelines for the export of defence materiel.
(i) Yes.
(ii) The guidelines divide the items under control into three parts, viz
Part 1a-Goods designed or adapted for military purposes and inherently lethal, incapacitating or destructive
1b-Other military and related goods.
Part 2-Cryptographic and related electronic equipment and software.
Part 3-Non-military lethal goods. These parts reflect the type of goods and the level of sensitivity. The guidelines set out the various considerations which apply.

(iii) a. The Department of Defence is required to consult with relevant Departments including the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Industry, Technology and Commerce if there are sensitivities regarding strategic, international or human rights issues. An exception is where the proposed export is lethal or of major military significance and to go to a destination which is clearly unacceptable to the Government in accordance with its Guidelines. In this case the Department can recommend direct to the Minister to deny the export. Further details regarding the criteria for considering export applications are contained in paras. 8-12, 36-37 of the Guidelines. Once approvals are given these act as precedents for follow-on sales unless circumstances change in the meantime.

b. The new guidelines were made available to the public from 24 July 1989 after advertisements appeared on that date in a major newspaper in each State or Territory and some national newspapers indicating availability of the document.

(5) About 91% of these were from non-government enterprises.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Defence: Funding of Local Government

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much and under which programs did your Department appropriate moneys for the use of local government authorities in the 1988/89 financial year.
(2) How much and under which programs does your Department estimate will be appropriated for the use of local government authorities during the current financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Commonwealth through its agent the Natural Disasters Organisation provides direct assistance to local government authorities by way of dollar for dollar subsidies towards the cost of providing accommodation for local State/Territory Emergency Service units up to a maximum of $10,000 per project. In special circumstances this payment can be exceeded to take account of such factors as very high transport costs of materials and/or abnormal labour costs.
(b) Expenditure is appropriated under the Program `Assistance to the State and Territories' with provision being made for the financial years 1988/89 and 1989/90 as follows:

(c) In respect to the current financial year provision was made on the basis of bids submitted by Directors State/Territory Emergency Services in the context of Budget Estimates. There is presently no backlog of applications.
